fields.headline: Linda Grant's top 10 Jewish books
fields.trailText: Linda Grant is the winner of the 2000 Orange Prize with When I Lived in Modern Times
fields.body:
Linda Grant is the winner of the 2000 Orange Prize with When I Lived in Modern Times.
Buy When I lived in Modern Times at Amazon.co.uk

1. The Truce by Primo Levi
Levi's journey back to Italy after the liberation. One of the great life-affirming works - and extremely funny.

2. The Book of Jewish Food by Claudia Roden
Not merely a recipe book but a history of the Diaspora told through the medium of the Jews' real religion, eating.

3. American Pastoral by Philip Roth
Hard to know which of Roth's fantastic big-hitters of the past decade to choose, but this is probably the best.

4. The Adventures of Augie March by Saul Bellow
The chronicle of American Jewish immigration.

5. In Dreams Begin Responsibilities and other stories by Delmore Schwartz
Collection of stories by a now almost forgotten genius.

6. Don't Call it Night by Amos Oz
Israel's leading contemporary novelist.

7. The Romance of American Communism by Vivian Gornick
Gornick's oral history of the first- and second-generation Jewish immigrants who formed the American Communist Party.

8. Buchmendel by Stephan Zweig
A short story set in his beloved Jewish Vienna, later destroyed by fascism.

9. Auschwitz: 1270 to the Present by Deborah Dwork and Robert van der Pelt
Definitive account of what, when, where, how and why.

10. Konin: A Quest by Theo Richmond
Reconstruction from the ashes of history of a turn-of-the-century shtetl.

(and Bernard Malamud's The Fixer, and Joachim Shlor's Tel Aviv: From Dream to Reality, and George Steiner's In Bluebeard's Castle, and...)

fields.headline: Debenhams to build 11 new stores
fields.standfirst: Creation of 4,000 jobs encouraged by strong clothing sales
fields.trailText: Debenhams yesterday disclosed plans to create 4,000 jobs through the opening of 11 new department stores over the next four years as its latest sales figures showed a strong surge.
fields.body:
Debenhams yesterday disclosed plans to create 4,000 jobs through the opening of 11 new department stores over the next four years as its latest sales figures showed a strong surge.

The £150m roll-out in cities such as Oxford, Newcastle-upon-Tyne and Edinburgh comes as other high street names including C&A and Top-Shop owner Arcadia have been closing shops.

The Debenhams expansion has been encouraged by a 6.6% increase in clothing sales over the past 10 weeks compared with the same period last year, and excluding new stores.

Overall sales were up 3.3%, above City expectations, at a time when poor weather has been blamed by other retailers for a drop in business. But worries about mounting costs meant Debenhams shares closed last night at 206p, down 9p.

The group operates 91 stores around Britain. It plans to increase the number through newbuild developments such as the Bull Ring facelift in Birmingham city centre.

The shops will average 80,000sq ft and offer clothes, cosmetics and accessories. Around 350 jobs will be created in each outlet but 40% of them will be part-time posts.

The company is pushing ahead with clicks as well as bricks, saying yesterday that its sales through the internet are about to exceed £5m in its first year of trading. It is also planning to double the distribution levels of its first home shopping catalogue, Debenhams Direct.

Peter Jarvis, the company's chairman said: "We believe that the ongoing improvement in like-for-like sales over the last six months endorses our strategy and we are confident we can continue to achieve robust levels of growth."

The company said the improved trading position resulted from a strong performance from own brand goods an increase in advertising and more competitive pricing.

Richard Ratner, retail analyst with Seymour Pierce, said Debenhams had done "pretty well" on the sales side. But he pointed out that House of Fraser had increased sales by 6.1% and even hard-pressed Allders had raised its figures by 5% over the summer.

Ratner expressed concern that costs were up 6% at Debenhams and Nick Bubb at SG Securities said gross margins were "a bit disappointing". Profit estimates for the year are likely to remain in the £120m-£140m range.

Retail consultancy Verdict Research said Debenham was succeeding because it was giving customers what they wanted, with "a focused range". By contrast C & A is pulling out of Britain completely at a cost of 4,800 jobs.

webTitle: Pop review: Stoking the fiery beat

fields.headline: Stoking the fiery beat
fields.standfirst: Billy Cobham/Ed Thigpen Queen Elizabeth Hall, London ****
fields.trailText: Billy Cobham/Ed Thigpen Queen Elizabeth Hall, London ****
fields.body:
As part of the South Bank's Rhythm Sticks festival, the BBC Big Band laid on this action-packed two-part programme featuring the talents of two wildly contrasting percussionists.

The venerable Ed Thigpen can cite a list of performing credits with some of the classic names of jazz, from Ella Fitzgerald to Oscar Peterson. In the second half, super-sticksman Billy Cobham seized centre stage for a display of the thermonuclear technique that transformed jazz-fusion in the 70s.

But the Big Band were never overshadowed by their stellar guests, and indeed it has become a mark of their collective expertise that they're able to fit in comfortably with interlopers from virtually any musical background.

Thigpen is sticksman and also entertainer, wisecracking with the band and laying on fancy exhibitions of brush technique, hands-on tomtom playing and even a smattering of scat singing. However, he was at his best when he did the fundamental things without fuss. With a whip of the wrist or a turn of the shoulder he could slip easily into a samba or bossa nova. When the band were roaring full blast through a suite of Duke Ellington pieces, Ed was right with them, stoking the beat with a minimum of effort.

Billy Cobham's set was based around his new recording "concept" which is apparently designed to give musicians the opportunity to play along with a virtual jazz orchestra.

In the flesh, Cobham, positioned behind his huge honey-coloured Yamaha kit, stormed through a batch of pieces which took full advantage of the band's dazzling array of colours, from trumpets and saxophones to vibes and beefy electric guitar. Cobham buffs will have recognised Stratus and Crosswinds, although not in these arrangements, while the new piece Conundrum zigzagged from riotous chords to passages of eerie calm. Cobham's drum solo suffered only mildly from superstar bombast. Tragically, the hall was far from full.

webTitle: Art review: When new is nowhere

fields.headline: When new is nowhere
fields.standfirst: It May be a Year of Thirteen Moons but It's Still the Year of Culture Transmission Gallery, Glasgow *****
fields.trailText: It May be a Year of Thirteen Moons but It's Still the Year of Culture Transmission Gallery, Glasgow *****
fields.body:
Subversion from within is a fine thing to encounter. Iain Irving's recent project, The Blue Chamber at Duff House, placed ironic work in the grandeur of a country house gallery. But this show, curated by Charisma (Keith Farquhar and Lucy Mackenzie) raises the subversive stakes by placing its mocking critique at the heart of Glasgow's art scene, the artist-run Transmission Gallery.

We are all implicated. Mackenzie made a horribly welcoming vestibule of Mackintosh-style doors. Charisma self-consciously include work by non-Scottish artists such as Markus Selg and Albert Oehlen to point up the tendency towards parochialism; they provocatively include work by 80s star Steven Campbell.

His metaphoric paintings got him hung in Glasgow's GOMA - enough to render him unmentionable in galleries like Transmission. His presence makes you ponder the gulf between work that sells and work that sits in cutting-edge spaces. It forces reflection on the relationship between commercial, museum and artist-run spaces and how we need them all.

The work on show deliberately collides, clashes, bewilders. Next to Farquhar's funny installation, Polymorph Moderne: Sex in Scotland 2000, sits Oehlen's glossy abstract painting. On one wall, Selg's ink-jet prints are all superficial weirdness; opposite sits Campbell, roaring politically in this new context. As an exhibition it precisely captures how impossible avant-gardism is as a position these days when we no longer know where the garde is.

Until August 6. Details: 0141-552 4813.

webTitle: It's a dirty job, but someone's got to do it

fields.headline: It's a dirty job, but someone's got to do it
fields.standfirst:
What kind of person injects dead bodies for a living, or gets excited about removing fat from sewers, or chases us for unpaid tax? Merope Mills meets three people who dread being asked, what do you do?

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: What kind of person injects dead bodies for a living, or gets excited about removing fat from sewers, or chases us for unpaid tax? Merope Mills meets three people who dread being asked, what do you do?
fields.body:
I am quite pleased not to be meeting Rob Smith. He says he's too busy doing his job to take time out to tell me about it in person but has agreed to chat on the phone. Phew, I thought, actually quite relieved we weren't going to come face to face. It's not that I don't like Smith. On the contrary, in the conversations we've had he was a very cheerful, friendly, pleasant kind of guy. But here's the thing ... I think he might smell.

Smith's job is to "keep on top of what's underground", which is the polite way of saying he works in the sewers. Actually, the really polite term is "catchment support engineer", which probably goes down better at parties as well. In a society where people increasingly define you by your profession, it must be hard, I imagine, to have a job with the popular appeal of an evening with Enoch Powell.

Not at all, corrects Smith. "A lot of people find sewers very interesting. There was a point when so many people wanted to come down it was impinging on the day job." I stand corrected. But who? Architects, he tells me, are the most enthusiastic. Apparently, the Victorian brick-work in the Thames sewers is quite alluring. "The construction is unique. The workmanship is superb," he enthuses. "It's beautiful for people who appreciate that sort of thing. I have the pleasure to work in the modern-day sewers, which are pretty fantastic, but it's the older ones that are magnificent."

Fantastic. Pleasurable. Magnificent. Not the sort of adjectives you'd expect to hear from a sewage worker, but it's how Smith chooses to define his work. "I thoroughly enjoy my job. There are times when the phone call comes and it's an emergency and you're really in the thick of it. I was in charge of the Leicester Square fat problem," he boasts, assuming I already know about the sewage crisis that resulted from too many fast food outlets pouring their fat down the sink. "It was a 4ft solid egg shape of fat. Totally blocked. I get those sort of projects, the interesting ones - or, I guess, the ones which no one else wants."

Claudine Lashley knows all about projects that no one else wants - she's been working for the Inland Revenue for 20 years. When she started as a lowly revenue assistant, it didn't matter who she was working for, she just told people she was in a clerical position. And when promotion came three years later she was happy - but left out the bit about being a tax officer when people asked. "Working in the tax office" or "for the Inland Revenue" or, if she was feeling coy, saying she worked "in the Civil Service" always seemed to go down so much better. Of course, when she became a fully-fledged tax investigator she just gave up lying altogether.

"When you're introduced to people for the first time there's that step-back reaction," she says. "Not in an aggressive way, but people are definitely surprised. A female is not most people's image of what a tax investigator looks like. I mean, we've got Hector the Inspector on our ad campaign at the moment and I think that's what most people expect us to look like."

It's what comes after "that step-back reaction" that amuses Lashley. "It's actually quite like being a doctor because when I walk into the room, once people have absorbed what I do, they start to realise that I can be quite useful. Then come all the questions about their tax bill or about their friend's tax bill. I'm quite a handy person to know."

It's this "handy" notion of tax people that the Inland Revenue are desperate to promote. Saddled with a bad image, Claudine describes how they are at great pains to undergo a makeover. "We don't call them tax investigations any more," she tells me, "they are inquiries. And we don't assume that people's tax information is wrong, we're just checking it's correct." And what are the humble taxpayers now known as in the Inland Revenue office? "Customers," she says, with a slight snigger.

It's for that reason Lashley maintains she too loves her job. "A lot of people think that working for the Revenue means a lot of confrontation, but generally when people deal with the Revenue it's because they need help and that's what I'm doing - giving them help."

Olwyn Burgess, a principal consultant at TMP Worldwide, which specialises in career management and training, says a positive approach to these allegedly unpopular jobs is not uncommon. "It's very much a question of personal interest. I made a conscious decision about going into career management and outplacement, a lot of which involves advising people who have been made redundant. When I tell people this they always say 'God, how depressing', but actually it's a very rewarding job."

She argues that few people actually understand what is involved with other people's work and their motives for doing it. "We might label a traffic warden as a Little Hitler, but in actual fact they are doing something for the community and stopping people parking where, for safety and legal reasons, they shouldn't. Now, if you've got a strong sense of what is right and wrong it's the perfect job for you.

"I also had a friend who worked as an undertaker, which sounds awful but it suited him perfectly because he was a very serious person," she says. "So people stumble into professions that suit their personality and their preferences."

Burgess suggests that it also boils down to the old "Do you work to live or live to work?" adage. Which is an interesting question for Derrick Leeder, since he works with the dead.

As the manager of Anglia Funeral Service, Leeder is the firm's chief embalmer and also applies facial make-up to the corpses ("as required"). "It's not the American style of loads and loads of make-up," he assures me, "just a light dusting." And the embalming? "That involves an arterial injection of preservative fluids." At £45 a shot, Leeder's services are a veritable bargain.

He admits to "falling into the profession", having worked for a building company that owned a funeral director's as well. He's been in the business 30 years and swears that his personal life has not suffered as a result. "My wife has always been very supportive," he says. "When I took my embalming examination she was there helping me study and getting me through it." The make-up, he says, she left him to figure out for himself.

And while Burgess acknowledges that embalming is unlikely to be a career goal, she says we should take heed before disparaging the work of others. "If everyone wanted to do the same job, we'd all just be clones of each other. It would be a very boring world indeed if we all wanted to grow up and be embalmers, but somebody's got to do it," she says.

True. It's just not a very nice thing to have to say at a party.

webTitle: Hollywood sues website to stop copying of films

fields.headline: Hollywood sues website to stop copying of films
fields.trailText: Hollywood joined the music industry in the battle against digital downloads this week, with a legal battle against a website operator for alleged copyright infringemen
fields.body:
Hollywood joined the music industry in the battle against digital downloads this week, with a legal battle against a website operator for alleged copyright infringement.

The Motion Picture Association of America, an industry trade group, has filed a lawsuit against Eric Corley, the publisher of 2600, a quarterly hackers' magazine and website, in a move that is being eagerly watched by online businesses, lawyers and computer users in the US.

Mr Corley's website has distributed software that unscrambles the encryption on DVDs, thereby allowing computer users to download movies on to high-quality discs and send films across the internet. In addition, it provides links to other websites which contain the same information.

At issue in the case, which came to court on Monday, is a 1998 law on copyright in the US which has already pitched the music industry against listeners citing the First Amendment of the US constitution, which protects the right to free speech.

Leon Gold, a leading lawyer for the film studios, told the court: "The threat of world copying is here and the process has begun. It will become an avalanche unless this court acts."

Martin Garbus, the First Amendment lawyer who has represented the author Salman Rushdie, is acting for Mr Corley, who calls himself Emmanuel Goldstein, in a reference to George Orwell's novel 1984.

Mr Garbus argued in court that the technology at the heart of the case is covered by the "fair use" freedoms awarded by the First Amendment. Such arguments are also being put forward to defend online music downloads under the Digital Millennium Copyright Act.

The unscrambling software is thought to have been downloaded from a website owned by Microsoft, the world's biggest software group, by a Norwegian teenager.

It has been largely used to allow people who already own DVDs to watch their movies on computers using Linux, the freely available alternative to Microsoft Windows.

The eight major film studios originally filed a suit against three defendants in January. Following an earlier order by the judge presiding over the case, two of the defendants settled. At the time, Mr Corley agreed to take the DeCSS software which breaks the encryption code off his site, but then continued to provide more than 400 links to sites where the code could be found, citing journalistic freedom of speech.

Mr Corley is a self-confessed hacker and his website is devoted to fighting against what it calls "the failing of our modern technical era... and corporate abuse of power".

The film industry argues that the links on the website blatantly evade the spirit of the prior injunction. It also says that the Copyright Act's language, prohibiting the provision of or "trafficking" in a circumvention device, includes linking.

US district court judge Lewis Kaplan could rule on the case as early as next week.

Martin Garbus, the First Amendment lawyer who has represented the author Salman Rushdie, is acting for Mr Corley, who calls himself Emmanuel Goldstein, in a reference to George Orwell's novel 1984. Mr Garbus argued in court that the technology at the heart of the case is covered by the "fair use" freedoms awarded by the First Amendment. Such arguments are also being put forward to defend online music downloads under the Digital Millennium Copyright Act. The unscrambling software is thought to have been downloaded from a website owned by Microsoft, the world's biggest software group, by a Norwegian teenager. It has been largely used to allow people who already own DVDs to watch their movies on computers using Linux, the freely available alternative to Microsoft Windows. The eight major film studios originally filed a suit against three defendants in January. Following an earlier order by the judge presiding over the case, two of the defendants settled. At the time, Mr Corley agreed to take the DeCSS software which breaks the encryption code off his site, but then continued to provide more than 400 links to sites where the code could be found, citing journalistic freedom of speech. Mr Corley is a self-confessed hacker and his website is devoted to fighting against what it calls "the failing of our modern technical era... and corporate abuse of power". The film industry argues that the links on the website blatantly evade the spirit of the prior injunction. It also says that the Copyright Act's language, prohibiting the provision of or "trafficking" in a circumvention device, includes linking. US district court judge Lewis Kaplan could rule on the case as early as next week.

fields.headline: Work stress boosts body's immunity
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Today's workplace stresses - too many emails, a creaking intray, a demanding boss - may at least help to prevent minor illnesses, researchers have found.
fields.body:
Today's workplace stresses - too many emails, a creaking intray, a demanding boss - may at least help to prevent minor illnesses, researchers have found.

The study at Plymouth University found that when students were placed under stress their body's immunity was given a temporary boost.

Samples of saliva were taken from them before and after they were set demanding computer based tasks. Levels of immunoglobulin - naturally occurring proteins which act as anti-bodies to a range of minor infections - were found to rise at times of stress.

Mark Wetherell, a PhD student who carried out the research, said: "The results suggest that the stress caused by the computer tasks stimulated an increase in immunity, [which] is important to ensure that the body is still able to fight off infections during times of stress."

Mr Wetherell, who plans to look in more detail at the link between stress and illness, presents his findings today to the psychology postgraduate affairs group conference in Glasgow.

Yesterday Kate Holden told the conference of the danger to vulnerable people from psychics.

Her research showed that those with low self-esteem were more likely to visit psychics.

She said one person she had questioned -who believed absolutely in the claims of psychics - had developed marital problems after being told she should divorce her husband.

Among other papers given was one disclosing that people who claimed to be more intuitive were better at guessing who contestants would pick on Blind Date.

Another noted that people with big hands felt less pain when they touched hot things, while a third concluded that bullies lacked empathy.

webTitle: Pop review: Latin love in a chilly field

fields.headline: Latin love in a chilly field
fields.standfirst: Salsa 2000 Three Mills Island, London ****
fields.trailText: Salsa 2000 Three Mills Island, London ****
fields.body:
Three Mills Island, in a bleak no-man's land near the Blackwall tunnel, is a strange place to find a remarkable array of veteran salsa superstars: Venezuelan Oscar D'Leon, Panamanian Ruben Blades, and Celia Cruz, who left Cuba after Castro's revolution to enjoy even more celebrity in the US.

For a performer who has been working for half a century, the "Queen of Salsa" still looked formidable. Her voice may not be what it was but she puts on a theatrical performance, belting out dance songs then switching to a rousing tribute to her friend Tito Puente, the percussionist and bandleader who died in May. She was helped by an energetic band and backing singers who included Jose "The Canary" Alberto, a man of remarkable stamina (he had just finished a lengthy set of his own, using the same band). Someone should have told them that it's no longer obligatory to sing Guantanamera.

There were more displays of macho salsa stamina from Oscar D'Leon, who came on looking like a jovial gangster on a weekend off. As ever, he provided a rousing dance set, helped by the Cuban emigre Alfredo De La Fe, who cut across the salsa rhythms with improvised solos on a green electric violin.

The main attraction was Ruben Blades. Unlike the others (who have all appeared at the Barbican over the past 18 months), he hasn't been seen here since the 80s. He's an unlikely salsa star, a law graduate actively involved in politics (he even stood for president back in Panama) who is also a successful actor.

His music was equally unexpected, both in terms of the lyrics, which dealt with social problems or everyday life, and the mix of salsa with other styles. There were hints of jazz, funk and reggae in his gentle, subtle songs, and a burst of Mack the Knife (in English) that switched to his own song of barrio gangsters, Pedro Navaja. It was an intriguing set, and would have sounded even better if not performed in a chilly field after a five-hour dance music session.

fields.headline: CSFB plans e-bank for rich
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Crédit Suisse First Boston, the Swiss-American investment bank, is planning to launch a new online private banking service targeted at the rapidly-expanding numbers of high earners in the US.
fields.body:
Crédit Suisse First Boston, the Swiss-American investment bank, is planning to launch a new online private banking service targeted at the rapidly-expanding numbers of high earners in the US.

The new service, known in the bank as "privateadvisor.com", is expected to compete with a $1bn venture between Merrill Lynch and HSBC, which also hopes to attract cash from the newly affluent.

The Merrill/HSBC company, based in London, will target those with "investable assets" of £60,000-£300,000 who are keen to make their own investment decisions.

CSFB's privateadvisor.com is expected to go after the same market and will be headed by Kevin English - the former chief executive of news website Thestreet.com.

Mr English joined CSFB's e-commerce department earlier this year and is expected to hire significant numbers of people - one insider said "several hundred people" were required - for the new service. Mr English was unavailable for comment.

A spokesman for the group also refused to comment on its online ambitions yesterday, saying it would be "premature to discuss" the new service.

Insiders say that privateadvisor.com will initially start in the US before it is launched in other parts of the world, such as Europe. It is expected to be branded as a CSFB product.

The bank's top management is expected to move swiftly into cyberspace - which sources say has been triggered by the rising number of users of its websites.

By the end of February, the number of CSFB's online banking customers had reached 200,000.

CSFB executives are keen to combine the web's low cost with the high margins generated by well-heeled investors.

Most traditional private banking services target the extremely wealthy - defined as individuals with investable assets of more than $1m - and offer bespoke investment plans.

In recent years, the growing ranks of individuals with at least $100,000 to play the markets with, has attracted the big banks.

These customers, say the banks, neither need nor want the sort of personal attention provided by a traditional private bank.

Studies by Gemini Consulting and Merrill Lynch suggest that private banking assets could rise above $38,000bn by 2005 largely because of the increasing wealth of this band of people.

Michael Maslinski, director of a management consultancy which specialises in private banking, has estimated that the richest 5% of people in the US, which includes those targeted by CSFB and its rivals, provide about half of the profits earned in the retail financial services sector.

"Private banking is not a niche any more - it's big business." he says.

The private banking operation of Crédit Suisse, which has SFr600bn (£243bn)in assets under management, also plans to launch a European e-commerce operation in the third quarter.

The new "ebank" is part of CSFB's global strategy. Experts say that across Europe, the Far East, Japan and Latin America, the number of households on the net that are also active investors is expected to grow more than fourfold in the next decade to 50m.

In Europe alone, the number of online banking and investment accounts is predicted to exceed 14m by 2004.

webTitle: Theatre review: Hit and miss absurdity

fields.headline: Hit and miss absurdity
fields.standfirst: The Exhibitionists Drum, Plymouth ***
fields.trailText: The Exhibitionists Drum, Plymouth ***
fields.body:
You could take Ridiculusmus' show, set in the kind of modern art gallery where piles of old shoes constitute the exhibits, as a comment upon Damien Hirst culture. Or you could just take it as a piece of old cobblers. This is a company capable of elevating nonsense into an artform, and they do it with a highly developed sense of fun, even if this hour-long show is hit and miss.

It is best when the surreal springs from reality, as three security attendants charged with guarding a pretentious gallery endure a day of boredom and find their attempts to enliven the situation topped by external events. Life is more absurd than we ever imagine or admit.

In this sense, Ridiculusmus is a direct descendent of Samuel Beckett. There is both a precision and poignancy about some of the images here: two men ballroom dancing in an empty gallery, the ridiculous amount of energy expended in doing nothing at all. The sense of time moving slowly while life passes these sad specimens by.

The piece would be better if it didn't try so hard to achieve such a high standard of lunacy. It also really demands to be seen in gallery rather than theatre spaces. But it is an amiable, cultish hour of entertainment that suggests that this wildly talented company has a bolder, darker and far funnier future ahead of it.

 Until July 22. Box office: 01752 267222

fields.headline: Manon
fields.standfirst:
Manon
Royal Opera House, London
****
fields.trailText:
Manon
Royal Opera House, London
****
fields.body:
Four months ago Sylvie Guillem took the leading role in Frederick Ashton's Marguerite and Armand, a role which no dancer had performed since it was created for Margot Fonteyn. Everyone speculated (rightly) that Guillem would be a natural Marguerite, given the similarities between that character and the heroine of Kenneth MacMillan's Manon, a role she has danced for years. But just as interesting is the degree to which Guillem's mesmerising interpretation of Marguerite has enriched her current portrayal of Manon - certainly as seen on Monday night.

Much remains familiar in her performance - the erotic virtuosity of her love duets with Des Grieux, in which her body refines itself into a pure energy of desire; the brittle chic she assumes when she becomes the trophy mistress of the wealthy Monsieur GM. Yet there's a new subtlety and nakedness in her performance which add layers to her characterisation of the MacMillan ballet.

When Guillem makes her first entrance as Manon, a girl newly exposed to fashionable Paris, she seems years younger than she used to. Rather than sizing up the glamour of this world, and calculating its rules, she seems set apart by her naive enthusiasm. Her gaze is wide-eyed, and that open-heartedness continues into the first giddy passion of her affair with Des Grieux (Jonathan Cope). There's a bright breathlessness and new spontaneity in their opening encounter and in the bedroom scene. Though Guillem and Cope have danced this ballet together dozens of times their characters look as if they've only just met, so intently and joyously do they goad each other to find new details within the choreography.

In the pas de trois with GM and her brother Lescaut, the fluctuating tensions in Guillem's body are a vivid graph of the struggle between her revulsion at GM's advances and her dawning appreciation of her own power. Her final capitulation has the stab of a small tragedy, and once she has become GM's mistress the drugged glitter of her dancing bears witness to the degradations she has accommodated.

Cope is a wonderful foil to Guillem, pushing his technique to the limits in response to her power and hunger. Irek Mukhamedov also makes a magnificently brutish Lescaut - the sheer physical weight of him, the slurry extravagance of his personality create a figure of fate both trashy and sinister. Given that Mukhamedov is 40, Cope 37 and Guillem is 35, the performance couldn't make a better case for the supremacy of the older dancer.

In rep till July 25. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

fields.headline: Investors wait on Greenspan
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Neil Hume: It did not require the services of a highly paid City analyst to explain the behaviour of the London market yesterday. The key was events in the US, in particular June's consumer price data.
fields.body:
It did not require the services of a highly paid City analyst to explain the behaviour of the London market yesterday. The key was events in the US, in particular June's consumer price data.

After trading in a narrow range ahead of the data, the FTSE 100's fate was sealed once the core CPI figure came in slightly above expectations and triggered a bad reaction on Wall Street.

But it was just before the close that the selling intensified, leaving the FTSE 75 points adrift at 6,450.5. At the close of play in London, the Dow was about 94 points lower and the Nasdaq 106 points weaker.

With most investors prepared to sit on the sidelines ahead of Alan Greenspan's testimony to the US senate this week, there was time to consider more esoteric issues.

One such case was Geo Interactive Media , the audio and video-streaming specialist, which has one of the largest private client shareholder bases of any company listed on the London stock exchange.

For brokers who follow the stock this fact causes no end of problems - usually in the shape of outlandish rumours. Recent tales to grace the online bulletin boards include talk of a Nasdaq listing and that Symbian will take a stake. It was therefore surprising to see the stock tumble 57.5p to £11.25 yesterday, especially as Geo is on a marathon tour of its institutional investors.

The roadshow, organised by house broker Lehman Brothers, is expected to take in three continents and will see Geo's management update institutions on recent deals, acquisitions and developments in the audio/video streaming world. No doubt Geo will also be explaining how it has a 12-18 month lead over its potential competitors.

Another measure of boredom was the attention brokers paid to Ofex newcomer Biogeny - a venture capital company that invests in early stage biotech developments with universities and other research institutes. Placed at 30p, the shares finished the day at 65.5p, with dealers intrigued by its involvement in a project that has demonstrated (in lab conditions) a potential means of eradicating malaria.

Elsewhere tech stocks were hit by a bout of profit taking ( Freeserve down 17p at 364p the worst affected) and the mortgage banks were under attack again with UBS Warburg the latest broker to deliver a gloomy forecast. War burg reckons 2000 will be the year when falling earnings start to become a reality for Britain's home loan lenders.

To prove it meant business, UBS placed "sell" recommendations on Halifax (down 12.5p to 548.5p) and Woolwich (off 4.75p at 263p) and slashed 2000 earnings forecast by 9.8% and 10.3% respectively. And just for good measure, it moved Abbey National from "buy" to "hold" and cut its earnings forecast by 3.6%. Abbey shares fell 21p to 754p.

With the banks' interim reporting season starting this week (figures from Northern Rock are due on Thursday) investors will have a chance to see evidence to put this theory to the test.

Among second tier stocks, Williams crashed 54p to 342p, as investors took fright at the costs of demerging its Chubb and Kidde divisions.

Enodis (Berisford in a former life) fell 25.5p to 260.5p as Schroder Salomon Smith Barney cut its rating to "hold".

Lower down the market, professional punters were betting that ITE Group , the trade exhibitions specialist, could provide further upside. Its shares rose 10p to 80p as it confirmed a story published here that it has received a takeover approach. While the company claims "the level of the offer under discussion is under 100p", those in the know reckon it is only just below that level, around 95p per share.

Automotive services group Inchcape could see strong gains today. It is understood that Guinness Peat will reveal it has amassed a 10% stake. Inchcape shares went 1.5p higher yesterday at 262.5p.

webTitle: First Direct rates match net's best

fields.headline: First Direct rates match net's best
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Telephone bank First Direct yesterday sought to exploit consumer dissatisfaction with standalone internet banks by saying it would be the first to offer interest rates similar to those offered by other online operations combined with an "award-winning person to person telephone service".
fields.body:
Telephone bank First Direct yesterday sought to exploit consumer dissatisfaction with standalone internet banks by saying it would be the first to offer interest rates similar to those offered by other online operations combined with an "award-winning person to person telephone service".

The bank, part of HSBC group, announced a range of products including a current account paying up to 5% on credit balances and a savings account paying up to 6%.

The 5% current account rate is higher than that paid by rivals such as Smile and First-e, but is only available to those with more than £5,000 in their account. Customers with less than £1,000 will earn 1%.

Rates for savers are also tiered, starting at 5% for those with £1 in their account and rising to 6% on more than £100,000. Also on offer is a credit card and personal loans.

First Direct announced plans to transform itself into an "e-bank" almost five months ago. The bank expects to double its 1m customer base within three years.

In a swipe at standalone rivals such as Egg, First Direct's chief executive, Alan Hughes, said it wanted customers to benefit from attractive rates, "but not at the expense of the service they receive".

"Some of our competitors support interest rates by penalising customers for calling them, while others are shut when you need them or automate their response to customers. We will not compromise our service for unsustainable headline-grabbing rates."

Mr Hughes said he expected most customers to use firstdirect.com. But those who do not use the net will not benefit from the new pricing - the existing lower rates will continue to apply to them. Banking via Wap phones will be introduced next month and TV banking is to go live in the autumn.

The bank, part of HSBC group, announced a range of products including a current account paying up to 5% on credit balances and a savings account paying up to 6%. The 5% current account rate is higher than that paid by rivals such as Smile and First-e, but is only available to those with more than £5,000 in their account. Customers with less than £1,000 will earn 1%. Rates for savers are also tiered, starting at 5% for those with £1 in their account and rising to 6% on more than £100,000. Also on offer is a credit card and personal loans. First Direct announced plans to transform itself into an "e-bank" almost five months ago. The bank expects to double its 1m customer base within three years. In a swipe at standalone rivals such as Egg, First Direct's chief executive, Alan Hughes, said it wanted customers to benefit from attractive rates, "but not at the expense of the service they receive". "Some of our competitors support interest rates by penalising customers for calling them, while others are shut when you need them or automate their response to customers. We will not compromise our service for unsustainable headline-grabbing rates." Mr Hughes said he expected most customers to use firstdirect.com. fields.headline: Follow thy leader
fields.standfirst:
The way we work: Richard Reeves

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The way we work: Richard Reeves
fields.body:
Bertrand Russell was once asked to define work. "Work is of two kinds," he said. "First, altering the position of matter at or near the earth's surface relative to other matter; second, telling other people to do so."

The distinction between doers and tellers, workers and management, "them" and "us", has characterised work for the best part of the past two centuries. Now, though, more is expected of all of us. Front-line staff are expected to act on their own initiative, and - at least to some extent - manage themselves. And those at the top can no longer simply manage. They have to lead.

Business has realised that, while management was fine for industrial structures, the fluid patterns of modern firms mean that new tools are required. Management is a science; leadership is an art, argue Liz Cook and Brian Rothwell in their book The X and Y of Leadership. Warren Bennis, a business analyst, says: "Management is about doing things right; leadership is about doing the right things."

The complexity of 21st century business - especially the depth and pace of globalisation - has made leadership more important. A stable, predictable world can be run by managers. A shifting, uncertain one needs leaders. And the diminishing power of nation states and politicians means that people leading major companies have responsibilities beyond their own corporate spaces.

But the idea of business leadership is in danger of becoming extinct, like motherhood and apple pie, along with empowerment and people-as-our-greatest-asset. It is difficult to oppose leadership. But what does it really mean to be a leader?

A Zulu chief once marched a division of his men over a cliff, in front of a rival, merely to prove their discipline. Great leadership? No - great dictatorship, but the two often get confused. The idea of a leader as someone with a blind, devoted following is deep in our psyche but real leaders are not megalomaniacs or control freaks.

In a brilliant essay, A Kantian Theory of Leadership, Norm Bowie from the University of Minnesota applies a Kantian philosophical framework to the modern debate on leadership. He argues that leaders should prepare decisions but not impose them: "The leader enhances the autonomy of his or her followers."

Jan Carlzon, former head of SAS airlines, is a hero of the corporate world because of the way he used enlightened corporate philosophy to turn the company around. But he realised he was failing as a leader - at least in the Kantian sense - when his vacations were punctuated by phone calls from his office asking for decisions. By pushing leadership skills down the organisation, a true leader holidays in peace.

Leadership is clearly vital, but can it be taught? There is a strong argument that leaders are born, not made - any more than years of painting lessons can create a Picasso. Character cannot be changed in a three-day course.

But there are others who believe leadership can be taught. Robert Lee, president of the Centre for Creative Leadership - a leading US institution in the field - says: "Leadership is something we believe resides in almost everybody as a potential, and by better understanding yourself you can improve your way of leading."

The truth is that high-quality learning opportunities can strengthen leadership skills, even if they can't turn every manager into a leader. We can't all be a Winston Churchill, but maybe we can probably all get a bit closer.

But the best sort of leadership is by example. This is a lesson we should have learned by now. As the author of Beowulf, the epic Anglo-Saxon tale, put it more than 1,000 years ago: "Behaviour that's admired is the path to power among people everywhere."

Love you and leave you

There are now legally permitted breaks for maternity, paternity, sickness, moving house, jury duty, children's illness, Christian religious festivals and bank holidays - just about all of life's big moments, in fact, except one: falling in love.

This is short-sighted. Percy Sledge knew that a man in love can't keep his mind on nothing else - and we all know it, too. When we are hopelessly in love we are hopeless at work.

Far better to recognise this than fight it. Staff in love are unproductive, and quite possibly distracting to co-workers. The government needs a vote-winner: how about some Love Leave?

Richard Reeves is director of futures at the Industrial Society. You can contact him at rreeves@indsoc.co.uk. For workplace distractions, visit www.workunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Figo in Real sights after Perez win

fields.headline: Figo in Real sights after Perez win
fields.standfirst: Madrid gets ready for Real decision
fields.trailText: Florentino Perez beat Lorenzo Sanz in the Real Madrid presidential ballot yesterday when he secured 55% of the votes, many of them on the back of a pledge to sign Barcelona's £32m-rated Luis Figo.
fields.body:
Florentino Perez beat Lorenzo Sanz in the Real Madrid presidential ballot yesterday when he secured 55% of the votes, many of them on the back of a pledge to sign Barcelona's £32m-rated Luis Figo.

Perez, moreover, had promised to refund the cost of more than 75,000 season tickets, which would cost in excess of £5.5m, if he fails to sign the Portugal forward. "Since the news broke he [Figo] has been under such pressure that I'm going to have to start work immediately," said Perez, who had also criticised Sanz's decison to offload Nicolas Anelka.

Rangers have made a £6.5m bid for Schalke 04's Emile Mpenza, a move which would break Scotland's transfer record. The 22-year-old Belgian is keen to leave after eight months with Schalke, who paid £5.5m for him but want £8m.

Aston Villa have given Benito Carbone a deadline to decide his future. "He has got until the weekend before I go to plan B. He can't keep us hanging around," said John Gregory, Villa's manager.

webTitle: Hussain returns to the quiet life

fields.headline: Hussain returns to the quiet life
fields.trailText: When Nasser Hussain returns to England captaincy duties today, he should give a nod of recognition to the man who has ensured that in his absence things have remained in remarkably good shape. Alec Stewart has stood in for only three weeks but there has been enough incident for three years as the England see-saw has almost been torn from its pivot.
fields.body:
When Nasser Hussain returns to England captaincy duties today, he should give a nod of recognition to the man who has ensured that in his absence things have remained in remarkably good shape. Alec Stewart has stood in for only three weeks but there has been enough incident for three years as the England see-saw has almost been torn from its pivot.

That Stewart has managed to leave that see-saw pointing slightly upwards is a considerable achievement. England's remarkable victory at Lord's has left them slight favourites to win a Test series against West Indies that stands at 1-1 with three to play, and West Indies' capitulation in the NatWest triangular series has also ensured that today's adversaries, England and Zimbabwe, have already qualified for Saturday's final.

Hussain's broken finger, suffered at Trent Bridge while playing for Essex, has also led directly to Marcus Trescothick's emergence as an international batsman. A major dilemma - who should open the innings with Michael Atherton in the third Test at Old Trafford - has been solved in the captain's absence.

Hussain's return tonight will not be proclaimed with a suitably belligerent musical blast over the PA system. The Edgbaston ground has been served with a noise-abatement order by the environment department after a residents' group complained about the noise at Warwickshire's floodlit National League matches.

Residents who buy houses next to sports grounds and complain about the noise fit into the same category as city dwellers who move into the country and try to stop the cows mooing. If there is a frenzied finish tonight, will the more excitable spectators please refrain from cheering because the highlights of the Queen Mother's birthday pageant will have just started on ITV.

For cricket's authorities, responding to public wishes by an enlightened attempt to introduce a brasher form of one-day floodlit cricket, the frustration runs deep. Darren Gough complained loudly enough to have his voice box surgically removed by the residents. "It can only happen in England," he said. "You have a country like England where people are mad about sport and yet people don't want to get into the spirit of it."

England's last two group matches - against Zimbabwe here today and West Indies at Trent Bridge on Thursday - might be largely irrelevant, but for Hussain they offer an essential route back to form. He has had a frustrating season, managing only 64 first-class runs for Essex in five starts.

Before his successful net session yesterday, his only clue that he might have regained fitness came in a gentle round of golf on Sunday. He is likely to replace Matthew Maynard, with the trickiest decision concerning whether Andrew Flintoff should remain at No3. Hussain can at least be grateful that he was spared judgment upon Flintoff's weight problem, leaving the Stewart media robot to blame it all on the press.

There has been a lot of tosh spoken and written about Flintoff. The appealing qualities of any out-of-the-ordinary sportsman should be forever recognised. But no one is suggesting that Flintoff adopts the Kate Moss diet, simply contending that the difference between 17 and 18 stone might be the difference between cheering an ebullient Falstaffian hundred against next summer's Australians or bemoaning the failure of a characterful cricketer to make the grade. It is obvious which will provoke the most noise.

webTitle: Uproar as Croydon women defect to Charlton

fields.headline: Uproar as Croydon women defect to Charlton
fields.trailText: They are the league champions, cup holders and one of the most powerful forces in women's football, having won a string of honours over the past few seasons. But when officials from Croydon Women's Football Club met with their team for the annual general meeting it was extinction and not success that dominated the agenda.
fields.body:
They are the league champions, cup holders and one of the most powerful forces in women's football, having won a string of honours over the past few seasons. But when officials from Croydon Women's Football Club met with their team for the annual general meeting it was extinction and not success that dominated the agenda.

In an astonishing move, members of Britain's most successful women's team voted in favour of their own takeover, shocking the chairman and committee members.

The Croydon players decided to move en masse across south London and will now be known as Charlton Athletic Women's Football Club after electing to be taken over by the Premier League club.

Despite opposition from the club chairman Ken Jarvie and others, they made their historic decision at a fiery meeting, claiming that the move would be better for their development as footballers.

From now on the team will play as Charlton Athletic, in a move backed by the Football Association.

Croydon have become one of Britain's better known women's teams and their press officer Donald Madgwick said yesterday that few had expected the club to vote itself into extinction.

"It was discussed right at the end of the meeting, under the section headlined any other business," he said. "This can't be fair. We have worked for many years to make Croydon women's team a success and now Charlton are going to walk straight into the national Premier League and take our place.

"I've no objection to players wanting to leave the club, but to take the whole team with you and wreck the whole club is an entirely different matter.

"I've always thought that the players were a wonderful bunch who were loyal to the team. I've obviously been living in a fools' paradise. It's a bit like Manchester United players attending their club's agm and voting in favour of leaving to become Liverpool."

Only days before the agm the players had been honoured at a civic reception in the town to mark their winning the league and cup double, which they have achieved twice within the past six years.

The midfielder Gemma Hunt, who voted in favour of the takeover, said: "Some of the older players were very sad but it's in the best interests of us all. We will have access to better facilities, will not have to pay to play and will receive more financial backing.

"We will have exactly the same team, same manager and same players. The only difference will be that we will be known as Charlton rather than Croydon and will play in different shirts at a new ground."

The FA said it had looked closely at the Croydon players' decision. "The matter has been handled properly," a spokeswoman said. "We checked to make sure that the club had gone through the proper procedures and there are no problems. Any team can vote to change its name and in favour of a takeover if it goes through the proper procedures."

webTitle: Bubbly Gazza checks in at Everton with a promise to think with his feet

fields.headline: Bubbly Gazza checks in at Everton with a promise to think with his feet
fields.trailText: With the cheerful demeanour of a man granted an unlikely reprieve, Paul Gascoigne yesterday played out the opening scene of what may be the final act of his pantomime career.
fields.body:
With the cheerful demeanour of a man granted an unlikely reprieve, Paul Gascoigne yesterday played out the opening scene of what may be the final act of his pantomime career.

The perennial bad boy of English football discovered that, in his case, and at the age of 33, the last-chance saloon is housed at Everton. Gascoigne, having been granted a free transfer by Middlesbrough, signed a two-year, £20,000-a-week deal at lunchtime before heading for a club training camp in Tuscany.

"This is a gamble for this football club and what I must now do is repay the faith and trust they have shown in me," said Gascoigne. "I know they are taking a chance, what with the off-field stuff which happened in the past. I have to keep my nose clean and deliver. I accept that this represents my last big chance in top-flight football. This really is a massive club and I'll do my best for them; the passion does still burn inside of me."

Last week, having declined invitations to join Kilmarnock and Motherwell, the former England midfielder was exploring the possibilities of ending his career in the United States or Australia until highly improbable salvation arrived in the form of the ultimate in old pals' acts.

Everton's manager Walter Smith, formerly his manager at Rangers, has something akin to a paternal interest in Gascoigne and yesterday the player's agent too described that relationship as more "father-son" than merely manager-player.

But, with Gascoigne now playing his football in a city renowned for its nightlife, joie de vivre and collective dislike of those with elevated profiles and bulging egos, Smith has placed a deserved reputation for common sense squarely on the line. "It's the biggest gamble of my career," he admitted yesterday.

Smith, moreover, will not hesitate to consign Gascoigne to the scrap heap should he show any signs of again becoming the disruptive and unsettling force which had so lessened his effectiveness at Newcastle, Tottenham, Lazio, Rangers and Middlesbrough.

"I really don't know what's happened to Paul over the past couple of years," said Smith. "I really thought that when he left Rangers for Middlesbrough he would make an impact. It didn't happen and that makes me sad. He is a tremendous kid who unfortunately has a penchant for attracting bad publicity; he's not a bad person - he just lets himself down now and again."

Everton's vice-chairman Bill Kenwright was in ebullient mood after making Gascoigne the club's fourth major signing of a busy close season. "I'm thrilled, delighted and excited," he said.

Gascoigne, despite his fondness for Middlesbrough's manager Bryan Robson, amounted to an expensive mistake at the Riverside. After costing the club £3.45m in March 1998 he managed only 44 senior appearances, and Robson recently informed him that he could leave on a free transfer despite having 12 months left on his contract.

"Things just didn't go well for me up at Middlesbrough, what with all the injuries and such," said Gascoigne.

Typically he saved the best until last, adding: "My brains are in my feet."

fields.headline: Sleaze allegations warning to MPs
fields.trailText: MPs were warned yesterday not to use the Commons standards watchdog to make "tit for tat"            sleaze allegations against each other in the run-up to the general election.
fields.body:
MPs were warned yesterday not to use the Commons standards watchdog to make "tit for tat" sleaze allegations against each other in the run-up to the general election.

Robert Sheldon, chairman of the Commons standards and privileges committee , said that the committee would regard it as "a very serious matter" if MPs were to put in trivial allegations of rule-breaking in order to score party political points to further their party's election campaign.

He was giving evidence to Lord Neill's committee on standards in public life on the final day of its hearings into whether the House of Lords should have a compulsory register of interests and a code of conduct. Peers who oppose a register claim that it could lead to political point-scoring in the Lords.

Mr Sheldon said: "The tit for tat situation concerns me greatly, where people outside the Commons are willing to trip up others.

webTitle: Salmond stuns SNP with decision to quit

fields.headline: Salmond stuns SNP with decision to quit
fields.standfirst: Succession race breaks out after party leader springs news of his departure
fields.trailText: July 18 2000 Succession race breaks out after party leader springs news of his departure
fields.body:
The leader of the Scottish National party, Alex Salmond, announced his surprise resignation yesterday, launching a contest for the leadership and, possibly, for the movement's soul.

Mr Salmond's declaration that after 10 years he will be standing down at the party conference in September stunned opponents, political pundits and many in his party. The SNP is enjoying a boom time, leading the opinion polls for Scotland's institutions and standing at more than 30% in polls asking Scots how they would vote in the next Westminster elections.

At a snap news conference in Aberdeen, Mr Salmond, 45, said he was convinced the SNP would win the Scottish election three years hence. "However, translating that political success on to a personal level, that would effectively lock me in to a further decade as party leader," he said. "I have decided instead to pass on the torch.

"It has been a rare privilege to lead the SNP over the last decade. In addition, I have enjoyed myself enormously. I have no complaints and no regrets."

Mr Salmond said he would continue as a member of the Scottish parliament for his Banff and Buchan constituency and hoped "to serve Scotland in the future in some other capacity".

As colleagues lined up to pay tribute yesterday, speculation had already begun about who the party conference would pick as new leader.

Analysts say the two front-runners are the party's deputy leader, John Swinney, who is close to Mr Salmond personally and politically, and Alex Neil, a leftwinger who has already thrown his hat into the ring.

Other possibles include the party's acting treasurer, Kenny Macaskill, its justice spokes woman, Roseanna Cunningham, and its business manager, Mike Russell, who was born in Kent.

The succession struggle is going to heighten tensions between the party's fundamentalist and gradualist factions. As a gradualist, Mr Salmond has been accused of betraying the party's core ideals by appearing to distance the SNP from outright independence.

One political analyst, John Curtice of Strathclyde University, said Mr Salmond's resignation would put the whole direction of the SNP up for renewed debate, but an equally pressing issue would be whether there was anyone of sufficient calibre to replace him.

"Alex Salmond is head and shoulders above his colleagues and most Scottish politicians in his ability to deal with the media and the party is going to struggle to fill that hole. No one is in Alex's class when it comes to media presentation."

When Mr Salmond became leader, Professor Curtice said, "the SNP was still a fringe party. He has left it as a serious parliamentary force for the first time in its history. Under Alex Salmond it has become the principal opposition party in Scotland. It is a very substantial legacy. He has made the SNP a force in politics."

In the first year of the new Scottish parliament the SNP has flourished in the polls, currently sitting three points ahead of Labour in Scotland on 36%. But there has been dissent in the party at Mr Salmond's leadership style and his often lacklustre performance at question time.

There has also been a series of internal crises, including the suspension of the party treasurer, Ian Blackford, who threatened to sue Mr Salmond.

Alex Salmond joined the SNP in 1973 and took over as leader in 1990. An economist, he previously worked with the old Scottish Office and the Royal Bank of Scotland.

Last night he insisted his departure was purely based on a desire to hand on the reins when the party was doing well.

But one nationalist MSP said: "I am not surprised he is stepping down - he has stepped back a lot since the election, and it appears to me that there was a deliberate move to promote others, to demolish the idea that we are a one-man band."

Christine Grahame added: "I don't think he has the same appetite for the job. Everyone detected that. I have done a job myself for 12 years and you get a bit battle-weary."

webTitle: The woman behind England's new hope

fields.headline: The woman behind England's new hope
fields.trailText: The world of Hayley Rowse, 23, has been turned upside down in the last 11 days. Her boyfriend, Marcus Trescothick, has suddenly become the talk of the town - the new saviour of English cricket. His weakness outside off stump, his penchant for sausages and his powerful hitting have become topics for national discussion. But Hayley seems nearly as relaxed about it as her nonchalant boyfriend.
fields.body:
The world of Hayley Rowse, 23, has been turned upside down in the last 11 days. Her boyfriend, Marcus Trescothick, has suddenly become the talk of the town - the new saviour of English cricket. His weakness outside off stump, his penchant for sausages and his powerful hitting have become topics for national discussion. But Hayley seems nearly as relaxed about it as her nonchalant boyfriend.

"Not much has changed for me, though I haven't seen Marcus since last Tuesday and it has been completely manic for him - lots of press and TV. I've spoken to him every day and he's taking it very well. He's the sort of guy who doesn't let things get to him. He's pretty relaxed which annoys me sometimes! It's always been his ambition to play Test cricket and he was so pleased to be picked for the one-day squad. I'm just glad he wasn't driving anywhere when he found out he'd been selected - he was so excited."

They met at a nightclub on Hayley's 19th birthday, four years ago last Tuesday. "I didn't recognise him but we just got chatting. I followed Somerset so when he said his name I said: 'Oh you're that cricketer who did well in such and such a year.' He is quite a shy type of guy and was a bit embarrassed, but we just laugh about it now."

In January they moved into a place in Taunton, where Marcus shows surprising skill in the kitchen for someone nicknamed Banger. "He is a great cook, and does most of our cooking. He will always do it if we have friends round to dinner - he knocks up a very good stir-fry. He does eat sausages but very, very rarely. He tends to eat healthily and hardly ever has fatty foods (though I'm just the opposite and love a McDonalds). I very rarely see him with a chocolate bar in his hand."

Hayley has been with him through leaner years than this one, when Trescothick, Mark Lathwell and underachievement were constantly mentioned in the same breath. Did he ever lose confidence? "No, he's still fairly young and he has always been positive. He spent two winters away in Australia working on his fitness and his game, and he has always had a positive attitude."

What they don't do is sit around discussing whether Andy Caddick bowls too short. "We try not to talk about cricket too much because it is his work - I don't like talking about my job either [she is a secretary for a building company in Taunton]."

What does she feel like while watching him bat? "I just sit there in complete agony and feel physically sick, though I'm not quite so bad now. But I was very, very nervous when he walked out in his first game for England. I cried, in fact. He couldn't see us in the crowd which was probably a good thing."

Going out with a county cricketer can seem like a bit of a thankless task. They work long hours, are away every other week during the nicest part of the year, and are then all over you like a rash in the winter. Hayley admits that it is hard but says, "you do get used to it and it helps that all the [Somerset] wives and girlfriends are really good friends. When the players go away we all get together and take it in turns going round each other's houses, and we also have girlie nights out. And if we do decide to go and watch an away game, we all go together."

They don't just play together in the evenings, they make up a pretty good cricket side. "Andy Caddick's wife played a few games till she had a baby, and so did Bethan Shine [Kevin Shine's wife]. Then there is Lucy Turner [Rob Turner's wife] and Jamie Cox's girlfriend, Helen, and me. Although my brother and father played, and I spent my childhood chucking balls at my brother in the back garden, I only really got interested in playing properly when I met Marcus and the other girlfriends. I gave up playing for Somerset this year but I am still an allrounder for Taunton ladies."

Though handy in the kitchen Marcus isn't a completely new man. "When I first started playing he used to take the mick out of me - although now he's very supportive. In my first year he took me up to the nets at Taunton to show me how to bat properly but of course I was having none of it."

Quite right. Women always know best.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read last week's column, on how the ECB can learn from the success of the Williams sisters at Wimbledon, click here.

He is quite a shy type of guy and was a bit embarrassed, but we just laugh about it now." In January they moved into a place in Taunton, where Marcus shows surprising skill in the kitchen for someone nicknamed Banger. "He is a great cook, and does most of our cooking. He will always do it if we have friends round to dinner - he knocks up a very good stir-fry. He does eat sausages but very, very rarely. He tends to eat healthily and hardly ever has fatty foods (though I'm just the opposite and love a McDonalds). I very rarely see him with a chocolate bar in his hand." Hayley has been with him through leaner years than this one, when Trescothick, Mark Lathwell and underachievement were constantly mentioned in the same breath. Did he ever lose confidence? "No, he's still fairly young and he has always been positive. He spent two winters away in Australia working on his fitness and his game, and he has always had a positive attitude." What they don't do is sit around discussing whether Andy Caddick bowls too short. "We try not to talk about cricket too much because it is his work - I don't like talking about my job either [she is a secretary for a building company in Taunton]." What does she feel like while watching him bat? "I just sit there in complete agony and feel physically sick, though I'm not quite so bad now. But I was very, very nervous when he walked out in his first game for England. I cried, in fact. He couldn't see us in the crowd which was probably a good thing." Going out with a county cricketer can seem like a bit of a thankless task. They work long hours, are away every other week during the nicest part of the year, and are then all over you like a rash in the winter. Hayley admits that it is hard but says, "you do get used to it and it helps that all the [Somerset] wives and girlfriends are really good friends. When the players go away we all get together and take it in turns going round each other's houses, and we also have girlie nights out. And if we do decide to go and watch an away game, we all go together." They don't just play together in the evenings, they make up a pretty good cricket side. "Andy Caddick's wife played a few games till she had a baby, and so did Bethan Shine [Kevin Shine's wife]. Then there is Lucy Turner [Rob Turner's wife] and Jamie Cox's girlfriend, Helen, and me. Although my brother and father played, and I spent my childhood chucking balls at my brother in the back garden, I only really got interested in playing properly when I met Marcus and the other girlfriends. I gave up playing for Somerset this year but I am still an allrounder for Taunton ladies." Though handy in the kitchen Marcus isn't a completely new man. "When I first started playing he used to take the mick out of me - although now he's very supportive. In my first year he took me up to the nets at Taunton to show me how to bat properly but of course I was having none of it." Quite right. Women always know best. Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read last week's column, on how the ECB can learn from the success of the Williams sisters at Wimbledon, click here.

webTitle: Comprehensive spending review: the Tory perspective

fields.headline: The chancellor and his shadow
fields.standfirst: Gordon Brown wasn't the only one under examination this afternoon - Michael Portillo's performance was just as important, thinks former Tory candidate Ed Vaizey
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown wasn't the only one under examination this afternoon - Michael Portillo's performance was just as important, thinks former Tory candidate Ed Vaizey.
fields.body:
Forget Gordon Brown's comprehensive spending review. The details of the speech he gave this afternoon had already been widely trailed. Of much more importance was Michael Portillo's performance. It was the Shadow Chancellor's first major set piece debate since he re-entered parliament and entered the shadow cabinet. How he fared will affect both the Tories' election prospects and his own career. It was vital for the Tories to get somewhere near the old familiar battleground of tax and spend. It was vital for Portillo to shine in front of his backbenchers.

Unfortunately, not even Portillo's greatest admirers could say that this was a barnstorming performance. He was not helped by some injudicious slip-ups, though some were beyond his control. Portillo stumbled when he referred to under-spinning instead of under-pinning. He should have seen that warning Labour MPs that they "would not save their seats" would bring raucous reminders of that terrible night in North London at the last general election when he could not save his own. But it has to be said that for someone in Portillo's position, to be referred to by the Speaker as the leader of the opposition was enough to finish off any hope of a fair hearing. Betty must be demob happy - will she be the first Speaker not to sit as a crossbencher in the House of Lords?

The performance may not have been brilliant, but there will be plenty more opportunities to come. What will matter in tomorrow's papers is the substance of what was said. It cannot be emphasised enough how much of an opportunity the Tories see Brown's proposed spending increases, the first chink of light between Prudence's billowing skirts.

The battle lines have been drawn. The Tories have chosen to stand on the ground of prudent spending and long-term tax cuts. It worked in the 80s. Whether this theme is taking root with the general public today is hard to fathom, however. It may well do. After all, as Portillo pointed out, Labour never won an election promising spending increases and the public are aware that spending must be paid for somehow.

Furthermore, as Portillo rightly and cleverly emphasised in his speech today, the public will not be as grateful to Brown as Brown thinks they should be. Spin is the new sleaze, and for this government, as perhaps with the last, the public is getting to the stage where they do not believe a word they say, either about the promised spending or the ability to pay for it. As Portillo said, Labour's spending isn't working and isn't credible. The Tories will try to make trust a central part of this election, not least for reasons of revenge.

While his leader practises judo, Portillo is trying a form of ju-jitsu on his opponent, using Labour's perceived advantages against them. Not only on the issue of trust, but on the issue of fiscal policy. Portillo is trying to saddle Brown with a spending guarantee, the mirror image of the Tory tax guarantee that caused the Tories such damage earlier in the year.

The argument runs as follows: by increasing spending significantly above the rate of growth of the economy, Brown has made an implicit pledge to fund real year-on-year increases in public spending. Portillo reasons that this is unsustainable. At some point, the economy will falter. It will become injudicious to continue to hike spending. Brown will either find himself closed in and forced to raise taxes, or he will have to climb down. That is why Portillo today refused to match Brown's spending increases, except in the area of health, which remains untouchable in the minds of politicians.

In effect Portillo has put Brown on notice and, he hopes, the public on their guard. It is a gamble. It will raise the morale of Tory backbenchers eager to find a chink in the Iron Chancellor's armour. At the same time it provides a convenient shorthand for commentators and doorstep canvassers to paint today's bounty as short-term and unrealistic.

But one must also counsel caution. Brown is gambling as well. The chancellor believes he has solved boom and bust, that the economic cycle no longer holds true in the new economy. His closest advisers genuinely believe that increased public spending can be sustained through prolonged economic growth.

But more realistically, the canny chancellor may checkmate Portillo another way. A pre-election budget next year already has an income tax built in, and you can bet your bottom pound that more are planned. Come March, we may have a chancellor crowing, as Nigel Lawson once did, "I can increase spending and cut taxes". A chancellor that can pat his head and rub his tummy at the same time a month before an election usually wins it.

This remains the dilemma for the Conservative party, their catch-22. As they have said repeatedly, taxes have risen. But no one has noticed, because income tax remains low. And while a huge hike in spending seems reckless, the headlines will cheer cash injections into the public's favourite institutions. Brown is the cleverest presentational chancellor since Lawson, and his boom will not go bust until after the election. Unfortunately today, Portillo could not raise his game enough to unnerve him. But at least the messages are coming right.

 Ed Vaizey is director of Consolidated Communications Public Affairs and a former Conservative party candidate.

fields.headline: Holiday activities
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor goes in search of fun and games for the summer holidays
fields.body:
Unless they show a precocious interest in sums, your children probably won't want a Maths Year 2000-themed day out. However, the free Birmingham Maths Fest on July 29 promises great things, and this year the National Grid for Learning has deemed a few museums suitable for holiday consumption.

Much more exciting is the Children's London site at This is London which rates the city's attractions in terms of suitability for children and offers discount vouchers for destinations all over Britain. Virgin Net's Days Out has a similar service, which lets you search for events by date and region.

The offer of a free children's ticket is the main reason to take part in Kids Week in the West End, which starts on August 25. Families have to buy an adult ticket at full price and the second and third children in the party get a 50% discount.

If you live in or near London, Birmingham, Leeds, Glasgow, Manchester, Cardiff or Bristol, Planit4Kids has some excellent listings and recommendations for the summer. Registered visitors can save the events into an online diary and get emails about upcoming events.

If your older children show no desire to leave the house, they might like to try some of the quasi-scientific experiments at Bizarre Stuff You Can Make In Your Kitchen. These range from traditional pinhole cameras and crystal gardens to fake blood, electric lemons, Cartesian divers and dancing raisins.

The more literary-minded could send in articles for the Children's Express, an international online magazine for children aged 8-18. Very young children can play games and practise basic skills at the Kids Channel. Online swaps are possible, too. The new parenting resource, Mumsnet, has tips for helping children to cook, read, draw and count for the first time, as well as plenty of networking opportunities and high quality editorial.

Education Unlimited will be suggesting events and places to visit over the summer holidays. Check our special report regularly for recommendations. If you want to tell us about events or what you thought of a particular day out, email editor@educationunlimited.co.uk and we will try to include it.
