webTitle: Chancellor announces £43bn boost to public services

fields.headline: Chancellor announces £43bn boost to public services
fields.trailText: Education and transport are to enjoy huge boosts in investment after Gordon Brown today unveiled a £43bn increase in public spending over the next three years.
fields.body:
Education and transport are to enjoy huge boosts in investment after Gordon Brown today unveiled a £43bn increase in public spending over the next three years.

The chancellor promised to get Britain learning and moving as he dipped into his election war-chest to appeal to middle Britain and traditional Labour voters by drawing up the battle lines on which it will be fought.

He told MPs that healthy public finances meant the government could afford to raise public spending to £246bn in 2003-04 from the £203bn of this year, significantly more than inflation, while staying in the black.

Mr Brown said that the government's "prudence for a purpose" during the two years after the last election had transformed the nation's finances as the Iron Chancellor turned into Cash Gordon.

Education spending is to rise £11.9bn over the three years to £57.7bn - average annual increases of 6.6% with heads sharing a special £540m fund they can spend as they wish.

He vowed that tough literacy and numeracy targets will be met, 500,000 more computers will be in classrooms within two years and and every school will be linked up to the internet within four years.

Before the 1997 last election, Tony Blair had pledged to make "education, education, education" his top three priorities and the education secretary, David Blunkett, has emerged as one of the biggest winners from the spending round.

The other main winner is the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, who saw his transport budget rise even more in real terms, climbing a staggering 20% a year from £4.9bn to £9.1bn to signal a concerted drive to ease road congestion and deliver better bus and rail services.

The fight against crime will see Home Office spending up from £8.2bn to £10.6bn over the period, an annual increase of 6.4%.

Even defence chiefs will get more money in real terms for the first time in 15 years with a £2bn windfall; the overseas aid budget will grow £800m; and a £415m fund will combat child poverty in Britain.

Agriculture will receive a further £300m, urban regeneration £400m and regional development agencies £500m. Mr Brown even found an extra £40m for the BBC World Service. Science and the arts also benefited.

And the chancellor said that in future, the government will match European Union development funds - a move that will be welcomed in Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and the north and far south-west of England.

Senior ministers are to make a series of detailed announcements over the next two weeks in an attempt to create a bandwagon to take the government through the summer and into an election expected next spring.

In a 40-minute speech, Mr Brown told a packed House of Commons that he wanted to create a "Britain of security and opportunity for all" in the teeth of Tory claims that he was funding the package by backdoor taxes.

A £13bn rise for the NHS was announced in last spring's budget, and the chancellor maintained the three-year spending spree was made possible by the government's prudence of the last three years.

Mr Brown resisted the temptation to double and triple-count increases - avoiding the mistakes of two years ago, when a £40bn boost to health and education turned out to be worth less than a third of that total.

The same trick today would have produced unbelieved claims of an £80bn bonanza. But he still risks public cynicism about the large figures until voters see the results in schools, hospitals and transport.

Today's package will be largely financed by the adoption of tight Tory spending curbs and tax hikes during Mr Blair's early years, Labour shifting from a spend-and-tax party into a tax-and-spend government.

With unemployment at a 20-year low, billions of pounds has been "saved", social security spending rising 1.5% a year in this parliament compared with 4% during the final Conservative years.

The chancellor has also gambled on no recession or serious economic downturn by loosening the purse strings ahead of the election to create clear blue water between Labour and the Tories.

The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, suggested that Mr Brown's "spending splurge" could turn out to be phoney, but he refused to commit the Conservatives to adopting them, leaving Mr Brown to claim the opposition offered a "Tory spending cut guarantee".

Mr Brown painted a glowing picture of public finances as overall spending grows to £212bn in 2001-02, £229bn in 2002-2003 before reaching £246bn after a series of above inflation awards to produce real improvements.

Mr Brown said the £28bn budget deficit inherited from the Tories has been "eliminated" and transformed into a current surplus of £20.4bn - more than the £17.1bn forecast in the budget earlier this year.

Healthy public finances had allowed him to repay a postwar record £18.1bn off the national debt last year and his plans show a further £29bn surplus over the three years.

Investment in public infrastructure, including buildings and roads, is at a 35-year low, and Mr Brown said it would virtually double to £18bn by the end of the period. The £22bn sale of new generation mobile phone licences, said Mr Brown, would reduce the national debt - unlike North Sea oil revenue which, he said, was "frittered away" under the Tories.

Whitehall departments and other public bodies will also raise £4bn a year by selling uneeded land, buildings and equipment.

The New Deal, initially introduced to help unemployed youngsters into work, is to be made permanent and a £134m rise to £200m in childcare spending will help parents take jobs.

fields.headline: Ten well chosen words
fields.standfirst: Every chancellor has his favourite phrases - find out what words Gordon Brown used
fields.trailText: Every chancellor has his favourite phrases - find out what words Gordon Brown used
fields.body:
1. Investing / investment
Times he said it: 41
Key quote: "By investing in our children we are investing in our children's future."
2. Education
Times he said it: 30
Key quote: "The greatest driver of prosperity - education and skills."
3. Target / targeted
Times he said it: 14
Key quote: "Targeted long-term investment is not only a social good, but in a changing and often insecure world an economic necessity."
4. Sustained / sustainable
Times he said it: 12
Key quote: "A sustained and sustainable improvement in our public services."
5. Health
Times he said it: 10
Key quote: "We are able to reallocate funds from unemployment and debt interest, to be used for our priorities in education and health."
6. Stable / stability
Times he said it: nine
Key quote: "Our choice is stability."
7. Opportunity
Times he said it: seven
Key quote: "A Britain of security and opportunity for all."
8. Strong
Times he said it: five
Key quote: "The precondition of a strong economy."
9. Success
Times he said it: four
Key quote: "Our success in cutting unemployment social security spending."
10. Discipline
Times he said it: two
Key quote: "We have not and will not relax our discipline."

fields.headline: Who gets what?
fields.standfirst: Gordon Brown has called his £43bn spending review "prudent for a purpose" but what are the frontline services that are benefiting, ask Patrick Barkham and Julian Glover
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown has called his £43bn spending review "prudent for a purpose" but what are the frontline services that are benefiting, ask Patrick Barkham and Julian Glover
fields.body:
Transport
A few months ago transport was tipped to lose out on the cash bonanza. But today rising popular concern about clogged roads and poor public transport led the chancellor to announce a "step change" in its funding, in the single most dramatic announcement among a profusion of real-term increases.

John Prescott's giant Department of the Environment was awarded a massive increase in funding of 20% a year in real terms, from £4.9bn this year to £6bn in 2001, £7.4bn in 2002 and £9.1bn in 2003-4. Deputy prime minister John Prescott will set out the spending plans in his forthcoming 10-year plan for transport. While he will seek to placate the roads lobby, railways and urban light-rail systems will be a priority. Voters want immediate improvements, but it will be years before they feel the impact of the rebuilding.

Education
Described as "the great driver of prosperity and skills" by the chancellor, education has done very well out of the spending review: Schools, colleges and universities will share almost an extra £12bn over the period 2001-2 to 2003-4. A typical English secondary school will see its direct funding rise from £40,000 to £60,000 in 2001-2, the chancellor told MPs. Primary schools will also get more, with funding for a typical junior school jumping from £9,000 to £12,000 in the same period. Funding per pupil will have risen by over £300 per pupil in real terms since 1997. By 2003-4, funding per pupil will be £700 higher than it was during Labour's first year in office.

The chancellor is hoping that this additional cash will boost the performance of Britain's under-achieving secondary schools, particularly in deprived areas. Skills, adult literacy and university access are issues which interest him, and they have done well. Higher education will receive an extra £100m in 2001-2 on top of the £295m announced earlier in the year. Further education will get £50m to extend the controversial performance-related pay scheme, which has recently been blocked by the courts. The decision to give £540m to head teachers to spend as they wish next year is noteworthy: new Labour is steering clear of its "control freak" tag.

Crime
The Home Office has won an annual rise from 2001-2004 averaging 6.4% a year in real terms. The chancellor signalled that new spending plans outlined by the home secretary, Jack Straw, next week would unveil a big increase in frontline policing, particularly welcome after today's crime figures showed a 3.8% increase in reported crime in England and Wales in the 12 months to March. As well as appealing to Middle England's desire to get tough on crime, the chancellor bid for the liberal vote, pledging money to cut drug-related reoffending and to double the number of addicts treated at national centres.

Welfare
The chancellor's attachment to the government's New Deal is well known. Announcing today's spending plans, Gordon Brown spoke of transforming what started out as a new deal for the young unemployed into "a permanent deal for long-term unemployed". £1.7bn from the windfall levy next year and every year until 2003 will help apply the welfare-to-work scheme to the older unemployed, in particular those skill-starved middle-aged jobless. The chancellor also offered a boost for the government's new national childcare strategy. Increasing funding from £66m to £200m by 2003-4 will aim to open up working opportunities to more mothers. All this is aided by savings which the chancellor said were "in excess of £1bn" in the welfare budget, coming from cut-backs on benefit fraud and getting more people into work.

Defence
Gordon Brown's first spending announcement was on defence, reflecting the concerns in Tony Blair's leaked memo that the government was seen as "soft" on issues of national and international security. The chancellor announced a startling reversal of the steady fall in defence spending: with £23.6bn next year, rising to £25bn in 2003-4, it will increase in real terms for the first time since the end of the cold war, more than a decade ago. The increase is also a reaction to military fears of overstretch as a result Britain's involvement in peacekeeping missions around the world.

Health
Details have been known about one of the big winners from the spending review since March, when the chancellor used the budget to unveil a £13bn increase in health spending in real terms over three years. By 2003-4 it will have grown by 6.1% - double the historic trend since the NHS was set up in 1948.

Early signs are that this will include new proposals to limit waiting lists to nine months or less and to break down the boundaries between different professions in the NHS.

Overseas development
Often the first target of chancellors looking to cut spending, Clare Short's department for international development has done well today. Foreign aid is to increase by 6.2% a year in real terms, with money also set aside in a joint budget with defence for peacekeeping,

Trade and Industry
The government has already announced a £1bn increase in spending on science, although scientists say they need more to compete. Today Gordon Brown has announced an increase in funding for a new small business service, from £197m this year to £277m by 2004. A key part of this will be a national internet service providing small business advice. Information technology will also be boosted by the government's pledge to offer all its services - from benefits to passports - online by 2005. Tony Blair will announce a new fund for this initiative this summer.

Regional Development
Another big success for John Prescott was the chancellor's promise of "match funding" for objective one, two and three areas supported by EU structural and social funds. Areas such as Cornwall, Merseyside and South Yorkshire will benefit from an estimated £600m in EU and government funds, while Wales is singled out for a rise of 5.4% each year in real terms.

Culture
Chris Smith took two projects to the chancellor as the spending review was underway: and has won support for both of them. A real-terms rise in annual spending of 4.3% will help revive school sports with the appointment of specialist instructors and also save regional theatres from closure. BBC World Service is also earmarked for extra funds, with its budget rising from £174m to £180m next year.

Environment
Environment has been on the periphery of Labour's concerns in its three years of government and the chancellor's spending plans for the next three years reflect this. There is an eye-catching pledge of a fund of £85m to assist with nuclear clean-ups, and also money for new initiatives to cut emissions and promote recycling and renewable energy. "Affordable" new housing is allocated an additional £1.6bn of new investment by 2004.

fields.headline: Hollywood battles its web nightmare
fields.trailText: A legal battle taking place in New York this week could have serious implications for film piracy on the net. Seven major Hollywood studios have launched a case against a website editor who they claim has cracked the code that encrypts DVDs
fields.body:
The music industry is being turned upside down by innovations on the net, and now it seems the movie world is not immune from the threat of its product being made available to download illegally - and for free - on the internet. A legal battle taking place in New York this week could have serious implications for film piracy on the net.

Seven major Hollywood studios have launched a case against a website editor who they claim has cracked the code that encrypts DVDs. The seven studios, Universal Pictures, Walt Disney, Fox, Paramount, MGM, Time Warner and Sony Entertainment, want to stop Eric Corley from marketing the DVD codebreaker - known as DeCSS- available through his 2600.com website, which is an online version of his magazine, 2600: The Hacker Quarterly.

The software makes it possible for computer users to copy full-length feature films from DVDs on to their own computer hard drives or CD ROMS. Lawyer Leon P Gold, who represents the studios, said: "This case relates to the protection of artistic works and to the health of the American motion picture industry". The courtroom was shown scenes from movies including Sleepless in Seattle and The Matrix (pictured) which had been downloaded onto a hard disk.

The studios are seeking to put an end to Corley's DeCSS web postings, and want compensation for profits lost due to DeCSS downloads so far. Corley's lawyers are citing the First Amendment, which they believe protect their clients' rights to provide the software to the public.

Meanwhile Eric Corley has become something of a hero among his fellow hackers for standing up to the hugely powerful motion picture industry, despite their winning a preliminary injunction in January forcing his site to remove the DeCSS code from the Web.

The Wall Street Journal yesterday also published the internet addresses of several sites that offer software permitting high-quality, full-screen videos to be downloaded from the internet relatively quickly. "Hollywood, your nightmare is here," the newspaper commented.

The technology is apparently based on software developed by Microsoft and distributed to software developers. It significantly reduces the size of a file for an average-length movie without significant loss of quality from five gigabytes to 650 megabytes, which can be easily stored on a conventional CD.

The case is expected to continue for a further two weeks.

webTitle: Schools top agenda in Brown's spending review

fields.headline: Schools top agenda in Brown's spending review
fields.standfirst: Public impatience with the government has led Gordon Brown to revive Tony Blair's "education, education, education" mantra, argues Ros Taylor
fields.trailText: 18 July, 5.30pm: Public impatience with the government has led Gordon Brown to revive Tony Blair's "education, education, education" mantra, argues Ros Taylor.
fields.body:
This time, it's all about schools. Gordon Brown's decision to award an extra £540m each year directly to headteachers, bypassing local education authorities, is testament to public impatience with the agonisingly slow improvement in educational standards. Mr Brown has also taken a leaf out of William Hague's new educational primer.

Last week's annual report boasted that 71% of 11-year-olds achieved the standards expected for their age in English and 69% in maths. Those results were hailed as a triumph for the new literacy and numeracy hours in primary schools.

Look at the results for older children, however, and the progress is distinctly slower.

Mr Brown announced an ambitious (some would say foolhardy) target for 14-year-olds today - that 85% of them will meet literacy and numeracy targets for their age by 2004. The extra £50,000 per year for a small secondary school is an attempt to achieve that.

Crucially, the new money will make it harder for headteachers to blame their local authorities for failure. Already a number of local authorities have been forced to hand over the responsibility for their schools to private companies and a new breed of "super-heads". With this initiative, failures will be pinpointed and targeted.

The Tory leader, William Hague, intends to get rid of local authority powers and "make every school a free school". Allocating a larger sum to heads is the first step towards exactly the kind of independence Mr Hague has in mind.

The Laura Spence affair, which the chancellor himself ignited, was revisited this afternoon. "Elitist" universities such as Oxford and Cambridge, which were criticised for admitting a disproportionate number of privately-educated students, will not be forced to positively discriminate in favour of state pupils, but their funding increases will be tied to an improvement in state admissions.

Given that the government wants to see half of all 18-year-olds going on to higher education, the real-term rise in funding by by 4.6% (with extra money for science) is the least that Mr Brown can get away with. Whether it will be enough to curtail the top universities' plans for a massive rise in tuition fees is unclear, but unless he can change their minds, the Laura Spences of the future won't be rejected by Oxford and Cambridge - because they simply won't be able to afford to apply.

fields.headline: Upstairs or down
fields.standfirst: Cambridge has won the dubious title of poshest UK university, but how are the other 99 faring?  Lee Elliot Major on the latest findings
fields.trailText: Cambridge has won the dubious title of poshest UK university, but how are the other 99 faring? Lee Elliot Major on the latest findings
fields.body:
Cambridge has dethroned Oxford as the most socially exclusive university in the country, according to the latest breakdown of figures for student applications and admissions to universities.

The statistics reveal an increasingly ghettoised higher education sector, with the vast majority of students among the elite research institutions from the white middle-classes, and usually straight out of school. Student bodies in the former polys, particularly in London, reflect much more closely the broad ethnic and class mix of society as a whole. Female students, meanwhile, make up over half of freshers in over 100 academic institutions.

The 1998-99 figures represent the most up-to-date social map of the student population, presented by the official academic number crunching outfit, the Higher Education Statistics Agency, and taken from the university and colleges admissions service.

Oxford's reputation as the UK's poshest university was sealed when Chancellor Gordon Brown accused it of elitism after it rejected state school pupil Laura Spence, who then gained a place and a £65,000 scholarship at Harvard. Brown attracted the wrath of academics for generalising from an ill-informed specific case. But the overall statistics backed his argument.

Performance indicators for universities unveiled by the higher education funding councils last December revealed that, with under half of its student intake from state schools in 1997-98, Oxford lagged further behind the benchmark for the sector as a whole for similar subjects and students' A-level results than Cam bridge. The Sutton Trust charity later used these statistics to show that the chance of getting into one of the top 13 research universities is about 25 times greater if you come from an independent school than from a lower social class or live in a poor area.

Admissions statistics for 1997-98, meanwhile, showed that Oxford had the highest proportion of students with parents from professional and managerial backgrounds among universities, enrolling just under 80% from the two highest social classes.

But the 1998-99 admissions statistics reveal that Cambridge has overtaken Oxford as the most socially exclusive university. There are two reasons for this: applications from the highest social classes were slightly down on the previous year for Oxford, but - more significantly - students from these groups are more likely to be selected at Cambridge once they have applied. In 1998-99 over 80% of Cambridge undergraduate admissions comprised students from managerial and professional households.

In fact, student applicants from the upper social classes are more likely to be admitted to the London School of Economics than any other university, including Oxbridge. The LSE leads a batch of elite London academic institutions, including King's College and University College, London, where a much larger proportion of students from posh backgrounds gain places than students from poorer households. It is only because so many students from upper- and middle-class backgrounds apply to Oxbridge initially, that the final proportion of admitted students from these classes is higher than other institutions.

At the LSE, just under 71% of admitted students from the UK were from the professional and managerial households in 1998-99, even though these groups made up only 62% of applications to the school. But it is far from clear what the reasons are for this bias in university admissions towards the upper and middle classes, and whether it is simply due to students being better prepared or qualified from such groups.

But perhaps the most startling trend to emerge is the increasing ghettoisation of the academic world, with a social, ethnic and economic divide distinguishing many of the older traditional institutions from the modern universities.

As well as the Oxbridge institutions and LSE, the universities of Bristol, Nottingham, Edinburgh, Newcastle, St Andrews, and University College, London all recorded over 70% of their UK student intakes from the two highest social classes in 1998-99. In contrast, students from these backgrounds made up less than half this proportion - 35% - of the new student numbers at the universities of Central Lancashire, Thames Valley, East London, North London, London Guildhall, Luton, Wolverhampton and Paisley.

Among the former polys, Oxford Brookes attracts by far the highest percentage of students from the upper classes, with over 40% of its intake made up of these groups. The UK academic sector as a whole admitted 52.26% of students from the two highest social class groups in 1998-99.

A dramatic racial divide also splits the academic sector, even though a university's locality can have a large impact on the ethnic diversity of its intake. Students from ethnic minority backgrounds make up less than 4% of intakes at Ulster, Exeter, Bangor, Stirling, Plymouth, York, Heriot-Watt, Lancaster, Edinburgh and Newcastle. Yet they make up more than 12 times this proportion - over half of student enrolments - at North London, Westminister, Thames Valley, South Bank and City universities. Just under 80% of freshers at the University of London's School of Pharmacy in 1998-99 were from ethnic minority groups.

The percentage of new female students at universities, meanwhile, partly reveals whether an institution has more departments in the sciences or arts. Those with fewest female freshers, for example, include Imperial College, London, and the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, where under a third of student intake were female in 1998-99.

Other universities with more male students are Cranfield, Loughborough, Heriot-Watt, Portsmouth, Coventry and Staffordshire. Just down the road from Imperial, Royal Holloway and Bedford New College had twice the proportion of female freshers in 1998-99 - making up over 60% of its intake. Other universities that have particularly high female intakes are Keele, Middlesex, Ulster, Anglia Polytechnic, and East Anglia.

Truer than fiction

Joseph Smythe

With three As from Havacasher's, the league-table-topping boarding school, Joseph strolled into Oxbridge. Like his father before him, he is now studying medicine and even after six years of training will still be only 24 when he graduates. Interviews held no terrors for someone used to attending his parents' dinner parties and conversing with consultants and academics.

Home for this, his first university year, is one of the rooms overlooking the central quad of Gates College. Most of his chums have been made over a bottle of port in the college dining-room. But there are other Havercashers scattered around the colleges in the ancient university town. Joseph appreciates fine art and is an accomplished cellist, but he has also been known to slum it on friends' floors after a particularly heavy night. He once went awol for 24 hours after Glastonbury.

Joseph enjoys playing most types of sport, including tennis, rugby, cricket and hockey, and has supported Arsenal football club ever since he first read Fever Pitch. When visiting his family in London he always tries to get to home games.

He was selected as the Gates College Mixed Hockey Captain for the 1999-2000 season. He is also a prominent member of the medical school rag committee, which is drafting plans to dress up as women for a day and collect money for a host of local charities.

Jo Smith

Jo dropped out of Claptown Comprehensive sixth form shortly after her parents divorced, but after a number of short-term clerical jobs retook two A levels in English and politics. Winning a place on the combined media and film studies degree course at London North Bank University was a family first, since neither of her parents had been to university.

Now 24, Jo rents a one-bedroomed flat in Archway, north London, which she shares with her boyfriend, who works as a runner for a cable TV channel.

She goes out clubbing when she's got the cash, but had to miss this year's Glastonbury when the cash machine ate her card. She supports Arsenal football club but never goes even though she lives just down the road. Her pet hates are having to do her weekly shop at Iceland rather than Sainsbury's and her boyfriend having even less cash than her.

Jo would be a member of Greenpeace if she could get round to joining, but it's hard enough saving her kitchen from becoming an environmental hazard. She aims to work in the media, and is angling for a work placement on the local paper. She wishes she had better contacts to help her career along.

She works part-time in a local pub, the Hare and Hounds, and has to skip some lectures to keep the job.

Her parents are proud of her achievements, but worry about her debts.

Like his father before him, he is now studying medicine and even after six years of training will still be only 24 when he graduates. Interviews held no terrors for someone used to attending his parents' dinner parties and conversing with consultants and academics. Home for this, his first university year, is one of the rooms overlooking the central quad of Gates College. Most of his chums have been made over a bottle of port in the college dining-room. But there are other Havercashers scattered around the colleges in the ancient university town. Joseph appreciates fine art and is an accomplished cellist, but he has also been known to slum it on friends' floors after a particularly heavy night. He once went awol for 24 hours after Glastonbury. Joseph enjoys playing most types of sport, including tennis, rugby, cricket and hockey, and has supported Arsenal football club ever since he first read Fever Pitch. When visiting his family in London he always tries to get to home games. He was selected as the Gates College Mixed Hockey Captain for the 1999-2000 season. He is also a prominent member of the medical school rag committee, which is drafting plans to dress up as women for a day and collect money for a host of local charities. Jo Smith Jo dropped out of Claptown Comprehensive sixth form shortly after her parents divorced, but after a number of short-term clerical jobs retook two A levels in English and politics. Winning a place on the combined media and film studies degree course at London North Bank University was a family first, since neither of her parents had been to university. Now 24, Jo rents a one-bedroomed flat in Archway, north London, which she shares with her boyfriend, who works as a runner for a cable TV channel. She goes out clubbing when she's got the cash, but had to miss this year's Glastonbury when the cash machine ate her card. She supports Arsenal football club but never goes even though she lives just down the road. Her pet hates are having to do her weekly shop at Iceland rather than Sainsbury's and her boyfriend having even less cash than her. Jo would be a member of Greenpeace if she could get round to joining, but it's hard enough saving her kitchen from becoming an environmental hazard. She aims to work in the media, and is angling for a work placement on the local paper. She wishes she had better contacts to help her career along. She works part-time in a local pub, the Hare and Hounds, and has to skip some lectures to keep the job. Her parents are proud of her achievements, but worry about her debts.

fields.headline: Big Brother
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the TV show for peeping Toms
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the TV show for peeping Toms
fields.body:
1. Big Brother, a worldwide "social experiment" and slice-of-life TV starts on Channel 4 tonight.

2. In the show, 10 strangers live for nine weeks in one house with 24 cameras and no privacy. Viewers vote for one inmate to be kicked out each week and the winner pockets £70,000.

3. From its origins in Holland the format has spread to Germany and the US and poppped up as Gran Hermano in Spain.

4. Big Brother attracts controversy: Germany's interior minister called on viewers to boycott the show if they "still cherish feeling for human dignity".

5. And in the US, CBS is accused of failing to properly vet its inmates after the New York Daily News revealed that one contestant, William Collins, was an aide to the anti-semitic (and expelled) former leader of Nation of Islam, Khalid Abdul Muhammad.

6. George, a 41-year-old family man who ranks The Blues Brothers as his favourite movie, has a little secret too. He accidentally shot and killed a close friend during a hunting trip 12 years ago.

7. But bigger problems may lie with the show's plummeting ratings. During Sunday lunch, engineering student Josh wondered aloud what would happen to the inmates if CBS prematurely pulled the plug.

8. Back in Britain, Channel 4's choices seem safer. Some 40,000 applied to take part in the British version, which is being made by Bazal productions, part-owned by the Guardian Media Group. Anna, a 29-year-old former nun, who loves anything written by Bill Bryson, is favourite to be last contender standing.

9. The conditions are tough. Personal possessions (such as pens) are banned and toiletries must be bought from a small weekly grocery budget.

10. Getting down to what most viewers (and TV executives) are most interested in, Flutter.com is offering person-to-person wagers on who will sleep with who. And when.

fields.headline: Shaken not sturdy
fields.standfirst:
It was billed as a symbol of British mastery of design and technology but wound up being a national embarrassment. So was London's wobbly bridge a product of over-ambitious 'emotional' design or flawed engineering? And why didn't anyone think of testing it? Andy Beckett investigates
Special report: the millennium
fields.trailText: It was billed as a symbol of British mastery of design and technology but wound up being a national embarrassment. So was London's wobbly bridge a product of over-ambitious 'emotional' design or flawed engineering? And why didn't anyone think of testing it? Andy Beckett investigates
fields.body:
If you go down to the millennium bridge in London, after midnight, when the workmen are gone and the buildings around are silent and darkened, you may notice something surprising. At the south end, behind the builders' hoardings, a solitary security guard sits in a steamed-up Portakabin. He'll be there for as long as it takes the bridge's wobbles to be cured. At the north end there are some temporary gates, locked but not that tall, a piece of paper pinned up reading "Bridge Closed", the pins already old-looking and rusted, and a single word of graffiti: "Why?".

And beyond the gates, out over the black Thames, between the swooping, lit-up handrails of Britain's most currently infamous architectural experiment, there may be silhouettes moving about - illicit visitors: curious people testing the decking, couples smoking cigarettes in midstream, people just marvelling at the views and taut steel. "You feel suspended in space above the river," says one. "It was a sublime experience." After watching the moon and the skyline for a while, he walked back towards the riverbank: "I saw another dozen people climbing up."

Even by British standards, the bridge has become an ambiguous piece of modern architecture. It has been shut for more than a month, ever since 200,000 people - about five times the number expected - turned up on its opening weekend. A campaign to re-open it, before the vibrations are even dampened, is gaining momentum in the London Evening Standard.

In some ways, this slim, silvery span and the appetite for using it seem to demonstrate a new national confidence in all things hi-tech and streamlined. Ever since its construction was announced five years ago, the bridge has been talked about excitedly in science fiction terms: a "blade of light", a "magic carpet", an "absolute statement", in the words of its designers Foster and Partners, "of our capabilities at the beginning of the 21st century".

New bridges in general, after decades as unloved and ugly projects, are back in fashion. There are plans for more in London. There are millennium crossings underway or recently completed in York, Peterborough, Tyneside and County Fermanagh. These arcs of glass and aluminium seem to offer spectacle and usefulness, opportunities for regeneration and property development, publicity for their surrounding areas - the perfect combination, it appears, for the contemporary urban planner. Mark Whitby, a bridge engineer with three British projects on the go, says local councils now tend to choose the "most adventurous" design on offer.

But what if it wobbles? When the millennium bridge's wide deck began to buck and sway, all this adventure suddenly looked slightly reckless. Aesthetics - one of the bridge's engineers approvingly described its design as "emotional not rational" - seemed to have overwhelmed practicality. And as identifying the precise problem, and its origin, and how to solve it, has lengthened the likely closure from "a few weeks" to "a few months" to "a matter of months - hopefully", so the structure has started to become a British symbol of a more traditional sort: a big project running late.

At first, official statements about the bridge, like an an untrustworthy station announcer's, see-sawed between evasion, over-confidence, and sulkiness. It was the pedestrians' fault. Or it was strictly the bridge engineers' (Foster and Partners remain keen to redirect press enquiries to Ove Arup). Or there was no problem at all, just a national suspicion of "ambition". Lately, the PR line has softened: "The swaying is bridge-induced, not pedestrian- induced," admits Tony Fitzpatrick, Arup's bridge overseer. He says that a solution - flexible shock absorbers fixed along the underside - is currently being discussed with the relevant manufacturers. But the anxiety set off by the bridge, and the over-budget Jubilee Line, and the late-starting millennium wheel, and the deflating Millennium Dome, and the builder-blighted quality of British cities in general, remains. Must building ambitiously in Britain always be such a struggle?

According to the official history of the millennium bridge project, the publication of which has also been delayed, a crossing between Southwark and St Paul's Cathedral was first suggested in 1851. It took another 60 years before an Act of Parliament was passed to authorise it, and another three were spent discussing whether the bridge should be positioned to create a new tram route or give the best possible view of St Paul's. Finally, in 1914, a florid classical design was chosen which included "a winged goddess driving a two-horse chariot". Then the first world war broke out.

The idea of a link between the prosperous City and poor south London gradually faded, as idealistic schemes for the capital tend to. It took the re-awakening of interest in grand architectural gestures along the Thames during the 90s to revive the bridge-building notion. David Bell, now chairman of the Millennium Bridge Trust, was working for the Financial Times in Southwark: "My office overlooked the river. I thought, 'Wouldn't it be fantastic to build a bridge from St Paul's to the Bankside power station?'"

Bankside was already marked for conversion into the Tate Modern. Southwark council was keen to make a cultural quarter out of its concrete flatlands. Tourism on both riverbanks would clearly benefit. But Bell was quickly made aware that such arguments might not be sufficient. "Everybody said, 'You'll never get permission.'"

He decided to use publicity as a weapon. In 1996, the Financial Times sponsored a public competition asking architects, engineers and artists to devise a crossing. More than 200 designs were submitted; one of them was from Foster and Partners, Ove Arup, and the veteran British sculptor Sir Anthony Caro. Precisely which of them initiated this collaboration is now a matter of polite jockeying. Caro says he called Foster. Ken Shuttleworth, the Foster partner in charge of the bridge, says they were thinking about entering anyway. Chris Wise, the Arup engineer most involved early on, has now left the company and communicates via cryptic phone messages.

What seems fairly certain is that, one evening that summer, Wise and a fellow Arup engineer, having agreed to meet Foster and Shuttleworth and Caro the next morning, went to a wine bar called Zelda's in Charlotte Street in central London and started drawing on napkins. They steadily rejected conventional designs - a suspension bridge's towers, for example, would have obscured St Paul's - for a flat, minimal platform "stretched as tightly as possible between the two banks", as Wise put it later. "We went home that night tremendously excited about the purity of the diagram, and petrified that the bridge might shake itself to bits..."

The following morning, they gathered at Caro's studio up the road in Camden. While Caro's assistants made rough cardboard models, Wise's "guitar string" design evolved into the "blade of light" Foster envisaged. Sitting in the studio's low, boxy chairs, surrounded by bold frag ments of recent Caro projects, they did not dwell too much, at least as the meeting is remembered, on the more prosaic question of the bridge shaking.

In December 1996, their design was announced the winner. "And I thought that was what you built," says Caro, ruefully creasing his brow. "How naive I was." For the next two and a half years, during many meetings at Foster and Partners, and impromptu group expeditions to the riverbanks, and an eternity of discussions with planning authorities, the actual structure of the bridge was determined. There were compromises: the flat span became a less abrupt arch, Caro's plans for elaborate ramps and gateways at either end were watered down. There were endless explanations: some sceptics in the City demanded to know how the bridge's lights could be kept free of charred insects. And, on occasions, there was a sense close to futility: when Foster gave a presentation to a City planning committee, the first ever by an architect, the first questioner afterwards thanked "Sir Richard Rogers".

But Foster, unlike Caro, was used to the minefield of a public commission. At one stage, the architects successfully re-submitted some rejected drawings by making the sky bluer and the bridge users younger. "What Nor man absolutely correctly judged," says Fitzpatrick, slipping easily into a public relations abstraction, "was generating the sense of wonderment".

Ove Arup gave the bridge its highest rating for complexity of construction - the same as a state-of-the-art corporate fortress. The cost, met by Southwark, the City, business donors and, most of all, the millennium commission, rose from around £10m to approaching £20m as the committees nit-picked and the Thames harassed the workmen. Building took 13 months instead of the promised 12; at the official opening in April, the Queen could only edge halfway across. Even now, behind the hoardings at the south end, the promised landscaping is piles of wet gravel and an abandoned wheelbarrow.

Since the bridge closed, there has been a suspicion that contemporary engineers are perhaps getting a bit carried away. The construction of models on computer screens, and the convergence of architecture and engineering have "released the engineer", says Whitby, "from the need to prove absolutely he knows what he's doing". He thinks this is good - experiment and the passing problems that result are the best way to learn more. The bridge's spin doctors have been arguing the same in recent weeks.

But another engineer, more closely involved with the millennium scheme, disagrees. "There's got to be tremendous care when a competition goes ahead that the engineering is sound," he says. He suggests that the judges in this case, who included politicians, businessmen from non-architectural fields, and the broadcaster Anna Ford, were more concerned with the look of the crossing, and the attendant possibilities for publicity, than with its structural soundness. "I was concerned about vibration when I first saw the plans over two years ago," he says.

Fitzpatrick responds that every possible test was done. A Canadian wind tunnel was hired to imitate gusts off the Thames, for example, before the bridge had even been commissioned. What about testing the span with crowds of people? There is an uncharacteristic pause. "Load testing of a new design is extremely rare. Bridges are built to the codes developed by the great and the good... They are built well within factors of safety." He pauses again. "The only way to have picked this up would have been a false opening. And you can't use the public for that."

Last week, Bell offered me a bridge tour regardless. Rain was blasting up the Thames. He climbed a slippery, wet ladder in his pinstripe suit, clambered over some scaffolding onto the streaming deck, and attempted to explain the latest official position. "The millennium wheel had its problems, but people forgot about them very quickly," he half-bellowed, as we battered our way to midstream. The bridge bounced very lightly beneath our feet. On all sides, above the handrails, London loomed dripping and magnificent. He grinned winningly. The spine of the bridge curved upward. We might have been climbing into the sky.

But afterwards, in the Portakabin, a thought occurred. Would the water on the deck freeze in winter? "The maintenance people have that under control," said Bell. "Besides, things rarely freeze in London."

webTitle: Corruption busters die in Hong Kong blaze

fields.headline: Corruption busters die in blaze
fields.standfirst: Suspicious fire kills anti-fraud investigators in one of China's boom cities
fields.trailText: Officials tackling corruption in China have been shaken by a suspicious fire at the weekend which killed investigators trying to root out graft in the boom city of Shantou.
fields.body:
Officials tackling corruption in China have been shaken by a suspicious fire at the weekend which killed investigators trying to root out graft in the boom city of Shantou.

The fire swept through a government guesthouse where the officials had been staying for months, killing five people.

Shantou, in the north of Guangdong province, is one of 15 coastal towns and cities on which Beijing's corruption commission has focused since January when President Jiang Zemin called for a new campaign against "unhealthy tendencies" among senior officials in the Communist party.

Other targets include Fuzhou and three other areas in Fujian province, now notorious as the source of the 58 illegal migrants found dead in Dover last month.

There are strong suspicions that the "snakehead" gangs of human smugglers in Fujian often work in league with party and government officials to send people abroad.

Initial reports from Shantou suggest that Saturday's fire, in a building which forms part of a closely guarded government compound, may have been started deliberately.

The Guangdong police chief, Liang Guoju, rushed to the scene to investigate the cause, and Shantou officials were told to "heighten their vigilance".

According to the local police, at least two of the dead belonged to the joint Beijing-provincial corruption team, and several other members of the team were seriously in jured. A report on China's Central Television website said that four of the team had died.

The investigations follow a number of high-profile cases of corruption.

Senior officials with good connections in Beijing have been implicated in a huge case of fraud and import duty evasion in Xiamen, another city in Fujian province.

Rumours that the wife of a close associate of the president is also involved have had to be denied publicly.

Investigators from the central commission for discipline inspection working on the investigation in Xiamen complained earlier this year that their telephones were being tapped by the local police.

An embargo has been imposed on further news reports of the protracted case.

Last week the Chinese parliament, the national people's congress, expelled Xie Yongwu, a member from Xiamen, on the grounds that he was suspected of being involved in smuggling.

Other cities under investigation include Haikou, capital of the island province of Hainan, where the first large-scale import scam was started by senior party officials as far back as 1985.

Guangxi province, whose capital Nanning is on the target list, is also well known for chronic corruption.

And a new purge of corrupt officials was launched last week in Shenzhen, the modern city across the border from Hong Kong, which is also on the list.

A deputy mayor of the city has been implicated in a plot to fix lucrative land deals in exchange for bribes.

Several of the team staying in the Shantou guesthouse are believed to have worked previously in another area of Guangdong, clearing up a complex graft case in the southern port city of Zhanjiang.

Mr Jiang's speech denouncing corruption in January was only published in April, apparently as Beijing grew increasingly concerned about the Xiamen case and other scandals.

The president condemned what he called a wave of "feudal" nepotism and graft, and said that "several leading cadres" were "exchanging power for money and power for sex".

But he balanced his condemnation of corruption with a warning against attempts by foreign countries to undermine China by "influencing us with their political views, ideology and lifestyles".

He returned to the theme in a speech on June 9, published yesterday, in which he called on young party cadres to "fight against western hostile forces infiltrating and seeking to overthrow [the party]".

Rumours that the wife of a close associate of the president is also involved have had to be denied publicly. Investigators from the central commission for discipline inspection working on the investigation in Xiamen complained earlier this year that their telephones were being tapped by the local police. An embargo has been imposed on further news reports of the protracted case. Last week the Chinese parliament, the national people's congress, expelled Xie Yongwu, a member from Xiamen, on the grounds that he was suspected of being involved in smuggling. Other cities under investigation include Haikou, capital of the island province of Hainan, where the first large-scale import scam was started by senior party officials as far back as 1985. Guangxi province, whose capital Nanning is on the target list, is also well known for chronic corruption. And a new purge of corrupt officials was launched last week in Shenzhen, the modern city across the border from Hong Kong, which is also on the list. A deputy mayor of the city has been implicated in a plot to fix lucrative land deals in exchange for bribes. Several of the team staying in the Shantou guesthouse are believed to have worked previously in another area of Guangdong, clearing up a complex graft case in the southern port city of Zhanjiang. Mr Jiang's speech denouncing corruption in January was only published in April, apparently as Beijing grew increasingly concerned about the Xiamen case and other scandals. The president condemned what he called a wave of "feudal" nepotism and graft, and said that "several leading cadres" were "exchanging power for money and power for sex". But he balanced his condemnation of corruption with a warning against attempts by foreign countries to undermine China by "influencing us with their political views, ideology and lifestyles". He returned to the theme in a speech on June 9, published yesterday, in which he called on young party cadres to "fight against western hostile forces infiltrating and seeking to overthrow [the party]".

fields.headline: Bar to success
fields.standfirst: Despite the worldwide fame of British theatre and dance, we are failing to invest enough in the training of our future McKellens and Bussells
fields.trailText: Despite the worldwide fame of British theatre and dance, we are failing to invest enough in the training of our future McKellens and Bussells
fields.body:
The government is failing to invest sufficient resources in the training of the next generation of actors and dancers, according to an influential new report out today which highlights the many anomalies in current funding arrangements for specialist further and higher-education courses.

The report, commissioned by the National Council for Drama Training, broadly welcomes the speedy introduction last year of a new scholarship scheme - the so-called Dance and Drama Awards (DaDA) scheme - by the incoming Labour government, which helped more than 800 students in its first year. But it is essentially inadequate in its scope, under-funded and bureaucratically very complex, the report says.

Mindful of the recent attention given to sports training after Britain's spectacular failures in Euro 2000, the 1998 World Cup and in tennis and cricket, its author, Graham Marchant, an independent arts consultant, concludes: "Britain is already seeing the results of failure to invest properly in training in sports activity; it would be a disaster if similar mistakes were made in one of the few other arenas where this country has an absolutely outstanding international reputation to defend."

The Marchant report on actors' training was commissioned by the NCDT, the body which accredits and oversees the standard and content of the training for actors and stage managers provided by the drama schools. It wanted an independent assessment of the success of the scholarships - introduced a year ago to provide the first mandatory funding for trainee actors, dancers and stage managers - at the end of their first year in operation, with a view to establishing how they might be improved and extended in future.

Ministers say that whatever the weaknesses of the new system, which has had some changes since its introduction, it is infinitely preferable to "the appalling shambles" that existed before. The incoming Labour administration inherited a hugely complicated web of courses for actors and dancers. These range from arguably the best quality courses, run by the tiny independent schools which did not qualify for state funding, to thousands of courses in performing arts and media which are not even recognised or connected to the industry.

Until the late eighties, students who wanted to enter the profession through a three-year course at an independent drama school relied on discretionary funding from their local education authority on the same basis as anyone at a university. Their fees were paid in full, and their maintenance grant depended on parental income. But local authorities came under pressure from central government over the next decade, so fewer grants were available. The system turned into a restricted "postcode lottery", with funds determined by where students lived rather than talent.

The situation became so bad that the Arts Council of England was persuaded to use lottery funds for an emergency Interim Funding Scheme (IFS) for dance and drama students. But even this continued the basic inequity of a geographical lottery for students, and was swept away when the incoming Labour government ordered the Department for Education and Employment and the Department for Culture, Media and Sport to agree a new, fairer system of receiving grants. Education secretary David Blunkett was appalled that the issue was one of the main topics dominating MPs' postbags.

The new-look Dance and Drama Awards Scheme was formally announced by higher education minister Baroness Blackstone in November 1998. Initially it involved 820 scholarships, worth around £6,000 a year, allocated to 29 private institutions with approved courses. Among the top dance and drama schools taking part in the scheme are the Bristol Old Vic Theatre School, the English National Ballet School, the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art, the Northern Ballet School and the Birmingham School of Speech and Drama.

As Peter Cheeseman, chairman of NCDT, comments in his statement prefacing the report: "The new mandatory scheme is a great milestone in the history of our state funding for the arts. The crisis had become so serious that hardly any grants were available to students who had passed the rigorous audition procedures and gained a place at our vocational drama schools. Only students from really wealthy families, and state-funded students from other countries, were becoming able to enter training. This was an appalling waste of national talent."

But the Marchant report is realistic about ongoing poverty among Britain's trainee stars. Such poverty is experienced by those who have won scholarships and those who have not and who have to resort to writing begging letters or taking part-time jobs on top of their gruelling training.

"Until the government is ready to use the funds it has available to support drama training with maximum efficiency, the charitable sector - and individual actors - must take the strain. This is simply wrong," Marchant says. So the scheme has helped create a "two-tier" system by discriminating between "talented" students who win the sought-after awards and so-called "untalented" ones who are on the same prestigious courses but without the benefit of the scholarship. "A better way to strangle the great British tradition of team acting at birth would be hard to imagine" is one of his gritty conclusions.

To solve this problem, more scholarships should be provided, the report says: "Since the industry believes that all the courses accredited by NCDT are appropriate and needed, then the government should provide enough funding for the numbers of British students needed to maintain those courses."

Another concern is that many of the courses run at the best-known schools, such as the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art, have been allocated to the further education sector when they should properly be part of higher education with a more appropriate structure of independent scrutiny. And while students on FE courses get assistance with annual fees of up to £9,000, they are ineligible to apply for student loans.

The DfEE has, however, trebled the size of a special hardship fund to help out FE students, allowing them to claim up to £3,000 in living expenses. But the Marchant report wants all students on the accredited courses to be eligible for student loans like any other student in higher education in Britain. In this way, the funding of all three-year dance and drama courses would be put on an equal footing with traditional university courses, which allow students to get maintenance grants as well as the payment of their fees over the £1,050 which they pay.

Adele Bailey, executive director of the NCDT, says: "The problem is that there aren't enough scholarships to go round for the recognised courses. And the scheme is an ugly one, with raw edges. Only 20 out of the 30 students admitted to Rada every year get funding through the scheme. You can't say the other ten are not talented."

 The Funding of Drama Student Training in Britain, Autumn 1999, by Graham Marchant is published by the National Council for Drama Training, supported by funds from The Mackintosh Foundation and the Society of London Theatre.

'It's no way to train or live'

Ben Weeratunge is 19 and has just completed his first year of a three-year course leading to a National Diploma in Classical Ballet at the Central School of Ballet in Clerkenwell, central London.

The teenager - whose striking stage presence and looks are due in part to his half-Thai background - is one of 18 students at the college with a sought-after DaDA scholarship. But that only covers up to £7,300 of his £9,500 annual fees, leaving him a shortfall in addition to the £1,050 he must meet himself. And he gets little help with his estimated maintenance costs of at least £5,500, as his course's Further Education status means he is not eligible for a student loan.

He has spent the first year living "hand to mouth", with financial help through loans, help from his mother (a single parent who is a teacher), a contribution from the FE hardship fund and earnings from weekend bar work.

The stress caused by finances and the physical demands of the course means he may have to drop out at the start of his second year - unless he gets significant private-sector sponsorship. "It has been a nightmare," he says. "I would like to become a professional jazz dancer and this is a wonderful course. Yet even with the supposed benefits of the scholarship, I am having to live hand to mouth. It is no way to train or to live."

The course is gruelling even by dance standards - 8.30am till 6.30pm, six days a week, with students expected to get in at 8am to warm up. Ben is also taking A levels and has theoretical coursework to do on Saturdays at college. But he has to spend the rest of the weekend working in a bar to meet his weekly financial commitments: rent of £75, travel costs of £25, and £30 for food.

"Last year I got dribs and drabs from trust funds, including £100 to buy ballet shoes, which I wear out pretty quickly. But there are lots of extras. On a course like this, for example, we are expected to see the dance shows in London, where ticket prices are not cheap."

For Ben, the worst thing is feeling constantly tired. "I am exhausted throughout the week, and very sadly I often feel as though I am not getting the most out of the course."

fields.headline: Make a difference
fields.standfirst: Many students get exploited on their summer jobs. You needn't, writes  Richard Colebourn
fields.trailText: Many students get exploited on their summer jobs. You needn't, writes Richard Colebourn
fields.body:
Summer holidays have arrived for students, but many face the prospect of working for longer hours than they would ever contemplate during term. Whether improving their career prospects, funding travels abroad or simply meeting the rising costs of studying, students are flooding the labour market. The unwary may be faced by employers pressurising them into working for longer hours and less money than their usual employees, safe in the knowledge that there will be others ready to step into their places.

TUC research suggests that the average student earns £4.37 an hour, but 3% of students will be earning less than the minimum wage, just £3.20 an hour for those aged between 18 and 21.

For many, employment is essential to pay for their studies, and some are exploited. The National Union of Students highlights the case of a student at Hull who spent the summer working for a company providing student accommodation, and was advised that he might be required to "sometimes" work long hours. A few weeks into the job the student was being asked to work until 9 or 10pm for six days a week, and was then threatened with dismissal if he didn't work on Sunday too.

Bharti Patel, Director of the Low Pay Unit, is aware of the problems students face. "There will be a big influx of of workers over the summer, especially in the leisure industry, which unfortunately is also one of the lowest paid. Employers exploit the big increase in the supply of labour by paying students low wages.

"Check out the pay of other employees. If students are part-time workers then they should not receive less pay than full-time members of staff," she advises.

Although students may regard themselves as just casual labour for the employer, they do still have rights. "If the job lasts for more than 13 weeks then the employee is entitled to holidays, and after four weeks they can demand a written contract. This is important because it is the foundation of the relationship between employer and employee. Another common problem is that people take a job and after a few days decide they no longer want to work there. They then have problems getting hold of the money they have earnt. There are ways of receiving owed pay through a tribunal," Patel explains.

However, a lucky few will be earning up to £400 a week working as interns for top banks, management consultants and major companies.

Such firms offer students the chance to experience life in the City, including the long hours and pressure. Competition for places is fierce, but companies reward the select group handsomely. Salaries range between £250 and £400 a week, but accommodation, overtime and food are often included on top.

Django Davidson, a geography student at Oxford, will be working at management consultants Andersen Consulting.

"I'll probably be there between 9.30am and 6-7pm, and maybe later to 11-12pm for the few days before projects are completed. But friends who have done internships at investment banks tell me that they were expected to work until midnight four days a week.

"The money will be very helpful because studying is expensive, and next year I am having to rent accommodation privately. The good thing about my internship is that you work alongside consultants on real projects, rather than just making the tea," he explains.

But if the worst happens, and you are heading for a long summer of shelf stacking or dish washing, employers and careers advisers suggest that you can still use it to your advantage once you graduate.

Whatever you do to earn money, the important thing is to make the most of it on your CV. Ben Johnston, graduate recruitment manager for Andersen Consulting, favours CVs that show how students have effected some change, regardless of the level or nature of work they have done. "Whether you worked in a bar or on an e-commerce project, the main thing is to show that you did more than was simply required."

fields.headline: Prudent for a purpose (II)
fields.standfirst:
Gordon Brown's statement

2000 spending review
fields.trailText: Madam Speaker
fields.body:
Madam Speaker

I turn now to the investment we must make in our economic future. Britain has great strengths - the best place in Europe to do business, with world class companies in science and technology - but to build for the future , we must put in place the long term investment which is the precondition of a strong economy and of bridging the productivity gap with our competitors and avoid the short-termism of the past.

Working with business, the role of modern Government is not to subsidise loss-makers, or to attempt to pick winners.

The new role of Government is to invest in science and innovation, to promote competition, small business development and enterprise for all, to encourage balanced regional development and meet the pressing needs of transport and infrastructure and most of all to invest in the greatest driver of prosperity - education and skills.

First, investment in science. With our investment in a one billion pound public private partnership with Wellcome to re-equip university science and extra resources to support pioneering medical research, we will raise the science budget by 5.4 per cent a year.

And to ensure invention in Britain leads to manufacturing in Britain and jobs in Britain, the Secretary for Industry will announce new resources for the University Challenge Fund that commercialises inventions and for university-based Regional Enterprise Centres.

Britain's small businesses are the backbone of our local economies. And to offer new services businesses have themselves requested, the budget of the new Small Business Service will rise substantially from 197 million pounds this year to 277 million pounds by 2004. This will include a national Internet service offering comprehensive business advice and a consultancy service for start-ups, worth up to 2,000 pounds for start ups in high unemployment areas. So that the numbers of small businesses who employ, which have already risen from 1.2 million in 1997 to 1.3 million, can expand in every area of the country.

The newest and most decisive challenge in the new century demanding higher levels of investment is to master and lead in the new information technologies from the Internet to e-commerce.

To make Britain best for electronic trading and to bridge the growing digital divide, the Review has agreed a three year programme of rapidly rising investment in our schools and our communities and a new fund the Prime Minister will announce to ensure that by 2005, Britain will have all Government services offered on line.

Investment in innovation, infrastructure and skills is essential in every region if there is to be high levels of productivity in Britain and full employment throughout our country.

To secure balanced regional development, Regional Development Agencies will receive new resources, their budgets increased by 500 million pounds a year by 2003-2004. There will not only be new funds but new flexibilities so that local people can promote local priorities and meet local needs they have themselves identified; in the North West promoting innovation and research; in the North East, increasing entrepreneurship; in Yorkshire and Humberside, small business development; in the East Midlands, information and communications technology; in the West Midlands, modern manufacturing; in the South East and South West, as in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, with their devolved decision-making, the promotion of clusters of growth; in every region new support for skills, employment and for schools and colleges to promote enterprise open to all.

The overall settlement for Scotland provides for an increase of 3.4 billion pounds a year by 2003-04, an annual real terms rise of 4.4 per cent. A separate announcement will be made by the Scottish Executive.

For the Objective 1 areas in the UK - in Wales, Cornwall, Merseyside, South Yorkshire - and for Objective 2 and 3 areas I am announcing a new approach that will raise their levels of investment.

Within our departmental allocations we are making today the Government will ensure funding for the European share of Objective 1, 2 and 3 projects.

For EU structural funds this is estimated to total 4.2 billion pounds over three years, including an estimated total of 600 million for new Objective 1 programmes in English regions.

The settlement increases funding for Wales by a total of 5.4 per cent a year in real terms and allows for match funding - and includes a special allocation to ensure funding of the European share of Wales' Objective 1 needs, an allocation to Wales of 80 million, 90 million, 102 million pounds over the next three years. I am also transferring management of the European Social Fund allocations for Wales of 149 million pounds over the next three years to the Welsh Assembly.

It is because of the importance to all regions of modern transport and infrastructure that we will now make a step change in investment in public transport.

Having in the Budget removed the automatic fuel escalator, extra money was allocated to roads and public transport this year. And now we are able to raise spending on roads and public transport by significant extra sums to meet the needs of business and the public, from 4.9 billion pounds this year to 6 billions next year, then to 7.4 billions and 9.1 billions in 2003-2004, a real terms rise of 20 per cent a year to 2004. Details of the targets to improve rail and bus services and to cut road congestion and of the allocation of funds will be set out in the Ten Year Plan published by the Deputy Prime Minister on Thursday.

The modern economy can succeed only when it uses all the talent of all its people. Any potential squandered is a resource denied to the country's future. In this Review we allocate new funds to advance our goal of full employment.

For 70,000 employers, nearly 500,000 young people and for Britain, which has seen long-term youth unemployment fall by 70 per cent, the New Deal has been succeeding, a central building block for our policy of full employment.

So long-term youth unemployment which rose to 500,000 in the 1980s is 50,000 today.

The Windfall Levy raised over 5 billion pounds with 1.6 billion allocated to schools, 3.5 billion to employment creation.

Because the New Deal has been even more successful than forecast, with more getting back to work more quickly, there is an underspend, enabling us to fund the New Deal well into the next Parliament, and to transform what started as the New Deal for the young unemployed into a permanent deal for all long-term unemployed.

Having helped 500,000 on the New Deal, we now set plans to help the next 500,000. Next year and until 2003, I expect 1.7 billion pounds to be available from the Windfall Levy to do more to coach the hard-to-employ young unemployed and to systematically create new opportunities for our long-term unemployed, nearly one million single parents and thousands of disabled men and women who want to work.

To bring both child care and employment within the reach of more parents, child care investment will rise from 66 million pounds this year to 200 million by 2003-2004, as we deliver our national child care strategy.

Because of our success in cutting unemployment social security spending, which grew by 4 per cent a year in the last Parliament, is growing by 1.5 per cent a year over the next three years and the budget for unemployment related benefits is falling.

To make further social security savings by tackling fraud and error we are announcing new investment in staff and technology. Having cut errors in income support claims by half, we now plan to cut fraud and error in the job seekers allowance and income support payments, first by 25 per cent by 2004 and then 50 per cent.

It is by continuing a prudent policy - economic stability, the New Deal, and tackling fraud and waste - that we are able to reallocate funds from unemployment and debt interest, to be used for our priorities in education and health.

I turn now to investment to ensure all children have the best start in life. Today's children will be tomorrow's doctors, scientists, engineers and nurses - our future workforce. By investing in children, we are investing in our country's future.

Having invested 7 billion pounds a year more in families - raising Child Benefit by 35 per cent to 15.50 pounds, guaranteeing a minimum family income under the Working Families Tax Credit and from next April the new Children's Tax Credit giving the typical family 442 pounds a year - it is time to take an additional step.

The war against child poverty requires not only additional cash but the support and encouragement of all forces of care and compassion in every community. And it can only be won by the combined efforts of parents and private, voluntary, charitable and public sectors working together.

So in a unique initiative - and after consultations with charities and voluntary organisations - we will create a national Children's Fund with a budget over 3 years totalling 450 million pounds to help children and young people at risk.

The Children's Fund will work with national children's charities and local community organisations - secular and faith based - and support those dedicated staff and committed volunteers who offer one-to-one help to young people - and parents - at risk. 70 million pounds will be allocated to a network of 50 local and regional children's funds.

Madam Speaker

I turn to investment in education as a whole.

Education qualifications are, in the modern world, the surest route to opportunity and security for all.

First, all children should be ready to learn when they reach school.

From the first Spending Review came Sure Start - now lifting 50,000 children and their parents out of poverty. In this second Review - and tied to targets for improving child development and parental responsibility - we will, by 2004, and with a budget of 500 million pounds, expand the number of children helped to 345,000.

And with nursery places already increasing from 200,000 in 1997 to 400,000 in 2002 the Secretary of State for Education and Employment will announce funds for the next stage in the expansion of nursery education

Second, having improved standards in our primary schools, the next task is now to raise standards as decisively in the secondary schools --- so that the expansion of resources the Secretary of State for Education and Employment will announce for all schools is designed to back up reform and to being about radical improvement within the comprehensive system to ensure opportunity for all means the highest standards for all

The Secretary of State for Education and Employment will now consult on and fund a new target for our secondary schools - by 2007 not today's 60 per cent but 85 per cent of 14 years olds must meet literacy, numeracy and computer standards.

To raise Britain's appallingly low staying-on rate, we are setting aside 150 million pounds a year for education maintenance allowances worth up to 40 pounds a week. Our new and challenging target is by 2004, 80,000 more young 16-18 year olds staying in education and by age 21 nearly 60 per cent of young people will have left school or college with A levels or their equivalent.

Under the New Deal for Schools 17,000 of our schools will have had some improvement, modernisation or renovation by 2002, and every one of our 32,000 schools will be linked to the Internet, with the objective of by 2004 500,000 more computers in our schools.

By 2010 we want the majority of young people to go on to higher education. The Secretary of State is today allocating 100 million pounds extra to higher education in 2001-02, making a 4.6 per cent real terms increase in total. And the Review provides further finance that will raise the numbers in part-time and full-time higher and further education - towards our goal of 50 per cent of young people going into higher education by the end of the decade.

State school pupils secure two-thirds of the top A Level qualifications but only half the places in some of our leading universities. To bridge this gap the Secretary for Education is today setting a new objective to improve access. The Higher Education Funding Council will provide financial help for universities submitting plans for year-on-year improvements in widening access.

2 million adults have a reading age of 7 or less. Adult illiteracy is not just a failure of our society but - as business leaders round the country have told me - an economic inefficiency that cannot any longer be tolerated. In the coming weeks, the Secretary for Education will announce the new resources provided to tackle these barriers to opportunity and earnings.
