webTitle: Gough's life story and Durham's do of the week

fields.headline: Gough's life story and Durham's do of the week
fields.standfirst: In wisden.com's gossip column this week, Charles de Lisle explains why Darren Gough is already writing his life story at 29 and reports on cricket's Do of the Week
fields.trailText: Gough sells his life story
fields.body:
Gough sells his life story

Twenty wickets in four Tests are not the only reason for the spring in Darren Gough's step. Gough has recently signed a lucrative contract to tell his life story.

Although it's a move commonly associated with stars near - or at - the end of their careers, Gough, 29, emphasises that he hopes to play international cricket for several more years. The autobiography will be published by Michael Joseph next May, to coincide with his benefit season with Yorkshire and the arrival of his favourite opponents, the Australians.

Why is Gough taking a step which even Mike Atherton and Alec Stewart, both about to play their 100th Tests, have so far resisted? Gough's representative, Clifford Bloxham, explains: "It's our view, and certainly Darren's, that it's better to produce the book when he's doing really well. He likes to think he has three or four more years at the top."

As for money, Bloxham will say only that Gough is being rewarded "commensurate with his standing in the game". Given that he is England's biggest drawcard, a figure of £30,000-£50,000 is probable.

"We're only interested in the most charismatic and successful sportsmen," says a spokesman for Michael Joseph, which recently published Viv Richards' memoirs, "and Darren's as close to a high-profile footballer as you can find in English cricket".

The publishers have high hopes that Gough's levels of form and fitness this season will be maintained when the book hits the shops next season. At least one publisher involved in negotiations, CollinsWillow, was deterred in part by Gough's injury record.

His account of the journey from Barnsley childhood to the only Ashes hat-trick by an England player last century (Sydney, 1998-99) doesn't promise much in the way of dressing-room score-settling, brushes with authority or domestic drama a la Phil Tufnell. As Bloxham puts it: "There's nothing really for Darren to be controversial about. He hasn't much to moan about, except injuries - and they aren't controversial."

Maybe not, but readers of Gough's newspaper column will be surprised if he doesn't elaborate on his forthright views on the failings of English cricket. Gough fans will also be treated to "funny observations and comments" in a work to which he's been giving surprisingly serious thought for several years, at least in spare moments. The book will be ghostwritten by David Norrie, long-serving cricket correspondent of the News of the World, who works with Gough on the column.

Gough is not exactly noted for his literary interests. He has one book - Darren Gough's Book for Young Cricketers (1996) - to his name but his reading habits are a standing joke on tour. During the 1998-99 Ashes trip, he caused amusement when he was spotted on an aeroplane turning the pages of what was believed to be "his first grown-up book" - Addicted, the bestselling life story of Tony Adams, the England footballer and reformed alcoholic. "Books are not Darren's number-one hobby," concedes Bloxham. "He prefers reading magazines or newspapers, or watching videos."

Do of the Week (the fifth in an occasional series)

Occasion "Eve of international dinner" on Friday, July 14, marking England's first appearance at Durham's Chester-le-Street ground, in the one-dayer against West Indies the following day. Held at the Linden Hall Hotel, Morpeth, Northumberland (a 35-mile drive from the action) in aid of Durham's Benefit Year 2000. The beneficiary is not a player, but the club itself, which will spend the £100,000 it hopes to raise on ground improvements and youth development.

Format Champagne reception at 6.45pm, followed by dinner at 7.30pm, with guests tackling five courses - if you count the truffles - with all the relish of a Flintoff. It was a traditional cricket evening - no gimmicks, no fuss - and it was all over by 11.15pm, not least because benefit committee members were due on duty at the ground at 8am next morning.

Attendance 180, paying £40 a head, led by Graham Gooch, Durham's batting coach, and David Graveney, chairman of the England selectors, who was Durham's first captain. "It's almost like coming home," remarked Graveney, who actually hails from the West Country. There were walk-on roles for his uncle Tom Graveney, returning to his native North East, who said grace, and Trevor Bailey, who proposed the loyal toast. Also there: Peter Parfitt, the former England batsman.

Notable absentees Organisers hoped to have "one or two" representatives of the England, West Indies and Zimbabwe squads, but none could fit it in. The first two teams had a decent excuse: their clash next morning.

Main talking points There was only one: the weekend's games at the Riverside, the proudest achievement yet of the Durham visionaries who aim to bring Test cricket to the North East sooner rather than later. Gooch's well-known mantra that it's the "finest county ground in England" couldn't be repeated often enough to the excited Durham rank and file. Afterwards, Tom Moffat, chairman of the benefit committee, said: "People were saying it was the best dinner they'd ever been to. There was no wasting time between courses!".

Principal entertainment An auction of memorabilia in which a bat signed by members of the great England side of the 1950s, including Graveney and Bailey, fetched £370. Then there were brief speeches: Tim Lamb, chief executive of the ECB, praised Durham's "spectacular" facilities, and David Kendall, bank manager turned after-dinner speaker, wrapped up proceedings.

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). You can e-mail him at cdelisle@compuserve.com

For last Friday's Grapevine, featuring stories on how EW Swanton's POW-camp Wisden has gone on show at Lord's, how Marcus Trescothick once reached 4000 runs off the last ball of the season, and how Zimbabwe are cashing in on their good form, click here.

webTitle: Tesco puts old measures back on its shelves

fields.headline: Tesco puts old measures back on its shelves
fields.standfirst: Quiz: how imperialist are you?
fields.trailText: Tesco is bringing back pounds and ounces for much of its food produce.
fields.body:
Tesco is bringing back pounds and ounces for much of its food produce.

Much of the in-store advertising at Britain's biggest supermarket chain will not even mention metric weights, while its own-brand packaged foods will display metric and imperial measures in equal size.

Tesco will also give prices calculated in old-style weight the same prominence as kilos and grams on shelves and at deli, meat and fish counters.

Rivals yesterday were considering the move, while the government and trading standards officials were marvelling at a publicity stunt that met the letter of British and European law but gave the impression of defending tradition.

Tesco's marketing director, Tim Mason, said: "It is time to turn the scales in favour of the British customer. Some 90% of our customers think in imperial. They tell us that when it comes to size, imperial matters. We're not anti-Europe, but we are pro-shopper."

The company said its research indicated that more than half its customers found metric weights confusing, and three-quarters would like imperial measures displayed.

Its online shopping arm had revealed misordering such as a customer ordering 3kg of broccoli (weighing 6.6lb) rather than 3lb as intended and another ordering 9kg of potatoes (19.8lb) rather than 9lb.

But Tesco is sticking within a European law that since January has required all goods to be priced in metric at tills. These were changed in most grocers years ago when other foods went metric. It is also obeying British requirements that labelling at shelf edges does not give greater prominence to imperial measures than to metric.

"We would never drop metric," said the company. "All kids have been educated in metric, but a large part of the population was not."

The Department of Trade and Industry welcomed the move: "We are very keen that retailers play their part in helping customers."

Tony Allen, of the trading standards institute, said: "It is a very clever bit of publicity. Legislation only requires that things are weighed in metric when you get to the till."

There have been some cases recently highlighted of traders apparently being warned in a heavy handed way to change to metric scales. But Mr Allen said: "We have taken a very soft approach to it, by advice and by helping to convert scales. A lot can be converted quite easily and cheaply."

Competitors yesterday said they too displayed imperial equivalents in many parts of their stores, but imperial weights had disappeared from packaged foods.

Sainsbury's said it gave both measurements, with price, on shelves with loose produce, though the metric was slightly more prominent than imperial. There was no comparative pricing at the deli counter, but prices were given per 100 grams rather than kilograms.

Asda said its imperial pricing on shelves, though smaller than metric, was in a yellow box.

Safeway said it had phased out imperial measures on packaged food to ensure clear labelling for customers.

webTitle: What the rising crime rates mean

fields.headline: What the rising crime rates mean
fields.standfirst:
Crime correspondent Nick Hopkin asks how seriously we should take the crime figures released by the Home Office today
Straw to target drink-related crime
Crime figures for your area
2000 British crime survey
fields.trailText:
Crime correspondent Nick Hopkins asks how seriously we should take the crime figures released by the Home Office today.
Straw to target drink-related crime
Crime figures for your area
2000 British crime survey
fields.body:
There is no getting away from it. Figures don't tell lies, not these ones at any rate. And they mean Jack Straw, the home secretary, has to digest the very unpalatable fact that crime in the UK has soared in the last 12 months.

But how significant are the new figures, released by the Home Office today, and whose explanation for the increase should we believe?

If the question wasn't tricky enough, there are whispers that the statistics released today mask the true extent of the problem. An independent report due out shortly will claim that the figures in England and Wales are at least 20% higher than those recorded by the police, and that hundreds of thousands of offences - including assaults, burglaries and car crimes - have been excluded because of police inefficiency and bureaucracy.

This report, by the inspectorate of constabulary, is interesting, but not truly significant. Police inefficiency and bureaucracy are not new issues. They were prevalent in 1999 and many years before. The inspectorate is banging the same old drum and its conclusions are valid only if taken in the broadest sense, rather than focused on one particular year.

There have always been wrangles over crime figures. The last British crime survey, which evaluates experience of crime, estimated that there were 20m incidents in a single year. The Home Office figures, which cover crimes recorded by the police, say that there were 5.3m last year. Neither invalidates the other.

Changes in the way violent crime is added up may have given an artificial look to the increase in this category. Common assaults are now included, but they should have been last year too. There could also be a delayed effect on the figures due to police forces coming to grips with new procedures. However, this cannot account for the number of violent crimes against the person increasing by 16%.

Yet Mr Straw hasn't tried to bamboozle us with smoke and mirrors. The rises are real and the home secretary thinks he knows where to lay the blame.

"There is a real problem, a really serious problem about alcohol and violence," he said today.

"I think young people have got more money in their pocket and there is a greater susceptibility to get drunk."

The Tories insist the solution is more Bobbies on the beat. Some senior police officers agree, but most, privately at least, admit that this knee-jerk response will not bring down crime rates. Sheffield, where crime fell last year, has proved that intelligence-led, target-based policing, is the way forward, not more officers walking the streets.

The argument is unlikely to sway Middle England. In one sense, Mr Straw's problems have only just begun.

webTitle: We have ways of making you read

fields.headline: We have ways of making you read
fields.standfirst: Belfast boys reap the benefit of having an award-winning literacy specialist at their school
fields.trailText: Belfast boys reap the benefit of having an award-winning literacy specialist at their school
fields.body:
Following the unprecedented scenes 10 days ago of children (and, indeed, adults) storming the bookshop barricades to get hold of a copy of the latest Harry Potter book, one has to ask: Is reading - as opposed to DIY, cooking or gardening - the new rock 'n' roll?

Certainly David Blunkett, along with several thousands of parents/ carers across the land, would be heartened to think so.

But while JK Rowling appears to have succeeded in appealing to male and female readers alike, in general boys continue to lag behind girls in their literacy skills. Added to this, there remain concerns about the drop in standards shown by many young people when they move from primary to secondary school.

For an all-boys secondary school, then, the battle to win year 7 pupils' hearts and souls to the simple pleasures and wider educational benefits of reading a good book is a doubly tough one. And it's a problem faced with each new intake at Ashfield Boys' high school in Belfast.

Over half of Ashfield's intake have a reading age of two years or more below their actual age, and staff used to face negative attitudes towards books from the majority of pupils when they arrived. But thanks to the school's literacy programme, this trend has been significantly reversed. Reading ages and borrowing from the school library have soared dramatically.

John McLean was curriculum and literacy co-ordinator at Ashfield, until his retirement after 35 years' service this summer. He explains that there are five main ingredients to the school's literacy programme, and the programme is very much a whole school issue.

The first element is language across the curriculum. "Every subject introduces four new words per month pertinent to their discipline," McLean explains. "Pupils write these up in a personal dictionary, and they're tested on them periodically."

Second, "Every teacher has accepted a common code of marking and grading. A cross-curricular exercise in moderation is conducted at various times during the year to guarantee consistency. Pupils are made aware of standards of presentation through seven simple rules."

Third, a full-time teacher is employed to provide in-class support for subject teachers, focused on the intake year at the school.

As part of their aim to make Ashfield a "reading school", the fourth ingredient of the programme is morning reading. "Every room has a trolley with a classroom library and for 10 to 15 minutes a day pupils read quietly," says McLean. Pupils also frequently use the main library, with loans balanced between fiction and non-fiction books.

The final ingredient is the remedial reading scheme, which all pupils in year 8 join during the year. Working in groups of two or three several times a week, pupils then return to normal subject periods when their reading age reaches a satisfactory level.

And here Ashfield has a secret weapon, in the shape of Doreen Minnis, Northern Ireland regional winner of this year's teaching award for Excellence in Special Needs in a Secondary School. Minnis was taken on as a reading specialist at Ashfield four years ago and, working closely with the special needs and English departments, she set up the remedial reading programme.

The essence of her approach was to try and work out what the boys would actually want to read. The school library was purged of all the old books that no one was reading, and replaced with the kind of books the boys were interested in, about soccer and computers. This led to Minnis having to pretend to be a soccer fan on many occasions! She retired this summer, and will be much missed.

One grateful parent wrote to the school, "May I take this opportunity of thanking the school, and in particular Mrs Minnis, for all the help and support Jason has received since he started in September. Jason has become a very confident reader who has rediscovered a love of books, after several years of feeling he was failing at reading."

If reading really is the new rock 'n' roll, thanks to the work of McLean, Minnis and their colleagues, the boys at Ashfield high school seem to have all the best tunes.

 Cool School on Tuesday June 13 featured Ellie Baker, who designed a rudder angle indicator for use in sailing. Ellie recently came second in her age group in the Young Engineer competition. Congratulations!

fields.headline: Recipe for success
fields.trailText: Having just completed the education department's training, I predict that performance management is going to be a piece of cake - for everyone.
fields.body:
Having just completed the education department's training, I predict that performance management is going to be a piece of cake - for everyone.

The recipe was provided by the excellent material, and the competent governor trainer enabled us to relate the material to our schools.

Of course, the recipe isn't perfect. The governing body will have to adapt it to fit the circumstances of their own school. But as I understand it this is one of the key reasons for having governors - to prevent control from Whitehall.

Performance management is just one of the elements needed to improve the school. To make it work, governors will need to:

 Be involved with and understand the school development plan

 Monitor and evaluate policies

 Receive and understand the performance information that the school receives or produces

 Form an honest and trusting partnership with the teaching staff - especially between chair and headteacher

The next stage is how to mix the ingredients together. At our school, the governing body and headteacher discussed the implications and established a working party. The only new ingredient was the external adviser.

The cake is now "resting" until the performance review in the autumn, which can only help us to focus on school improvement and effective governance.

 FE Browning is a chair of governors in Essex.

To make it work, governors will need to:  Be involved with and understand the school development plan  Monitor and evaluate policies  Receive and understand the performance information that the school receives or produces  Form an honest and trusting partnership with the teaching staff - especially between chair and headteacher The next stage is how to mix the ingredients together. At our school, the governing body and headteacher discussed the implications and established a working party. The only new ingredient was the external adviser. The cake is now "resting" until the performance review in the autumn, which can only help us to focus on school improvement and effective governance.  FE Browning is a chair of governors in Essex.

fields.headline: Only the best should apply
fields.standfirst: Kevin Conway  asks whether the Learning and Skills Council will be slick enough for his college
fields.trailText: Kevin Conway asks whether the Learning and Skills Council will be slick enough for his college
fields.body:
Nick Stuart, the director-general of lifelong learning at the DfEE, addressed sixth-form college and tertiary principals at their annual conference recently. The agenda he laid out for post-16 lifelong learning on behalf of his ministers is, I believe, utterly reasonable - raising achievement to the standards of the best at present, improving retention, widening participation to form a more inclusive learning society and closing skills gaps in key areas such as information technology and engineering. We are happy to work to that agenda in our colleges.

Again, on the positive side, my colleagues are relieved that, at long last, we have a government which understands the need to invest to achieve these objectives. The past few years have seen the first real increases in funding per student for many years, such a refreshing change from the arid policies of year-on-year cuts of 3% and more of the previous administration. We have a real chance, therefore, of making progress in meeting objectives which are both demanding and right. As providers, we are ready to take up the challenge.

However, there is one key piece of the jigsaw that must be remodelled to fit into this vision - namely, the administrative interface between the DfEE and providers. At present this is the Further Education Funding Council and the Training and Enterprise Councils, but shortly will be the new Learning and Skills Council. I, for one, am looking for a new partnership between my college, as a provider, and the new Learning and Skills Council and my local learning and skills council.

In May, 1999, ministers at the DfEE awarded Greenhead college Beacon College status. At the same time, the funding council awarded the college accredited status. To achieve these, the college had to provide conclusive evidence of the highest standards over time in achievements, retention, widening participation, financial management, top quality assurance in all areas of the college, and strong and visionary governance and management.

Fifteen colleges have achieved this Beacon status. In each, the common factors are that the managers of these colleges set their staff demanding objectives in terms of developing their students' potentials on the one hand, and, here is the crunch, they then ensure that the senior administrative team support their staff in every way possible to meet those objectives.

A key part of my job is to ensure my senior staff see as their primary focus the facilitation of my staff and students in terms of resources and support to meet set objectives. I believe our college administration must be of Rolls-Royce standards so that there can be no excuses for not meeting objectives fairly set.

So back to my jigsaw piece - the new Learning and Skills Council administration. This has to be a Beacon administration, if we want world-class lifelong learning. I want senior administrators to help me solve my problems, not to create continually new problems for me. I want to know my objectives for the following academic year in January or February, and I want my full budget allocation at the same time. Ideally, I want both presented on two sides of A4, so that my governors and staff can plan for excellence.

I am looking for senior administrators who are respectful, genuine and empathetic, and who wish to facilitate and serve me and my fellow principals, so that we can do likewise for our staff. I want a grade one administration, with many strengths and few weaknesses, with people who have a genuine experience of working in the sector.

 Kevin Conway is principal of Greenhead college, Huddersfield.

fields.headline: Not up to scratch
fields.standfirst: Colleges would collapse wihout part-time teachers, many of them unqualified. But won't compulsory training risk driving them away?
fields.trailText: Colleges would collapse wihout part-time teachers, many of them unqualified. But won't compulsory training risk driving them away?
fields.body:
Further education is laced with staggering statistics that continue to trigger delight - and also prompt some despond. First the good news: adhesion to the government's crucial "social inclusion" agenda; responsibility for providing over 40% of UK entrants to our universities; oh, yes, one in 10 (190,000) degree-level students each year completing their higher education studies in the ivory towers called further education colleges - also the epicentre of vocational learning and, equally, the proud defenders of traditional adult and continuing education culture.

These achievements are impressive and often go unrecognised. The sector could do even more and faster. But holding it back, more than anything, is the equally astonishing fact that the majority of the part-time people delivering the further and lifelong learning revolution are not qualified, in the formal sense, to teach at all. This matters because virtually two thirds of all further education teaching staff are now employed on a part-time basis to do the business.

It is a recent phenomenon. In the mid-1980s part-time lecturers accounted for only about 15-20% of the total work workforce. But by last year, this proportion had leapt dramatically to 63%, with many recruited through agencies.

Take two examples. Solihull college has 1,118 staff on the pay roll, 178 are full-time lecturers, but 528 are part-timers. At Blackpool & Fylde college there are 271 full-time staff but 322.26 part-time ones.

The bad news is not necessarily that part-time teachers do most of the teaching in further education. It is that too many are not up to scratch as teachers, according to senior Further Education Funding Council inspector Beryl Pratley, referring to a national survey to be published soon.

However, Paul Mackney, general secretary of the main lecturers' union Natfhe, reckons the problem is not the quality of part-time work taught in colleges, but the way these lecturers and staff are employed. There is, he reckons, the existence of a "cut-price Yosser approach", in which lecturers remain casualised on temporary, possibly fixed-term deals, with no contractual rights.

There needs to be a high-quality staffing strategy, whereby contracts guarantee on-going work and employment rights are acknowledged and enshrined in colleges' human and resource management practices.

Mike Foster, the non-fox hunting MP for Worcester, who is surely in the running for promotion to ministerial office, says the days when part-time lecturers could easily be tagged as "Neanderthals" - as one local chamber of commerce had once allegedly lamented - was outdated. Part-timers, adds Foster - himself a former part-time lecturer at Worcester College of Technology, are at the frontline of the flexible approach to learning that is now both demanded and expected.

The government agrees, and come this September, following extensive consultation, they'll be spelling out in detail the sort of qualifications and routes to achieve them that will be prerequisite to future employment in the sector. A General Lecturers' Council (GLC) may also be set up, striving to replicate the identical professional body (General Teaching Council) just established for schoolteachers.

The intention is that all further education lecturers should eventually have a recognised teaching qualification. It is anticipated that part-timers will be expected to get an intermediate level qualification within two years and a full certificate of education (FE) a year after that.

A DfEE consultation paper published recently on the back of year-long talks between sector leaders and civil servants, declared that most of the part-time staff canvassed about this sort of qualification did not object. But the paper also warned: "Applying the same requirement to part-time lecturers as full-time ones would have the advantage of ensuring that whoever teaches a group of learners has been trained to a consistent professional level. Yet this could also be seen as a barrier to some."

It is a potential dilemma since employment flexibility is one of further education's indisputable hallmarks. "Its ability to draw on a wide range of part-time staff, many of whom work in other professions, is an asset which we want to nurture and protect," promised the paper. "But we also want to ensure that students get the highest quality of teaching. Getting the balance right between high minimum teaching requirements and avoiding them becoming deterrents to participation by would-be lecturers is crucial."

One way round it could be to insist some part-timers pass a different test which concentrates on key teaching skills and pays less attention to wider non-teaching activities.

These imminent reforms will be bedded down by the new Further Education National Training Organisation (Fento). The task has been eased by a new agreement just struck between employers, represented by the Association of Colleges, and the six nationally recognised staff unions on the rights of part-time staff.

Jocelyn Prudence, the association's director of employment services, explains: "Our new agreement with the unions now values part-timers, tries to ensure they should not be devalued and that their status should be improved. This is part of the national drive towards professionalisation for the sector."

A further influence is a new European law that shuffled into existence at the start of this month. The directive states the terms under which part-timers cannot suffer less favourable pay and working conditions. Personnel managers are already trembling when they consider the financial implications for their colleges.

Geoffrey Mead, head of employment law at solicitors Warner Cranson, is an expert who has already read between the lines. He warns: "Since substantially more women than men work part-time, conditions which mean that part-timers are treated less favourably than full-timers could constitute indirect sex discrimination."

Brenda Barber, TUC deputy general secretary, believes the directive will encourage colleges to rethink present employment regimes. It will bring them up to date to suit the new agenda and avoid possible wars of attrition ending up in the courts of law, with few winners other than lawyers.

fields.headline: Things we hate about you
fields.standfirst: Parents have lots of complaints about schools - but it's not so easy to make them
fields.trailText: Parents have lots of complaints about schools - but it's not so easy to make them
fields.body:
Schools where no one answers the phone, where important messages are sent home via pupil post, where changes in uniform are announced without consultation, where the exam results are excellent, but the loos are a health risk. Teachers who smoke in front of children, who are habitually late, who never mark the books, whose comments at parents' evening reveal that they haven't a clue who they are pontificating about...

Parents would like to complain. But it isn't easy, since many schools have no complaints procedure, and a government commitment to require schools to set up systems to deal with complaints has been shelved.

"Saying 'my door is always open' is not the same as having a procedure," says Anna Bradley, director of the National Consumer Council. "Schools are behind other parts of the public sector. The debate everywhere else is about the quality of the procedures, not about whether they should exist at all." In the meantime, parents' helplines are being swamped by a tidal wave of discontent.

The Advisory Centre for Education (ACE) is taking over 6,000 calls a year from concerned parents, with charity helpline Parentline reporting 20% of its calls from parents worried about some aspect of their child's schooling. Concerns range from uniform, exclusion and bullying to problems with admissions and difficulties encountered when children have special needs.

"A major problem is inconsistency," says Parentline's chief executive, Dorit Brown. "School policies on uniform or behaviour aren't followed through - and the schools become very defensive when parents complain."

"Often there is no procedure to follow," says Susan Rees at ACE. "A sign of a very good school is one where complaints are listened to. Too many teachers go straight onto the defensive."

Alison had concerns about two teachers at the West Midlands secondary school her son attended.

"There was no homework being set and he was coming home with unbelievable stories about what happened in lessons." Alison was broadly supportive of the school; her eldest child had done well there. She asked for an appointment to discuss her child's progress. To her horror she found herself discussing the problem with the head of year - one of the teachers she had gone in to complain about. "I just didn't know what to do," she said.

Another parent tried to discuss the format of the parents' evening with the head of a Lancashire school.

"I'd read about a school that offered consultation interviews," he said, "instead of these ridiculous parents' evenings where you stand around all night to see harassed staff for about three minutes. I said I thought the consultation interviews were a good idea and asked if the school had considered them. The head just dismissed the idea - he was condescending and arrogant."

One of the problems faced by parents is the position of power enjoyed by most heads. Carol Rookwood, headteacher of St Island primary school in Kent, banned Harry Potter books from her school, to the disgust of several parents, because she believed they promoted witches and wizards as good rather than evil.

"Parents have the final say on what children read at home," she told reporters, "but I have the final say on what they read at school." So much for the home-school partnership.

And it's a mistake to imagine that complaints are only made about weak, failing schools. Many of the parents contacted by the Guardian were happy with the education their children were receiving and preferred to remain anonymous because they didn't want to attack the school in the press. But all were in agreement that schools needed to do more to address legitimate grievances.

Professor Cedric Cullingford has researched parental attitudes to school and believes that the situation has worsened through the nineties as a result of government reforms. He cites more detailed end-of-term reports as symptomatic of the trend.

"The sheer length and detail of the report puts parents off," he said. "Parents feel disenfranchised by a system that was supposed to make them more powerful. They're no longer welcome in schools because teachers don't have the time to see them."

Some schools appear to have developed a bunker mentality, where criticism from any quarter has to be rejected as a matter of course.

"If they do that to their parents," says Margaret Tulloch from the Campaign for State Education, "they are turning away the people who are their biggest supporters."

A mandatory complaints procedure was included in this year's school standards legislation but, to the disappointment of parents' groups, the government hasn't implemented the relevant provisions. The education department argues that the requirement has been dropped as part of the drive to reduce bureaucracy, but Tulloch believes that schools will eventually be the losers unless they address parental concerns.

"The glib market forces argument was always nonsense," she says. "Parents don't want to vote with their feet - they want their local schools to respond to their children's needs. People want to be listened to, it's something schools need to address."

Parent governors ought to be the ideal candidates to channel concerns, but many heads are vehemently opposed to governors relaying what they describe as "tittle-tattle from the school gates".

Sometimes the governors defend the school at all costs. "In my case," said one parent whose child had been bullied, "the head and the governors clubbed together to deny the problem existed. Legally I suppose they were in the right, morally it was outrageous."

Some observers believe that the legislation wasn't implemented because heads argued that formal procedures would encourage unreasonable complaints.

"There are some members of the public with unreasonable expectations," said the National Consumer Council's Anna Bradley. "But by far the bigger problem lies with low expectations. People think that no one will take any notice of their complaint, that nothing will happen."

The Campaign for State Education argues that a complaints procedure is just the first step.

"It's no good just grafting on a procedure," says Tulloch, "it's about changing attitudes to raising problems." A recent report by the Economic and Social Research Council echoes that view, arguing that there was a need to rid schools of the "deep-seated culture" of deference that stops many parents speaking their minds.

Teachers vs. parents

What teachers say

How are things at home? Any problems there?

I don't see how we can change the system just for your child.

No, in order to opt for German she has to be in the top set in maths.

We sent a message home about this some time ago.

We've always run parents' evening like this.

I can assure you that there's no bullying in this school.

What parents say

He seemed to do so much better with Mrs Johnson.

How long have you been teaching?

No, she doesn't like PE - and neither did I.

Perhaps if the classroom were a little quieter, Sophie would be able to finish her work.

I can't believe that Kevin would have done anything like that.

That's the fifth pencil case she's had stolen this year.

 ACE: 020-7354 8321; ACE exclusion line: 020-7704 9822. Parentline: 080-8800 2222.

 A sample schools complaints procedure can be found on the Rise (Research and Information on State Education Trust) website.

fields.headline: Riding instruction
fields.trailText: Riding instruction
fields.body:
Hello there. Hi. Can I help you?

I was just admiring your fine seat. I beg your pardon?

The way you were sitting on that magnificent beast. Oh, I see. Thank you.

Not at all. I'm something of a hippofile. Yikes! Is it these jodhpurs?

How do you mean? Well... you said something about hippos.

No, no. You wear them to perfection, like a Jilly Cooper cover. Dear me.

Hippofile means lover of horses. Oh I see.

And you obviously like them too. I adore them. I teach riding.

Interesting life. But pretty hard work? Yes. We teach people of all ages, backgrounds and abilities, from amateurs and beginners to skilled professionals. But that's not all.

There's more? Instructors get involved in the schooling of horses, devising training programmes of exercises to break them in and to enable them to respond to a rider's commands.

Must they all ride as well as you? Too kind. No, instructors don't have to be brilliant performers, but must be able to inspire confidence. In addition...

There's more still? As well as teaching, an instructor may be in charge of a number of horses and ponies, and have to water, feed, groom and exercise them, and clean boxes, yards and tack.

Exhausting. It takes stamina and fitness, and being prepared for early morning starts and late evening duties.

What other talents are required? An instructor needs to show patience tolerance and understanding when dealing with both human and equine clients, while maintaining discipline and remaining calm in a crisis. Good communication skills are a must in order to articulate clearly what is expected and to motivate pupils in an appropriate manner.

And where does this all happen? We work in riding schools, competition yards, private stables and pony trekking and riding holiday centres.

Mostly outdoors? Pretty much, and in all weathers, although some centres may have indoor training facilities.

And long days? We tend to work unsociable hours, as people wish to take riding lessons outside the usual working hours.

And you teach everything? Oh, no. The type of teaching an instructor does depends on the level of their instructor qualification. Instruction can cover basics, such as simply mounting a horse correctly, to coaching teams in tactics and strategies for major events and competitions. The British Horse Society (BHS) and the Association of British Riding Schools (ABRS) offer instructor training at various levels.

What do they do? The BHS instructor qualifications range from the Preliminary Teachers Certificate which enables a person to teach basic riding under supervision, to the Instructors Certificate which requires a very high standard of horsemanship and teaching.

And the other? The ABRS qualifications begin with the Initial Teaching Award, enabling the holder to teach at a basic level in riding schools, and progress to the Advanced Teaching Diploma that is designed for candidates who have ridden and taught to a high level.

How do you get these qualifications? There are specific courses designed to specific qualifications. Training often takes place while you're working at stables or riding schools, or out pony trekking.

fields.headline: Drama
fields.trailText: Louisa McLennan takes centre stage
fields.body:
Drama ideas
***
Aimed at: teachers

Listing lesson plans by age group, this is great for dipping into if you need a last-minute idea. It also suggests ways drama can be used in other lessons (such as studying the mask-work of the Ancient Greeks in history).

Scripts and more scripts
****
Aimed at: teachers and pupils

The scripts on-line database provides an excellent collection of free scripts suitable for auditions or use in class. There are few full plays, but if you need snippets, look here. But beware of the "how to annoy your drama teacher" page!

V&A theatre museum
***
Aimed at: everyone

Britain's National Museum of the Performing Arts contains all the key collections on the British stage. This site explains the V&A's role in representing all the live performing arts, including drama, dance, opera, musical theatre, circus, puppetry, music hall and live art. The V&A also holds an online national video archive of stage performances.

London Theatres
***
Aimed at: everyone

It tells what's on when and where in London theatres, and includes smaller shows as well as the big playhouses.

National Youth Theatre
***
Aimed at: older students

Competition for places in the National Youth Theatre has always been tough, but its official site does make the application process less daunting. Find out how to request an audition, what the theatre does, and read reviews of recent productions.

Creative Drama
****
Aimed at: teachers

This primary-coloured page overflows with enthusiasm for school drama with classroom ideas, whole plays for performing and an extensive resource index. Best of the UK drama sites.

The Living Play Book
***
Aimed at: teachers

It describes itself as "the most complete, most up-to-date collection of improv' games on the planet". Although this might be an exaggeration, it does contain useful information, and alphabetical listings make finding new and old drama games easy.

The Costume Page
***
Aimed at: teachers and pupils

This site is packed with presentation ideas for anyone putting on a play. An illustrated history of costume provides both ideas and educational details, as well as contacts for where to order buttons and beads and ready-made outfits. Unfortunately, the buy on-line section lists mostly only US sites.

Drama Guide

****
Aimed at: teachers

Split into well explained warm-ups, cool-downs and time fillers, this site may work best with a class of relatively well-behaved pupils.

Talking to Shakespeare

***
Aimed at: everyone

The best of a selection of "talking to" sites. Readers can question Shakespeare on any aspect of his life and work. Will's answers, which can be quite entertaining, are written by leading experts on his work. This can be useful for homework - pupils could ask, say, whether or not Hamlet was mad. It may also lead to some good advice for a school production.

fields.headline: Nae bovver
fields.standfirst: Eastenders is fuelling the new linguistic imperialism.  John Crace  cocks an ear
fields.trailText: Eastenders is fuelling the new linguistic imperialism. John Crace cocks an ear
fields.body:
Fings ain't wot vey used to be, bruv. New research carried out by Dr Jane Stuart-Smith at Glasgow University suggests that the delicate sounds of the Gorbals are losing out to non-standard southern English, aka estuary. Whether this is much of a loss to the nation's eardrums is a matter of personal prejudice, but for the Scots there can be few things worse than to discover a new form of English cultural imperialism.

Dr Stuart-Smith's research is a more detailed continuation of the work she published last year in Urban Voices, edited by Paul Foulkes and Gerard Docherty. In collaboration with her research assistant Claire Timmins, and statistician Dr Fiona Tweedie, Stuart-Smith found 32 willing Glaswegian guinea-pigs representing a cross-section of age, class and gender and put them through a series of tests, ranging from repeating a list of 100 words to everyday conversation.

What emerged was that traditional consonant sounds, such as the "ch" in loch, and the local pronounciation of milk as "mulk", were on the decline, and that "f" had begun to replace "th" in words like tooth. However, the changes were highly localised.

"This effect is found only in the inner city population sample - the predominantly working class. It is not true in the suburban sample - among mainly middle-class teenagers," says Stuart-Smith. The actual analysis of the findings, while relying heavily on Dat technology, also required some interpretation.

Timmins explains: "There was a marked difference between ad-libbed conversations of the working-class boys in the 13-15 age group and their reading of the list," she says. "When they read out the list, the variance from the Glasgow accent was much more noticeable. We took this to be a sign that they wanted to appear tougher when they read out loud. Similarly the middle-class Kelvinside accents tended to stress the "h" in words such as which and when. We felt that these people were perhaps trying extra hard to sound more Scottish than they really are."

Even allowing for these anomalies, the findings turn the received wisdom of linguistic research on its head. For decades now, it has always been assumed that it was face-to-face contact that brought about changes in language and dialect. If this were true, you would expect the more mobile middle-class groupings who were likely to have been exposed to a greater variety of language to be the first to lose their Scottishness. But the reverse is true, with the working-class kids, many of whom may have only rarely travelled outside Scotland, the most susceptible to outside influences.

Which puts the media - and EastEnders in particular - firmly in the spotlight, though the case remains far from scientifically proven. "The debate about whether the media affects pronunciation is contentious, rather like the debate about violence in the media, and it is a difficult area to research definitively," says Stuart-Smith. "But this is an area we intend to study. That will involve us finding out much more about the people and their TV habits and their degree of contact - if any - with people from southern England."

The idea that language could be influenced by the media may be a surprise to linguists but it certainly won't be to parents whose children have incorporated various bits of Home and Away and Neighbours Strine into their everyday speech without having gone within 10,000 miles of Down Under.

Indeed, in the early 1990s a New Zealand researcher noted the same process in reverse with the increased glottalisation of the dialect. "Pass the budder" had been transformed into "Pass the bu-er".

What may be more of interest is why some programmes are more likely to influence dialect than others. Coronation Street and Brookside are as popular as EastEnders but the Salford and Mersey accents stay put.

Similarly, throughout the 1950s and 1960s all BBC announcers adopted the clipped upper-class sounds of received pronounciation and yet the accent is now only found in isolated pockets of Knightsbridge and the shires. Today, the BBC's pronunciation department only advises on difficult foreign words and presenters are advised to talk in their local dialects. Which ought to preserve language rather than lose it.

Some accents, including Scots, are highly valued for their sense of trustworthiness and mellifluity, but no one has ever bothered to include estuary in either category. Yet estuary it is that marches ever onwards: researchers have noted similar changing dialect patterns to Glasgow in Newcastle, Hull and Derby.

But if Estuary is here to stay, it won't be the first time it has made its presence felt. "In the 14th century, a Londoner wouldn't have been able to understand someone who lived 40 miles outside the city," says John Sutherland, Lord Northcliffe Professor of modern english literature at University College London. "It was eventually Chaucer's English that became the standard." Chaucer, Phil 'n Grant. It's a noble lineage. And shortly to become more noble still. Mike Coles, an RE teacher in London, has just translated the Bible into Cockney rhyming slang. Would you Adam 'n' Eve it?

fields.headline: The devil you know
fields.standfirst: Academic reviewers should not be anonymous, says Les Back
fields.trailText: Academic reviewers should not be anonymous, says Les Back
fields.body:
Rejection is a professional hazard in academic life. It can take the form of a cast out grant application, or a "thanks but no thanks" missive from an academic journal or publisher. But the price of rejection is increasing. Funding of university departments will in large part be determined by the performance of their staff in the Research Assessment Exercise in 2001.

These evaluations are made on the quality of our journal articles, books and the frequency of successful applications for research funding. So getting published and raising research money is increasingly essential in the hothouse of higher education.

Yet the fate of proposals and written work is in large part sealed by people whose names we do not know. They are the anonymous referees whom funding agencies and editorial boards summon to pass expert judgement. But in a world where debates over freedom of information and civil rights are increasingly being connected, can we defend a situation where the fruits of our intellectual labours are decided by nameless judges who are not held accountable for the content of their opinions?

I know many people - myself included - who have poured over a referee's comments for lexical fingerprints, those telltale traces of the reviewer's identity such as references to their own written output, evidence of their pet concerns or a weakness for archaic printer fonts. Negative reviews which damn with faint praise are particularly devastating for a research-grant application. With competition for ESRC grants so high, it only takes one negative review to consign an application to the dustbin.

Defenders of retaining the anonymous reviewing system argue that it allows reviewers to be frank and honest. "If reviewers had to be named it would lead to anodyne and meaninglessly bland assessments," they say. Or, more self-interestedly: "If colleagues knew I had written their review they would never invite me to give conference papers, or to contribute to edited books."

But isn't concealment the worst kind of deceit? "I'd be delighted to go to Rome on an academic freebie, so long as I can keep under wraps that I sabotaged your publishing aspirations." These are weak justifications.

Often editorial boards have to act as the arbiters in this play of personal grudges and tainted judgements. Editors are in the unenviable position of having to decide how much of the brutal detail in the referee's report to disclose. The best try to protect the sometimes fragile confidence of scholars by filtering out their worse excesses. These difficult editorial dilemmas might easily be avoided if the system were more transparent.

My view is simple. If critics do not have the integrity to be accountable for the content of their assessments, they shouldn't put fingers to keyboard. Anonymity has provided a mask behind which petty jealousies, envy, spitefulness, rivalry and intellectual sectarianism has flourished.

My strength of feeling on this issue was sealed when a senior professor of sociology sent me his comments on an article I'd written with John Solomos and Tim Crabbe that he'd refereed. In a scribbled note he explained that he "didn't believe in anonymous reviewing". It has to be said that his comments were fairly trenchant, but I respected him all the more because he did not hide behind the referee's privilege of secrecy. He made me realise that anonymous reviewing is a bankrupt and indefensible practice.

Now when I write a review on applications or paper I follow his example, and send my comments directly to its author(s), and I would encourage others to do so. I've heard it said this would make it harder to find reviewers, particularly for journal submissions. But I think we have to have more backbone. Such transparency might even make reviewing more careful and thoughtful.

But this problem doesn't end with deciding the fate of grant applications and journal submissions; the lack of accountability in criticism is a symptom of a wider syndrome.

Our intellectual culture is sadly lacking an ethics of measured critique. Cheap and vituperative asides creep into the best academic writing. As a result, argument can degenerate all too quickly into name-calling. Years of scholarly endeavour can be dismissed with a few cutting sentences aimed only to bolster their author's credentials and authenticity.

This has produced a situation in which appearing to be a harsh critic - and in teaching the equivalent is being a tough marker - is a prised attribute and evidence of a truly "pumped up" brain. This is little more than a form of intellectual machismo - which can be embraced equally by women and men - so that substantive disagreement and critical dialogue becomes almost a sideshow.

What is centre stage is a "performance of intelligence" in which the commentator is the main attraction. Academic minds might be better trained on understanding the troubled world that lay beyond the gates of the university campus.

 Les Back is acting head of the Centre for Urban and Community Research at Goldsmiths College.

fields.headline: Living in the past
fields.standfirst: It's fun being a Tudor at the weekend, or a Saxon, or an Elizabethan. It also teaches schoolchildren a lot more than books.  Jerome Monahan gets set for battle in the English Civil War
fields.trailText: It's fun being a Tudor at the weekend, or a Saxon, or an Elizabethan. It also teaches schoolchildren a lot more than books. Jerome Monahan gets set for battle in the English Civil War
fields.body:
"Boy, bring me my gloves and give them to me one at a time!" Immediately, seven-year-old Tim Newton breaks off our conversation and heads for the makeshift canvas tent behind him. His place in the pecking order of 17th-century society is clear, and when an officer of Sir William Pennyman's Regiment issues an instruction he knows better than to dawdle. "It is actually fun helping the officers," he says later on, although his mum Debbie admits he cried the first time an order was barked at him.

Tim is one of hundreds of children regularly participating in living history events. This summer, while he enacts camp life during the English Civil War, others like him will be recreating the day-to-day existence of everything from Vikings through Elizabethans to drummer boys in the Confederate Army of the 1860s at numerous events across the country.

It is clear that there has been a big change in recent years with historic recreation societies altering their focus from battlefield action to showing the practicalities of ordinary life lived by our ancestors. It is a shift that has given families and children an important role to play.

"Popular history on television has had a major influence in fuelling the public's fascination with life in the past," says Howard Giles, head of special events for English Heritage. "And so have we, by scheduling an ever-increasing number of living history events at our properties. This year we have planned 1,000 and we do everything we can to ensure the historical accuracy of what's on show."

Another fan of living history is Professor Mick Aston of Bristol University and Channel 4's Time Team: "Anything that gives people a handle on the past has to be worthwhile. There is also a huge amount that academics can learn from those trying to recreate life in the past and having to solve the practical problems that crop up."

There is no doubt that whatever their age, young re-enactors benefit in a wide variety of ways from their commitment to the past.

At 15, Estelle Crump is already a veteran member of the English Civil War Society. "I have been involved since I was 11," she explains, "and what I love about it is the freedom it gives me. I feel safe. I'm surrounded by friends and I enjoy singing songs around the fire late into the night and going to the beer tent. I don't get much sleep, though." According to Estelle, some of the best things flow from having to live in period costume: "It's a tremendous equaliser - when everyone is dressed up you have no idea of backgrounds. I have made friends with people I would never have met otherwise."

"It's an idyllic life for kids," says David Gibson, a major in the 17th Virginia Regiment of the Southern Skirmishers, whose daughter and grandson regularly help to recreate American Civil War camp life and conflict. "Everyone knows them and around the site they can do as they please." This is echoed by 12-year-old Ben Stanley who, as a member of Regia Angloram, spends weekends being a Saxon of the period just before the Norman invasion. "I have a friend and we go off and play all day, climbing trees. We only go back to 'the wic' - our settlement - for a drink."

Ben's casual use of the word "wic" illustrates another bonus of historical recreation for children - they pick up a tremendous amount of knowledge almost without trying. It is hardly surprising, perhaps, given the hours they spend witnessing the arts and crafts of the past and their parents' "in role" responses to the public's questions.

Katherine Goodman is only 10 and already she is used to playing key parts in the 16th-century living history events staged by the Tudor Group. She has just spent nine days as Ursula Washington at Sulgrave Manor in Northamptonshire, enacting daily life there circa 1587 for visiting schools. She is very used to dealing with the public: "I never get embarrassed. If someone laughs it's their problem. Once someone even thought I was battery-powered."

According to Katherine, a lot of the information about the period in schoolbooks is not to be believed. "They are full of lies," she says. "My teacher has an arrangement with me - sometimes she will look at me after she has said something and I will nod and then she knows it's okay."

Surprisingly, Katherine's low opinion of school history is not uncommon among young historical re-enactors. "It's boring," confessed Tim Newton on his return from glove duty. "You have to sit on the carpet and listen." For a broader view Chris Culpin, the director of the School's History Project, pinpoints the lack of scope for empathy in the history curriculum: "Many teachers are doing some very imaginative work but they are forced to concentrate on the diplomatic and the constitutional sides of history. They have so much to get through and there isn't much scope for studying the lives of ordinary people, especially at key stage 3."

But it would be inaccurate to say that the lessons learnt during re-enacting history do not translate into academic curiosity. Get 12-year-old weekend Viking Owain Barry onto the subject of Norse Gods and be prepared for a bewildering outpouring of sagas featuring Loki, Valhalla and the Ragnarök. Meanwhile, Estelle Crump is looking forward to A-level history, but with one proviso: "As a member of a Parliamentarian regiment I am going to have to learn to be more open-minded about the King's cause."

For Estelle, the memory of watching smoke drift across a battlefield at Powderham Castle in Cornwall is among her earliest memories. fields.headline: Lore of the land
fields.standfirst: Folk traditions are often a mix of the strange, mysterious or absurd.  Jerome Monahan digs deep into their origins
fields.trailText: Folk traditions are often a mix of the strange, mysterious or absurd. Jerome Monahan digs deep into their origins
fields.body:
All over Britain strange rituals occur throughout the year. This summer you may see people counting swans, decorating wells or dancing outside pubs with bells on their trousers. Some say these are the activities of crazy people looking for an excuse to dress up in silly clothes or drink too much beer. Supporters say folk traditions provide links to the past and have an important job to do - they give specific groups, communities, even countries, a sense of identity.

In fact, folk tradition and lore do not only belong to other people. They contribute to most of our own lives on a daily basis - they may often seem invisible as we take them for granted.

What does "folk" mean?

One definition of a folk tradition is "informally transmitted culture" - a belief, habit or activity that is picked up rather than deliberately learnt. "Folk" means "people" and so any group regularly repeating an event or activity can be said to be taking part in a folk tradition. Similarly, any story or legend can be called folklore even if it is only retold within a school community or a family.

Where do folk traditions come from?

Some may have roots in pre-Christian, pagan belief while others may date from a particular historic event. In Eyam (pronounced "eem") in Derbyshire, there are good examples of each. At the end of August the local well is "dressed" with flowers, while a separate outdoor church service is held to mark the self-sacrifice of the village during the plague years 1665-6.

The historian, Ronald Hutton, says much British folk tradition is linked to the pattern of the seasons. So spring ceremonies include symbols suggesting rebirth, and summer festivals involve merry-making in the sunlight.

Are they very different from religious festivals?

They can be closely related. Early Christianity took over parts of many beliefs that pre-dated it. Churches were often built on pagan holy sites while pagan celebrations were transformed into Christian holidays. When England became a Protestant country in the 16th century there was pressure to stop these doubtful traditions. In the 1640s and 1650s many kinds of festivity were banned. But some remained or were started up again later and have survived to this day in one shape or another.

Aren't most folk traditions and folklore to do with the countryside?

Inevitably, many are country-based because most people lived there as little as 200 years ago. But cities and towns have a rich folk culture, too, which has often been overlooked. To an outsider, a child collecting coins on behalf of a stuffed "Guy" in November might seem strange but to many it is familiar and unremarkable.

One of the most interesting forms of city folklore is the urban legend. These are often tales of horror and misfortune which always seem to have happened to "a friend of a friend". They arise out of nowhere, are told as if they were true and then vanish again.

Children's sayings, rhymes and games are also a form of folklore. Many go back centuries and take different forms across the UK.

Can folk traditions survive?

It depends what is meant by "survive". Folk culture is not static and timeless. Who is to say that the rules that children create to control Pokemon trading are worth less than more traditional playground songs?

The desire to preserve folk traditions dates back to the late 19th century when historians, musicians and poets began to worry about the effect of rapid industrialisation on ordinary people. They started collecting songs and folklore and even tried to revive old traditions.

Are folk traditions dangerous?

Some can help one group and exclude or intimidate another. Northern Irelan's "marching season" is one example of this - members of the Protestant community insist they have the right to march through Catholic areas despite the uproar this causes.

Activities

 Start a collection of your family sayings and traditions. At school write down games, rhymes and "friend of friend" stories you find.

 Visit the folklore society website at www.folklore-society.com

 Find out about regional festivals and celebrations at www.englishtourism.org.uk or www.visitbritain.com

 For Derbyshire well-dressing ceremonies contact 01246 345777.

 For urban legends try www.urbanlegends.com

 The comedian, Mike Harding, has a site devoted to one of the most mysterious characters of folklore: the Green Man at www.mikeharding.co.uk

 My thanks to Caroline Oates of the Folklore Society.

fields.headline: Barbecue sauce
fields.standfirst: Donald Hiscock  gets a flame-grilling at the annual barbecue
fields.trailText: Donald Hiscock gets a flame-grilling at the annual barbecue
fields.body:
We had our annual staff barbecue last night. It was also a big leaving do, for some were retiring after years of noble service to education through periods of change and transition. Or so the Principal said in his address.

The truth is, there wasn't much nobility on the patio outside the science block. You would think that a string of fairy lights, floating candles and a medley of Burt Bacharach numbers would be enough to induce bonhomie in any social gathering. But things were far from mellow after a term of restructuring consultations.

We experienced barbecue rage before the evening was half underway. My mate Colin from maths tore up his paper plate in disgust when he finally reached the front of the food queue to discover the chicken had run out.

"What do you mean breasts are off?" demanded Colin. "Got any legs then?"

"No chicken left. Can do you a burger," said Deirdre from art.

"You can stick your sodding burger," shouted Colin. He stormed off to vent his anger on a bowl of pasta salad.

Workplace stress is a serious business. Last night's event was intended to take our minds off the rivalries and bitterness that an academic year of working together can induce. We failed to meet our target on that count then.

Apart from those retiring to their cottages in Calvados some were opting for a career change. One person was taking out a loan to finance her dotcom dried flower business, while another colleague was about to breed tortoises full-time.

There was plenty of lewd heckling when Deirdre from art stood up to receive the obligatory college paperweight and something shaped like a cucumber from her head of faculty. Deirdre is known for her video installations involving scantily clad men tied to deck chairs with chains, ropes and other nautical paraphernalia.

"Is it always like this?" asked recently appointed Administration Manager, Murray Whelk. "We haven't got to the best bit yet," I replied.

The best bit comes with the final speech reserved for the longest serving member of staff. For several years this honour has gone to Ted Ledbury. According to the management Ted officially retired five years ago. But he always gets re-hired come September, only to moan and curse his way through another year of educational initiatives.

Like the proverbial swallows Ted Ledbury's retirement marks the start of summer. It's just a pity that he never turns up for the presentation. He does actually turn up for the food. He is always first in the queue with his own oversized dinner plate. But when it comes to the "And so to Ted..." he is nowhere to be seen. Five years ago he was given a framed aerial photograph of the college and an inscribed fruit bowl. Lately, whichever principal is in post holds up two hundred Benson and Hedges and a litre of scotch until someone offers to pass them on to Ted.

There's nothing like a little bit of predictability in an uncertain world. We had a thoroughly miserable time. But then we did last year, and the year before that. I dare say it won't be long before we are all eagerly awaiting next year's gathering. And I hope Ted can make it as well.

fields.headline: Level playing field?
fields.standfirst: Donald MacLeod  and Lee Elliot Major  on Oxford's move to transparency
fields.trailText: Oxford colleges are to publish background details of students and unsuccessful applicants for the first time in the wake of the Laura Spence controversy.
fields.byline: Donald MacLeod  and Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
Oxford colleges are to publish background details of students and unsuccessful applicants for the first time in the wake of the Laura Spence controversy.

Colin Lucas, the university's vice-chancellor, made the concession in his evidence to the Commons select committee investigating higher education, ending years of fierce resistance by the colleges. Although university-wide figures on the numbers of state and independent school applicants is available, the colleges control their own admissions and evidence from Cambridge shows wide variation in how successful they are in attracting and admitting pupils from state schools and FE colleges.

John Grogan, vice chair of the all-party university group, said the concession would have "dramatic consequences". Colleges would be encouraged to adopt best practice: "Information is power, and the independent sector has long been assiduous in gathering as much data as possible about the admissions patterns of different colleges in order to steer their applicants towards the path of least resistance. A more level playing field is now in prospect." He hoped Cambridge colleges would follow suit.

He pointed out that at Cambridge King's College now had an 80% intake from state schools while Clare College had introduced a points system which took account of the average A-level pass rate at applicants' schools, which benefited state-school candidates.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, hinted that he had won considerable extra funding from the Treasury for access schemes and summer schools to encourage a wider range of young people to break into elite universities. Speaking at a summer school at St Hugh's College, Oxford, he said he wanted to draw a line under the Laura Spence controversy.

Anxieties were fuelled by Chancellor Gordon Brown when he declared that it was scandalous that a comprehensive pupil with outstanding GCSEs had been rejected by Oxford but given a scholarship place at Harvard. Brown acknowledged Oxford's attempts to open up to all talents. And new figures show Oxford is becoming slightly less socially exclusive but Cambridge is becoming more so.

At a seminar organised by Peter Lampl's Sutton Trust for academics and MPs, Marlyn McGrath Lewis, Harvard's director of admissions, outlined the steps the university took to boost the number of applications. Whereas Oxford has one schools liaison officer and a number of ad hoc schemes, Harvard has an admissions budget of $9m and a staff of 19 recruiters scouring the US for talent. An annual mail shot of 53,000 letters goes out to students who do well in national tests. As a result Harvard has 11 applicants for each place, while Oxford has only three.

The lecturers' union Natfhe, however, pointed out that despite its scholarships Harvard is not in fact socially inclusive and accepts half the proportion of black and Hispanic students in the American population.

And as universities waited for the results of the government's spending review today, David Triesman, general secretary of the Association of University Teachers, said wider access depended on proper funding: "Properly funded universities will be able to make sure they take students from all parts of our society, not just students from rich families. But if universities are deprived of public money, they will be forced to look for money wherever they can find it.

"Giving money to universities isn't an alternative to giving money to schools. You have to do both. If you improve state schools as the government wants to do, it will go for nothing if the top universities still take half their students from among the 7% of the population which goes to fee-charging schools."

Tomorrow the Committee of Vice-chancellors and Principals will stress to the Commons education committee that the access debate should encompass all universities, not just the research elite. "Access is an issue for the whole academic sector, not just Oxford and Cambridge," said Dr Geoffrey Copland, vice-chancellor of the University of Westminster. "It is an issue which the whole sector has been working on for some time now, and any new money for access initiatives is needed for all universities."

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.trailText: The summer holidays would be a great opportunity to encourage my children to try out something new and different. Any ideas?
fields.body:
With the summer holidays coming up, I think it would be a great opportunity to encourage my children to try out something new and different - something that would be fun and enjoyable, but could perhaps lead them into acquiring a new hobby or interest. Any ideas?

Many parents/carers will soon be faced with the annual cries of "I'm bored", and "I don't want to play outside". But help is at hand for those fortunate enough to have internet access - either at home or in a cybercafe.

Planit4kids.com is a one-stop destination for everyone searching for ideas on how to entertain their children.

For those without access, try the local library, which supplies all kinds of information. Local newspapers often publish a special children's supplement on activities.

Many organisations offer all the thrills of a summer camp, but on a non-residential basis. With sites all around England, Camp Beaumont (020-7922 1234) offers Playtime for 3- to 4-year-olds, where they can do anything from acting to roller-skating to sand play. Mini Activity Magic for 5-7s includes archery, swimming, and trampolining. Mini Activity Mania is for 8-11s, offering seven different activities a day. For the older age range, the Teen Club is a chance to make new friends with activities like basketball, and snorkelling, volleyball and arts and crafts.

Most local leisure centres run varied sporting programmes, offering tennis lessons, kayak taster sessions or football coaching. And for those into playing, composing, performing and listening to music, Musicale (01582 460978) offers non-residential courses across England for 5-18s.

You might want to encourage your little dears to attend a cookery class. Solihull College (0121- 678 7141) offers children's courses for youngsters aged 7 and over. Pre-booking advisable.

For those lucky enough to live in Hale, Cheshire (0161-929 6886), a visit to Colour Me Mine, a craft cafe, promises the "perfect place to relax, enjoy a cappuccino, and indulge your creative urges". Here, there are 400 ready-to-paint ceramic, terracotta, glass, mosaic and wooden pieces to paint and glaze. Adults can stay, too!

Whether or not you're able to take a trip to Europe this year, the summer months can be an excellent time for 3- to 11-year-olds to benefit from language clubs in French, Italian and German run by Le Club Français all over the UK. The teaching is informal, with drama, crafts, role-play and plenty of lively games. Ring 01962 714036 to find your nearest club.

Many libraries may follow the example of Barry library in Glamorgan (01446 735722) which is running a special computer zone for children to develop their IT skills on PCs. Parents/carers are allowed to try the games too. Entry is free and children are supervised throughout.

Budding thespians are spoilt for choice, with many theatres running summer schools/clubs. For example, at the Bull Theatre in Barnet (020-8449 0048) a two-week project at the beginning of August will allow children of 11 years or over to learn about theatre, movement, circus and acrobatic skills.

A visit to the Soho House Museum in Handsworth, Birmingham (August 2) is a chance to make and take home your own balloon. A week later a craft session based on the "Connecting Threads" exhibition at the museum will be led by the textile artist Debi Keyte. Both activities are free with admission to Soho House. Bambi fans can see the original at the Ashton Court Estate at Long Ashton, Bristol (0117 963 9174) where a deer-feeding walk for children will be led by the estate's deer-keeper on August 1. Country fairs/festivals are generally run in July or August, weather permitting, and can be a fun day out as well as prompting an interest in the crafts and skills on display.

Youngsters aged 9-11 are challenged to improve their survival skills at Westonbirt Arboretum, in Gloucestershire (01666 880220) on August 1. Children will learn how to build a den - if such tuition is needed! - and how to follow and lay their own trails in the woods.
