fields.headline: Designs on women
fields.standfirst: Emma Powell and  Roshni Patel  check out the opportunities for girls in engineering
fields.trailText: Emma Powell and Roshni Patel check out the opportunities for girls in engineering
fields.body:
Should more girls carve out careers in the male-dominated engineering industry? Twenty British sixth-form girls recently spent a week in Finland, where they were spearheading a new initiative to attract more women graduates into the engineering profession.

The girls spent their week at Oulu University, gaining an insight into the variety and international scope of engineering. Women account for just 5% of professional engineers, despite making up 45% of the UK workforce.

During their stay they visited the headquarters of Nokia, Finland's biggest engineering company and the world's biggest maker of mobile phones. The new initiative, Insight 2000, has been launched by Emta, the national training organisation for engineering, to encourage more sixth-form girls to take up engineering at university and help to end the traditional male dominance of the industry. A further 500 maths and science A-level students are attending residential courses throughout the UK this summer, with women engineers from industry as group leaders.

Emma Powell

"I am studying maths, chemistry and physics A levels at Peter Symonds College in Winchester. I had been trying to decide which degree to study, with ideas ranging from computer or electronic engineering to meteorology! My careers adviser suggested that I went on an Insight course to help me decide whether I'd like to pursue an engineering career.

"The course was organised by the Smallpeice Trust and Emta. Finland was chosen for the course because of its dedication to modern technology. I found the trip interesting not only for this but also culturally, as we were each paired with a Finnish girl.

"The course consisted of lectures on subjects including teamwork, creative design, engineering and presentation skills. We were also given mini projects to emphasise points raised in the lectures, and to gain experience working as a team.

"The Nokia site we visited was involved mainly in research, development and production of base units - they receive the microwaves from your phone and convert them into electrical signals. Two women, Virpi and Auli, made a presentation about their jobs and career paths. I am now strongly considering a degree in electronic or computer systems engineering."

Roshni Patel

"Making the choice of course at university can be extremely difficult; the range of subjects is immense. The task ahead seemed daunting, bound only by the limits of a mathematics or physics-related option, as I am taking A levels in maths, further maths, physics, French and general studies.

"Engineering seemed a feasible area, as did computing, but I had no first-hand experience of what these involved. Insight promises to give girls in their first year of A levels a view of engineering at degree level and as a profession, and this appeared to be exactly what I needed.

"The course took place in Oulu, a place characterised by a strong presence of high-technology industries. We gained information on the separate branches of engineering, and which would suit us as individuals. A highlight was internet page production, which particularly appeals to me.

"For me the most rewarding part was a visit to a Nokia plant. Three female employees made presentations. We learnt about the different routes through higher education leading to a career in telecommunications, the roles played by specific engineers in research, design and production, the theory behind mobile phone technology, and job opportunities with Nokia. We also got a view of the way of life in Finland.

"I have now decided to apply to study maths and computer science. A career in telecommunications is also very appealing. Any girl who has a chance to attend such a course should embrace it."

fields.headline: By the right, get studying
fields.standfirst: Soldiers are in the front line of lifelong learning
fields.trailText: Soldiers are in the front line of lifelong learning
fields.body:
Of all the gin-joints in all the towns in all the world... Life seldom turns out as you imagined it to be. Take the army. Switch on any of the various TV docusoaps on the paras/ new recruits/ women recruits/ SAS/ marines that fill the prime-time slots and you will see men and women being put through a range of hideous ordeals, while being shouted at by officers. Listen to the Ministry of Defence and you will hear how the armed services should start recruiting ex-cons to make up the shortfall in numbers. Whichever way you cut it, the army hardly looks an attractive option.

So it may come as a shock to find out that while other organisations make a great show of paying lip service to lifelong learning, the army has grabbed the idea by the throat and this September launches its Personal Development Record (PDR). This a chunky ring-binder containing details of academic and professional qualifications, personal and military records, reports and assessments, which will be given to all ranks and cap badges of the 100,000 regulars and 40,000 territorials.

"It's not rocket science," says Brigadier Patricia Purves, director of educational and training services (army). "Other organisations have developed similar documents and we have adapted their best bits to suit our purposes. The army has always kept records of its soldiers' careers, but this is the first time we have produced something structured for soldiers to keep for themselves.

"The idea is that all ranks start to take more responsibility for their own careers. We are hoping that they will begin to see the connections between the various training courses they have already undertaken and to think about what they want to do next. There is also a specialist section where soldiers can see what courses they ought to have done at various points in their career, so they can see a clear path of what they need to do to get promotion. We have also spelt out the civilian equivalents of their army training courses. For instance, a sapper in the Royal Engineers would achieve at least two NVQ passes during his training."

Most soldiers only stay in the army for a limited period. The average time served ranges from between four and 12 years, and Brigadier Purves says this is just how it should be. "We want people to stay as long as possible," she says, "but most of the work is a young person's job. So when recruits join we always tell them they will leave one day and they will do so at an age when they need to find another career. This makes their education and training critical for rejoining civilian life."

The focus on education is not just fulfilling a remit to return capable, skilled adults to civvy street but an active attempt to retain the soldiers they have: 15,000 recruits may join the army each year, but at least that many leave, some of whom the army would have preferred to keep. In a break with conventional military wisdom, which states that educating soldiers drives them out of the army, the £1.7m PDR scheme is predicated on the notion that learning will encourage them to stay.

This hasn't always been that easy. The itinerant lifestyle and bizarre funding procedures have prevented many soldiers from taking part in external educational courses, even though the long hours of downtime in overseas areas, such as Kosovo, make these postings an ideal opportunity to learn. The army hopes that its new online deal with Ufi (former university for industry) together with the new learning credits scheme, will go a long way to remedying this situation.

Which is not to say everyone will want to take advantage of it. "Some people don't join the army to go back to reading and writing," says Lieutenant Colonel Ian Tritton of the Royal Welsh Fusiliers, "and we're certainly not going to force them to. But our aim is for those who want to learn to have every opportunity to do so. And our trials suggest that the PDR is an important step in the right direction."

fields.headline: Houses and homes
fields.standfirst: Some of the best stories have been around for several years...
fields.trailText: Some of the best stories have been around for several years...
fields.body:
One of my testers recently informed me that his best friend lived in a flat. "S'not a flat! It's my home !" retorted the friend. Interesting stuff, I thought. I set off to hunt down books about homes and houses - and found that some of the best stories have been around for several years.

My first find was Knock, Knock! Who's There? by the wonderful Rose Impey (Orchard, £3.99). This is a bargain - two new retellings for the price of one. Little Frisky Mouse is most generous in the way she shares her little house - but Rumbling-Bumbling Bear is just too big.

Hare has problems too; no one is brave enough to help when a squatter moves in. It's ideal for early readers - clear print, lots of repetition, brilliant black and white pictures by Louise Voce - but don't miss out on this book's potential for the younger set. Read it out loud - the language is fabulous; no one could possibly resist joining in.

Michael Rosen's This is Our House (Walker, £4.99) also features a cardboard box - but this one is inhabited by George, who wants it all for himself. Bob Graham's subtly humorous pictures pull the reader right into the story by using colour to focus the attention on the immediate action; the background is monotone. Don't ignore anything, though - spot Luther playing with his jumbo jet long before it crash lands - and check out the back cover. Houses are much happier places if you all work together...

Then we go from cardboard houses to the real sort with front doors that a little boy can slam bang! - leaving himself on the inside and his mother on the outside. That's Alfie Gets In First by Shirley Hughes (Red Fox, £3.99), which although originally published in 1981 still entrances small children and makes adults smile wryly - been there, done that.

Harry's Home (Orchard, £4.99), by Catherine and Laurence Anholt, is gently perceptive with pictures stuffed full of glorious detail. Harry lives in the city, but now he's old enough to go and stay with Grandad on his own.

They take a bus, a train, a boat, a bus, and a taxi - and finally arrive at Grandad's farmhouse. It's all very strange and different; Harry isn't certain about it at first, just as Grandad isn't sure about the city. This is an ideal introduction to the idea that there's more than one way of living and it's fun to go and see; home will be safely waiting for you.

In Over in the Grasslands (Macmillan, £4.99), Anna Wilson has taken the old rhyme "Over in the grasslands in the heat of the sun, Lived an old mother rhino and her little rhino one" and given it a fresh feel with a starry cast including jackals and warthogs, all painted in sparkling colour by Alison Bartlett. My younger testers chortled at every single picture and demanded several re-readings; they are now experts about bees living in beehives and eagles in nests.

Finally there's The Visitors Who Came to Stay (Walker, £9.99), written by Annalena McAfee with illustrations by Anthony Browne. This is a new edition, even more breathtakingly beautiful than the1984 version. Katie, living by the sea, resents the intrusion of Dad's friend Mary and her son Sean into her neat and tidy home.

It's a pleasantly told story, but Anthony Browne's extraordinary pictures present such strong visual metaphors that any imaginative child will understand Katie's feelings without reading a word - and, what's more, will understand more about Katie than she does herself. The emotions run very deep - but at the same time there's a wicked sense of humour. Find the rubber plant.

fields.headline: Abuse of power
fields.standfirst: Bullying still a big problem for college staff
fields.trailText: Bullying still a big problem for college staff
fields.body:
Six out of 10 college lecturers are victims of bullying, usually at the hands of superiors, says a new report.

Financial pressures, funding cuts and organisational changes are the most common of the reasons identified for this bullying, according to the survey by the lecturers' union, Natfhe.

The extent of the problem appears marginally worse than similar research revealed three years ago. But things are now likely to improve because of a joint agreement to address bullying between unions and the Association of Colleges, said the Natfhe general secretary, Paul Mackney.

The new report, compiled from questionnaire returns, shows that bullying most frequently took the form of criticism, power abuse and withholding information.

Criticism becomes bullying when it is delivered in inappropriate situations, for instance in front of colleagues or a class of students, or when no chance is given to respond, says Mackney.

A third of victims reported sleeping difficulties as a result of their treatment. A quarter said their self-esteem had been seriously dented.

One in five said their bullying was so bad they were considering leaving their jobs.

Nearly half of the lecturers in the survey reported the problems, either to their union, colleagues and managers, or to close family and friends. But very few said they felt confident enough to take the issue up with their personnel department.

Christina Savva, researcher and author of the report, said: "The main concerns lecturers had were to do with a lack of respect and trust, the feelings of vulnerability that come from being bullied, and fear of being undermined in public by one's colleagues or employers.

"It is vital that institutions address the issue with clear written policies, more support groups, and training."

Complaints by the bullied to their institutions triggered a variety of responses. But, notes Savva, "the response that stands out the most was 'nothing' was done at all."

Barely one in 10 of the lecturers said that their institutions had a specific anti-bullying policy. A fifth said their institutions had a policy on harassment and another fifth said they didn't know what theirs had.

Natfhe officials view the report as timely in coinciding with formal complaints about staff harassment and workplace bullying against a number of colleges and universities, including Basildon college, East Yorkshire college and the Upper Bann Institute in Northern Ireland.

Natfhe sent out questionnaires to 2,400 members and 249 valid responses were returned, a response rate of 10.3%. The questionnaires were backed up with phone interviews.

Most of those who replied to the survey were in the 41 to 55 age band. Nine out of 10 were white. Three-quarters of them worked in colleges.

"Bullying has been endemic in the college system," says Mackney. "It's been driven by the pursuit of targets, which were often unachievable and certainly underfunded."

He said he was hopeful that the new agreement with employers nationally would successfully address problems in colleges where bullying is not endemic.

Where it has been endemic, Mackney says, action has been needed from the Further Education Funding Council. "We hope to reach an understanding of the problem with the new Learning and Skills regime."

"Bullying has been endemic in the college system," says Mackney. "It's been driven by the pursuit of targets, which were often unachievable and certainly underfunded." He said he was hopeful that the new agreement with employers nationally would successfully address problems in colleges where bullying is not endemic. Where it has been endemic, Mackney says, action has been needed from the Further Education Funding Council. "We hope to reach an understanding of the problem with the new Learning and Skills regime."

fields.headline: Chair of nails
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston sees a simple invention for easing a deadly third-world agony
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston sees a simple invention for easing a deadly third-world agony
fields.body:
Here's a shocking statistic you probably won't have heard. In Mexico, 4% of people who are wheelchair-bound die every year from pressure sores and ulcers.

What sets Clyde Ramkissoon apart from most is that he has decided to find a solution to this awful problem. And he has done it during a busy year as a further education student on an access course to get him to university.

His solution - a "pressure mapping" chair - involves a few pieces of wood, some foam, and 500 or so ordinary household nails, materials he knows will be affordable in developing countries.

With them, Clyde, 35, who has spent his adult life in humanitarian work with the disabled, thinks he has invented an inexpensive device which will relieve much suffering and prevent needless deaths around the world, and can be easily made in poorer countries with materials to hand.

It is a beautifully simple idea. The nails are placed a centimetre apart, head upwards, in the seat of the chair. They are not rigid but can move up and down.

"A person with a hip problem, for instance, which causes them to sit more to one side than the other would leave contours of their pressure points in the nails.

"You can see exactly how much pressure is being applied and where."

A cushion can then be fashioned to compensate for and correct the imbalances causing the problems.

Clyde decided to design the chair as the project required for his access course at Hammersmith & West London college, from where he goes in October to do a BSc in prosthetics and orthotics at Salford university.

Before starting the access course last September, he had spent a few months in Mexico where he heard the statistic quoted at the top of this piece.

"Pressure sores and ulcers are particular problems for people in wheelchairs all over the developing world," he says.

"It can take as little as five hours sitting in a chair for a pressure sore to start. This is exacerbated by climate and lack of means for tackling it in developing countries."

He took his idea to the Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital, Edgware. Doctors in the spinal injury unit were impressed. He worked with them and biomedical engineers at the hospital.

"An accurate pressure-mapping device used in developed countries costs around £15,000.

"The version we've produced costs about £50 and is just as accurate."

Now he wants to raise a little cash to take his device to Mexico in August for field trials and to get feedback from patients and technicians there.

"I just need a ticket to get me there."

Clyde, who was born in Trinidad, began his career working with his brother, a Roman Catholic priest, Fr Gregory Ramkissoon, who runs the Mustard Seed Communities, organisations for physically and mentally handicapped adults and children in Kingston, Jamaica.

He subsequently worked in Africa, Asia and the Middle East for the French humanitarian outfit Handicap International.

Once his chair is established he aims to create a wheelchair which will cope with the uneven terrain and steep hills in a place like Nepal, and which can be constructed out of materials to hand in developing countries.

"Bits of bicycles and pieces of wood, mainly."

webTitle: In brief and the latest casting news

fields.headline: In brief and the latest casting news
fields.standfirst: Gibson's Patriot meets with chilly UK reception, why Keanu mkes a convincing killer, film-makers turn once more to Marvel comics, Michael J Fox swears the oath of allegiance and who'll be spicing up the Harry  Potter film
fields.trailText: Gibson's Patriot meets with chilly UK reception, why Keanu mkes a convincing killer, film-makers turn once more to Marvel comics, Michael J Fox swears the oath of allegiance and who'll be spicing up the Harry Potter film
fields.body:
The Mel Gibson epic The Patriot, has got off to a dismal start at the UK box-office. In its opening weekend, the film took just £1m. Other summer extravaganzas Gladiator and Mission: Impossible 2 both made around four times as much. "The Patriot should have been one of the big summer films in the UK as well as elsewhere,'' said Mary Scott, box-office editor for industry magazine Screen International, "but it is thought damning reviews and the anti-English bias had a major influence on revenue. "It is typical Hollywood ego to just go ahead and make something they think everyone will see and like regardless," she commented.

 Keanu Reeves' co-star Ernie Hudson apparently had serious doubts over the star's ability to play a serial killer in the forthcoming Driven because he is so "nice". Reeves plays a brutal serial killer, while James Spader and Marisa Tomei are FBI agents on his trail. Hudson says, "At first I thought that I didn't know if Keanu could do it. But after some time on set I realised he would be just fine. He is very convincing because he is like all those guys on the news. People think they are really nice and people trust him and they have no idea how deadly this guy is until it is too late. It is a really tense movie."

 It looks likely that another Marvel Comics character, Daredevil, will be the next comic-book hero to hit the big screen. Hot on the heels of the X-Men adaptation, directors are queuing up to work on a project involving America's crimson-clad crime fighter. Shaft director, John Singleton, a devoted comic book fan, and Mark Steven Johnson, who is to write the screenplay, have said they would both love to take the director's chair.

 Canadian-born Michael J. Fox has followed in the footsteps of the Welsh-born Anthony Hopkins and become an American citizen. The actor, who recently left his hit TV show Spin City to campaign for Parkinson's Disease, from which he suffers, has been "greatly bothered" by living in America but not being able to vote. Fox has lived in Atlanta for 20 years, and whose wife and children are all American citizens.

 Rob Legato will be the visual effects supervisor for the Harry Potter film. Legato, best known for his work on Titanic, is currently in England preparing for the film. According to Mothership website, we can look forward to a high-spirited game of flying broomsticks as well as a particularly evil Voldemort (who will be played by Tim Roth). The film, scheduled for release in November 2001, has yet to cast a lead.

 Sandra Bullock's next role will be a woman trapped in an abusive relationship. Bullock, currently filming the beauty pageant adventure Miss Congeniality, is thought to be linking up with producer, Irin Winkler, who she worked with on The Net, in a film called Enough.

fields.headline: Brave new world
fields.standfirst:
On the eve of the biggest shake-up in post-16 education for decades, Will Woodward examines the implications of Curriculum 2000 for students, teachers and parents
The new exams
fields.trailText: On the eve of the biggest shake-up in post-16 education for decades, Will Woodward examines the implications of Curriculum 2000 for students, teachers and parents
fields.body:
They are ready, more or less, but that isn't to say they are not nervous. There are not many school days left before Curriculum 2000, the biggest shake-up in post-16 education since the 1950s, is reality for pupils, teachers and parents.

The climb from GCSE to A levels, generally regarded as the most difficult step up in a pupil's academic career, will be negotiated differently from now on, with more stops on the way. Most sixth-formers will do AS levels in their first year and most will do four subjects rather than three.

AS levels, so teachers say, are recognisably easier than the old A level. "I've heard people say it will be like the old O level," said Helen Neal, head of sixth form at Thurston Community School in the Suffolk town of Bury St Edmunds. Her colleague, head of history Phil Walden, says: "The AS is a better bridge between the GCSE and A level. The leap between GCSE and A level was just much too big for some students."

But then A2, the second year of the A-level course, may even be harder than the old A level. Potentially the big educational leap will come between lower and upper sixth, rather than year 11 and lower sixth.

Most students will drop one subject after AS level and take three forward to complete the full A level. Though they will be marked separately, officials are at some pains to stress that A2 won't be a qualification in its own right. There will be, hopes the government, depth with extra breadth.

And variety: a new vocational A level will be offered alongside traditional A levels; a "key skills" course designed to improve employability; and soon Advanced Extension Awards for the very brightest students and free-standing mathematics units.

Schools are mostly behaving as the government intended. According to a survey by the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service, 83% of sixth-form students at nearly 2,000 schools and colleges will be taking four AS levels; 12% will take five and less than 5% will take three or fewer. Some 93% are expected to move on to complete three A levels in the second year.

But as the Guardian showed recently, there are signs of an emerging class barrier when it comes to the other qualifications, with vocational A levels and key skills more popular in comprehensives than grammar and independent schools.

"There's still a great deal of uncertainty about key skills," says John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association. About a quarter of schools will teach key skills as a separate qualification in its own right, but they are also expected to be taught through the other courses. There have been problems injecting them into the A-level history and English courses.

At Thurston, a big, 380-strong sixth form, they are adapting to the new climate. They will be running 20 AS levels in September including two new ones, PE and politics, and five vocational A levels.

"Students will have greater choice as to what they want to do, they are not going to be narrowed down," says Helen Neal. "Everybody will be doing key skills and that will definitely help later on with their employability."

The school is encouraging students who are doing a mixture of A levels but who want to do one science to take the science vocational A level rather than specialise in biology, physics or chemistry.

Some students are taking vocational business alongside AS communication studies; other popular choices include health and social care (vocational) with biology (AS), business (vocational) and maths (AS), leisure and recreation (vocational) and PE (A). But the school, where pupils regularly mix disciplines at A level - common combinations include biology, chemistry and history or physics, chemistry and English - is already used to cutting across the arts/science divide.

Using a computer, they have organised a timetable where only about "10 or 12" students are not doing exactly what they chose, though it might be more tricky when their choices change again - by as much as 50%, Neal says - once the GCSE results come in and the timetable is fixed. The timetable will be fuller, with 24 out of 30 periods for most students taken up with lessons, rather than the current 18. Neal fears interest in community and voluntary work, which the school encourages, will drop off.

Thurston will probably hold most of the AS exams in the summer term, and split the A2 exams, holding them in January and June and lessening the stress of the traditional A-level season. A small number of independent schools are reportedly keeping it going, with knobs on, by holding all a pupil's AS and A2 exams at the same time at the end of two years' study.

Generally there are concerns about whether the extra breadth hoped for by the government will be realised. Dunford says the signs are that the popular fourth AS subjects are not maths or foreign languages, as ministers would hope, but media studies, psychology and sociology. "It's increasing breadth but it's not increasing the wider study at an advanced level the country really needs."

And even for the most willing schools, there have been problems. The course specifications have come very late. Phil Walden only received the final AS history syllabus in March, though it was little different from the draft in December that was delayed by wrangling. "I didn't think the three-month wait was really worth it." He is unhappy that some of the original source work he was able to do in the old A-level course is not included.

Partly because of the delay, Walden says, publishers haven't produced properly tailored books. "We are going to have a real dilemma on what we should spend or whether we should spend it all." In Neal's subject, chemistry, a course that once required just one main textbook per pupil will now require two - a £13 book for AS and a £25 one for A2.

The government has given £19m from the standards fund for staff training in the new syllabus, of which Thurston got £10,000 worth of "very useful" help from Suffolk advisers. Ministers also said £35m of the money given to schools through local authorities was to support the switch to Curriculum 2000, but since that was swallowed up in the general school budget, Thurston hardly noticed it. Some schools have found that they are spending their slice of Gordon Brown's extra £1bn for schools.

But to many in the system, what will matter most about Curriculum 2000 is what the universities think of it. That in turn will have a huge impact on what courses students decide to do at 16.

UCAS has produced a detailed briefing on the new qualifications, urging universities to decide their view of them and publish them quickly. "One of the difficulties encountered with any major change relating to progression routes to HE is a tendency for a 'vicious circle' to emerge: pre-HE providers wait for signals from HE; HE finds difficulty in committing itself until it knows the intentions of the pre-HE sector," it said.

Universities should "establish a flexible admissions policy to deal with a more mixed economy" of post-16 qualifications, and "grasp the nettle of responding positively to a variety of different profiles".

But Dunford says the universities are responding "far too slowly", that only 20 universities have so far made their intentions known, and the flexibility has been limited. The new UCAS "tariff", giving points for grades in the new qualifications, is so far being ignored by the traditional universities, who though they will take other qualifications into account, are still insisting on three good A levels. But Oxford, for instance, is encouraging applicants to offer a contrasting subject among their fourth AS level.

Few if any universities will make key skills an entrance requirement in the medium term. AS-level results, for instance, produced before applications to university, will provide a powerful guide to admissions tutors, but universities are treating them warily. "It's clearly going to take a few years to settle down," says Dunford. And although it is no consolation to those students embarking on the climb, it will be fascinating to see how the route pans out.

 UCAS
 See also individual university websites for admissions policies.

fields.headline: The new exams
fields.trailText: Will Woodward introduces the new qualifications
fields.body:
A level

Instead of? The old A level.

What is it? The A level is in effect being split into two halves. The first half, AS (Advanced Subsidiary); and the second, A2.

The AS is a qualification in its own right, but the A2 is not. To obtain a new A level, both AS and A2 will have to be completed.

Though AS and A2 will have three units each, the A2 will be more demanding than the AS. AS will be more "accessible".

How will it work? Sixth-formers will normally do four AS levels in their lower sixth and drop to three A2s in their upper sixth.

Advanced Extension Award

Instead of? The Special Paper.

What is it? AEAs will be the last part of the "suite" of world-class tests available at nine, 13 and 18, designed to stretch the most able students and help differentiate between students with a high proportion of As at A level. They are intended to be based on the same curriculum content as the corresponding A level and be accessible to all able students from whichever school and college.

How will it work? Trials are being held now and they will come on stream from 2002.

Vocational A level

Instead of? Advanced GNVQ.

What is it? There will be three versions available: an advanced subsidiary vocational certificate - three units; a vocational A level - six units, and a vocational A level (double award) - 12 units. Major changes to old GNVQ include units written in clearer language and new systems of moderation and assessment.

How will it work? The six-unit vocational A level is expected to be the most common. Will be taken in many cases alongside traditional A levels. The 12-unit qualification will have double-linked grades, ie AA, AB, BB, BC etc. The three-unit qualification will only be available in a limited number of areas - business, engineering, health and social care, and ICT.

Key Skills

Instead of? It's a completely new qualification.

What is it? Qualifications in application of number; communication; and information technology will be available from autumn 2000.

Other key skills outlined by the government include improving own learning and performance; problem-solving; working with others.

How will it work? Some students may take these as separate qualifications; some may develop them in A-level courses. Grades will run from levels 1-5; achievement likely to be at level 2 or 3 for entry into higher education.

Free Standing Mathematics Units

Instead of? It's completely new.

What is it? Separate units of maths courses. Either at foundation level - maths of up to GCSE grade D standard; intermediate - maths up to GCSE grade A; advanced - each unit of maths equivalent to a unit of A level.

How will they work? Each unit requires 60 hours of teacher-directed study. They are designed to either help students without a GCSE who want to show some maths understanding, or students who have a GCSE in maths but want to reinforce or extend particular areas.

Some variations and information

AS levels can be completed over two years and A levels (that is, AS and A2 together) can be completed in one. And single AS levels (with no A2) can be taken in one year in the second year of sixth form.

Some schools will offer students the chance to do five AS levels in the first year, but only the strongest students will be advised to do so. A few, as now, may complete four A levels.

For a few minority languages - Arabic, Bengali, Chinese, Dutch, Gujarati, Japanese, modern Greek, modern Hebrew, Panjabi, Persian, Polish, Portuguese, Turkish - the A level will have four units instead of six (ie two at AS, two at A2).

Sixty-seven subjects will be available at AS and full A level. Five subjects will be available at AS but not at full A level: critical thinking; European studies; Science for Public Understanding; Social Science: Citizenship; World Development.

AEAs will be available in biology, chemistry, economics, English, French, geography, German, history, Latin, maths, physics, religious studies, Spanish, Welsh, and Welsh as a second language and, subject to confirmation, critical thinking.

Though AS and A2 will have three units each, the A2 will be more demanding than the AS. AS will be more "accessible". How will it work? fields.headline: Madrid, capital de la marcha
fields.standfirst: Spain is famous for its fiestas. But increasingly, youngsters see going out as just an opportunity to take drugs
fields.trailText: Spain is famous for its fiestas. But increasingly, youngsters see going out as just an opportunity to take drugs
fields.body:
Madrid tiene fama de ser una ciudad con mucha marcha. Fiesta es una palabra española incorporada al diccionario inglés. Las noches de marcha son muy largas, y la música y el baile continúan cuando sale el sol.

Cada vez más las drogas son también parte de la noche. Un 29% de los jóvenes salen de marcha para drogarse, según el estudio "Salir de marcha y consumo de drogas", del Plan Nacional sobre Drogas. Uno de cada tres menores de dieciocho años en España se emborracha una vez a la semana como mínimo.

Un 10% de los jóvenes mezcla alcohol, cannabis, éxtasis y cocaína, mientras que en Europa sólo un 2,8% mezcla las cuatro drogas. Tres millones de jóvenes han probado el éxtasis. Y para algunos ha sido mortal. Éste es el caso de J.P.M, de Madrid, de diecisiete años, y P.M.C, de Pineda de Mar, de catorce años.

Crees que España es el país de Europa con más marcha?

Elisa López (vive en Madrid y tiene 17 años): En Madrid por las noches hay mucha fiesta. Sin embargo está cambiando. Una nueva Ley de la Comunidad de Madrid prohíbe la venta de alcohol en discotecas y bares a menores de dieciocho años. Antes del verano podíamos beber alcohol a partir de los dieciséis años. El resultado es que la gente bebe más, pues se juntan los amigos para comprar alcohol y beber en los parques.

Juan Álvarez (vive en Madrid y tiene 19 años): Sí. Nosotros tenemos otra forma de vivir, de salir y de divertirnos. Lo hacemos con más alegría. Aquí normalmente se sale hasta las siete de la mañana, y en Francia, por ejemplo, a la una no queda nadie en las calles.

Cómo son las noches de marcha en Madrid?

Elisa: Empezamos a las siete y media en la discoteca de tarde, hasta las once y media. Entonces vamos a tomar algo. Pero queremos bailar más y a medianoche volvemos a la discoteca hasta las seis y media de la mañana. Se trata de bailar con la música a tope y sobretodo que sea bakalao. Al principio te lo pasas bien y luego te alocas. Es la obsesión de bailar y aguantar hasta el cierre. Los que aguantan todo son pastilleros porque los demás hacia las cuatro nos entra el sueño. Con mis amigas tomamos entonces una Coca-Cola y seguimos. Al final cada uno va a su bola. Se liga bastante, sobretodo por la noche. Viene un chico y te dice "quieres una copa?"

Juan: Aquí cada uno sale con una idea en la cabeza. Algunos salen a tomar copas y divertirse. Otros necesitan drogas para resistir. Y hay gente que bebe y se pone agresiva. Yo en Madrid recomiendo ir al Capital. Es una discoteca con siete plantas y en cada una hay un tipo de música diferente. Y los que no quieren bailar pueden ir a los bares de la calle Alonso Martínez. Están abiertos hasta las tres y media.

Los jóvenes españoles están entre los mayores consumidores de droga de Europa y de los primeros en empezar. Por qué crees que es así?

Elisa: Aquí es muy fácil comprar droga. En mi clase no hay pastilleros pero porros muchos. Y saben perfectamente dónde ir para comprar. Por qué? Después de toda la semana en el colegio acabamos estresados. Cuando llega el fin de semana nos decimos "voy a pillar el pedo del siglo". Las pastillas son lo más peligroso. Mucha gente las toma en las discotecas para aguantar más, para poder decir que han estado toda la noche. Depués, a las siete de la mañana van a otro sitio hasta las once.

Juan: Yo empecé a ver droga en el colegio a partir de los quince años. Se puso de moda. Muchos consumían para copiar a los amigos, para no sentirse marginados. Algunos pocos porque realmente querían probarlo. Empezaban con el porro. Ahora cada vez hay más jóvenes que dependen de la droga para salir y divertirse. Tengo amigos que podrían llegar a robar para consumir.

Crees que los padres españoles son más permisivos que los europeos?

Elisa: En España los jóvenes estamos más descontrolados y más libres. Llegas tarde a casa y nadie te ve. Los padres saben que sus hijos toman alcohol pero no tienen ni idea de que toman pastillas. Y tienen miedo a saber.

Juan: Los padres son bastante permisivos sobre la hora que vuelven los hijos a casa. Vas a la universidad, sales por la noche y a tu casa casi no vas. La mayoría salimos jueves, viernes y sábado hasta las siete de la mañana. La noche es tu terreno, te sientes más libre. Estás donde conoces todo y nadie te va a decir nada si tomas una copa de más. El consumo de drogas depende más del entorno del joven.

a tope to the maximum

emborracharse to get drunk

pasárselo bien to have a good time

fields.headline: The comprehensive spending review
fields.standfirst:
This afternoon Gordon Brown sets out his spending plans for the next three years. Julian Glover explains what lies behind his telephone number-sized figures

The comprehensive spending review
Live coverage and analysis of Gordon Brown's spending plans at 3pm today.
fields.trailText: 18 July, 10.30am: This afternoon Gordon Brown sets out his spending plans for the next three years. Julian Glover explains what lies behind his telephone number-sized figures.
fields.body:
Why all the fuss?
Today the chancellor, Gordon Brown, reveals the outcome of the Treasury's comprehensive spending review, the budget's twin sister. In the budget, the chancellor explains how he will raise money through taxes; today he explains how he intends to hand it out through spending. Since the budget happens every year but the spending review only every three years, today's announcement is arguably more important than budget day.

Will it affect me?
Yes, in a big way if you don't live in Scotland, Wales or Northern Ireland (whose budget allocations are calculated separately, although linked to the review). The review determines how much money government departments will have to spend over the next three years. The public finances are in a healthy state, so Mr Brown has a lot of cash to hand out - an extra £40bn over three years. This means that government spending will grow by 3.3% a year after inflation, far more than any government has been able to offer for years.

Where's the money likely to go?
Some parts of the review have already been announced. Health will swallow up £13bn; education is likely to get at least £10bn; while transport, crime, child poverty and regional development are all likely to do well. Defence and the environment will probably miss out. Many of the chancellor's decisions have been well trailed in advance - but his speech is likely to contain some surprises.

Why has the cake been divided like this?
Partly because of political priorities. Voters want more money spent on health and education and, with an election coming up, the government is keen to oblige. Likewise, transport looks likely to do well in the review partly because it has become a political hot potato.

So the chancellor's just trying to buy votes?
No. The review is also part of an ambitious Treasury project to revolutionise the way British government works. In the past, departments were allocated sums of money after months of tough negotiation. But they often had only a hazy idea of what they actually wanted to do with the cash they won, and had to spend it all within a year. This meant much of the money could have been spent more effectively. The Labour government decided to focus spending on "outcomes" - it asked departments what they wanted to do, rather than how much cash they wanted. Departments had to settle a series of "performance service agreements" (PSAs) in the first spending review, announced in 1998. In addition, the Treasury set up cross-departmental committees to consider spending on areas not properly covered by one department.

And did it work?
To an extent. But the Treasury's demands were so complex that some ministries ended up underspending. And critics claimed that the process effectively put the Treasury in charge of most government activity. In response, the Treasury has simplified the process, cutting the number of PSAs from 600 to 200, but retained what it claims is a coherent strategy for the future of the public sector.

What do the opposition parties think?
They believe the chancellor's generosity has much to do with the next election. The Liberal Democrats say that Mr Brown should have increased spending earlier and further. The Conservatives have promised to protect spending in key areas such as health and education, but it remains unclear whether they would cut taxes or invest more in areas such as transport.

fields.headline: Body identified: it is Sarah
fields.trailText: Sussex police today confirmed that the body of a young female found yesterday in undergrowth is that of missing schoolgirl Sarah Payne.
fields.body:
Sussex police today confirmed that the body of a young female found yesterday in undergrowth is that of missing schoolgirl Sarah Payne.

Assistant chief constable Nigel Yeo said the force had opened a murder inquiry into the eight-year-old's death and called for a minute's silence at a press conference a mile from the roadside spot near Pulborough, West Sussex, where Sarah's body was discovered.

Detectives believe Sarah's body had been dumped in the field on the first weekend in July. She disappeared on Saturday 1 July after a family day out at the beach at Littlehampton, about 12 miles south of Pulborough.

Mr Yeo would give no details of the death but said that Sarah's body was found naked. "She was unclothed, the clothing we have yet to find. That's what we're looking for in the field," he said.

The schoolgirl's parents Sara and Michael, both 31, from Surrey, have been informed of the latest developments, Mr Yeo confirmed.

Sarah's body was removed by two officers at about 9pm last night. Home Office pathologist Vesna Djurovic carried out the post-mortem examination overnight after the body was taken to the mortuary at Worthing hospital. Forensic officers today continued a fingertip search of the surrounding area using sniffer dogs.

She was last seen alive near her grandparents' home at Kingston Gorse, near East Preston, West Sussex. Police believe Sarah was abducted after she left her brother Lee, 13, and Luke, 11, and sister Charlotte, six, with whom she had been playing in a corn field.

Lee told police he saw a white Ford Transit-style van in the area at the time. A Littlehampton man was quizzed by police for more than 60 hours before being released without charge.

webTitle: Upbeat on downloads EMI takes the internet plunge

fields.headline: Upbeat on downloads EMI takes the internet plunge
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: EMI will today publish more than 300 "digital downloads" in the biggest move made by a major record label to sell music online.
fields.body:
EMI will today publish more than 300 "digital downloads" in the biggest move made by a major record label to sell music online.

The corporation will make available 200 singles and 100 full-length albums including music from artists like NWA, Blondie, Mel C, Poison and D'Angelo.

Customers can now buy music from over 50 internet music retailers including Amazon.com, CDNow and Virgin Jamcast. However, for now the music will be "territorially restricted" and only customers in the US will be able to buy EMI tracks online.

The price is expected to be comparable to that of a CD in the high street. "We believe our music has a fair value in the market," says Fergal Gara new media director of EMI records UK, "this is an experiment and we expect to determine the fair online price is time."

Mr Gara says EMI UK aims to roll-out a parallel service by the end of the year.

Online music pirates have been the bane of the music industry for some years. The popular MP3 file format is used to distribute music illegally with programs like Napster and Gnutella. EMI's downloads will be available in Microsoft's secure Windows Media format.

In the future EMI plans to launch versions in LiquidAudio's "secure" format too. The announcement has been made to coincide with Microsoft's release of its "version 7" of the Windows Media Player.

Jay Samit, senior vice-president of new media at EMI, said: "One of our goals is to make buying music as easy as stealing music, and making stealing music as hard as possible. Compare this to other labels and you'll see this is really a full-scale commitment."

In May Sony Music put 50 singles for sale online. However, in general major music labels have moved very slowly towards using downloads as a viable way to sell music.

The news comes as legal battles rage in the US. The Recording Industry Association of America is suing Napster - a service which lets its 20m subscribers share MP3 files for free - for copyright infringement.

fields.headline: Hillsborough police jury retires
fields.trailText:
A jury retired today to consider its verdict in the case of two former senior police officers accused of manslaughter at the
Hillsborough disaster.
fields.body:
A jury retired today to consider its verdict in the case of two former senior police officers accused of manslaughter at the Hillsborough disaster.

Former chief superintendent David Duckenfield and former superintendent Bernard Murray deny two sample charges of manslaughter at the disaster in April 1989, when 96 people died during an FA Cup semi-final between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest.

In the 27-day trial at Leeds crown court the prosecution said that the case, which has been brought by the Hillsborough Families Support Group, centres around the officers' failure to close a tunnel leading to pens three and four, where the victims died, after Exit Gate C was opened and thousands of fans flooded into the stadium.

Alun Jones QC, prosecuting, told the court that opening the gate while failing to close the tunnel at the Sheffield stadium was criminally negligent and amounted to manslaughter.

Mr Justice Hooper has told the jury of eight men and four women not to make a decision based on sympathy, either for the victims' families, who have packed the court's public gallery every day, or for the two defendants.

Mr Duckenfield, 55, of Bournemouth, Dorset, and Mr Murray, 58, of Pontefract, West Yorkshire, have since retired from South Yorkshire Police.

Former chief superintendent David Duckenfield and former superintendent Bernard Murray deny two sample charges of manslaughter at the disaster in April 1989, when 96 people died during an FA Cup semi-final between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest. In the 27-day trial at Leeds crown court the prosecution said that the case, which has been brought by the Hillsborough Families Support Group, centres around the officers' failure to close a tunnel leading to pens three and four, where the victims died, after Exit Gate C was opened and thousands of fans flooded into the stadium. Alun Jones QC, prosecuting, told the court that opening the gate while failing to close the tunnel at the Sheffield stadium was criminally negligent and amounted to manslaughter. Mr Justice Hooper has told the jury of eight men and four women not to make a decision based on sympathy, either for the victims' families, who have packed the court's public gallery every day, or for the two defendants. Mr Duckenfield, 55, of Bournemouth, Dorset, and Mr Murray, 58, of Pontefract, West Yorkshire, have since retired from South Yorkshire Police.

fields.headline: US vice-presidents in the running
fields.standfirst: The presidential contest has failed to stir much public interest - but rumours about Bush and Gore's likely choice of running mates abound, reports Martin Kettle in Washington
fields.trailText: 18 July, 11.30am: The presidential contest has failed to stir much public interest - but rumours about Bush and Gore's likely choice of running mates abound , reports Martin Kettle in Washington.
fields.body:
If you believe one report this week, only three people - George W Bush, his wife Laura and the former defence secretary Dick Cheney - know the identity of the man, or possibly the woman, who will be Bush's vice-presidential running mate in November.

According to another report yesterday, the search for Bush's Veep - which Cheney has been coordinating at the Texas governor's behest for several weeks - has now been narrowed down to four serious contenders: Governor Frank Keating of Oklahoma, Governor Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, Senator Chuck Hagel of Nebraska and Senator Fred Thompson of Tennessee.

A third story says that Bush will make the announcement as early as next Monday, in order to maximise publicity in the days leading up to the Republican national convention, which opens in Philadelphia on July 31.

It is perfectly possible that all three stories are true, and that Bush will indeed tap one of the four names on Cheney's list next week. If this is the case Ridge would be the most moderate of the choices, Keating the most conservative and the two senators, both of whom were John McCain supporters during the primary races, somewhere in the middle.

There is stiffening resistance to Ridge among Republican conservatives because of his tolerance of abortion rights. But he might be the electorally clever choice, if the eventual race is as tight as the latest opinion polls suggest. Two new polls yesterday show Al Gore closing to within two points of Bush. The contest in November could come down to a close fight in a handful of key swing states, including Ridge's Pennsylvania.

But don't bet on it. The choice of running mate is the next key stage in the 2000 US presidential election, and in a contest that has failed to capture the public imagination so far, both sides believe that the announcement of who is on the ticket will be crucial to getting the next bounce in the opinion polls.

For that reason, it is in the parties' interests to stir speculation about the Veep issue. Over the past week, there have been apparently authoritative stories linking Bush to Governor George Pataki of New York, a moderate, and to Congressman John Kasich, the chairman of the House budget committee and a conservative. Some Washington insiders will tell you that Senator Dick Lugar of Indiana is still in the frame too. Governor Christie Whitman of New Jersey, a more liberal equivalent of Ridge, cannot be wholly ruled out either.

My own guess - and, let's be frank, that is all that it is - would be for Ridge, if only because everything else that Bush has done in the last two months has been straight out of the Bill Clinton "How To Win From The Centre" playbook. Clinton's instinct was to go for a political soulmate. If Bush follows suit, he will go for a fellow centrist like Ridge.

Al Gore has the luxury of being able to wait and see who his rival selects. But Gore is likely to act quickly once Bush has chosen. Indeed Gore's advisers are pressing him to steal some of the Republicans' thunder by announcing the Democratic number two on August 4, the day after the Republican convention ends.

Be that as it may, the latest polls will also encourage Gore to go for a centrist Democrat rather than someone that might balance the ticket in the traditional pre-Clinton manner. Right on cue, last week's speculation that Congressman Dick Gephardt was under consideration has evaporated. Everything points to Gore choosing a fellow moderate such as Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, a name increasingly mentioned, or his Senate colleague Joe Lieberman of Connecticut. Governor Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire is surely also in the running.

But, if Gore's assessment is similar to Bush's probable thinking, then he too will be looking for a party centrist from a state he might not otherwise win. In that case, Senator Bob Graham of Florida becomes the most logical choice for the Democratic ticket. But since when were such choices made wholly on the basis of logic?

fields.headline: England's team effort a cakewalk
fields.trailText: England's last appearance in a one-day international at Edgbaston produced the so-long-and-thanks-for-all-the-fish loss to India in last year's World Cup. Today their display would merit an exemplar performance in the hitch-hikers guide to one-day cricket.
fields.body:
England's last appearance in a one-day international at Edgbaston produced the so-long-and-thanks-for-all-the-fish loss to India in last year's World Cup. Today their display would merit an exemplar performance in the hitch-hikers guide to one-day cricket.

Before now, England had collapsed or cakewalked their way through this competition. Marcus Trescothick had scored most of their runs (with a little help from Alec Stewart in one game, and Graeme Hick in another), while England's bowlers had done what they have grown used to doing - either try to dig the batsmen out of the hole or win the match on their own.

This time round it was a team effort, as Marcus Trescothick - two fours and a six in his 20 - fell victim to Heath Streak and the law of averages.

Alec Stewart made his third one-day hundred, a typical riposte from a man restored to the ranks yet again. His captain looked in far better nick than he has all season. Nasser Hussain suited coming in at No. 6, a position he should consider batting in the Test series. Graham Thorpe steadied the ship without doing anything spectacular.

Craig White hit two sixes in a row off Grant Flower and though Hick didn't score any runs he took two wickets in consecutive balls, and in the same over safely snatched Mark Ealham's return to run out Murray Goodwin.

The one player who didn't do himself any favours was Andy Flintoff - who was lucky to make 24. He was dropped once, and bisected the keeper and first slip with another edge. His dismissal, a flat-footed, stationary carve, will not have endeared him to the selectors who are faced with a rare treasure chest of batting riches for the Old Trafford Test.

The Zimbabweans didn't bowl a single maiden (England bowled four in the first ten overs). And they had problems with their own resident chubster, Alistair Campbell, who managed to run out two of his fleet-footed team-mates, Murray Goodwin and Grant Flower - the masterminds of that brilliant run-chase against West Indies on Sunday.

They also bowled negatively, with both Dirk Viljoen and Grant Flower pitching slow left-armers over the wicket into the rough. The Edgbaston crowd must have been dying for the musical entertainment forbidden them by the spoilsports of Birmingham. And their batsmen lacked sparkle.

For the first time in their entire history of one-day international contests, England have one over the Zimbos: they lead 8-7. Nine-seven has a nicer ring to it, don't you think?

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.headline: Augenzeuge
fields.standfirst: Alois Bäurle, a police dog-trainer, talks about the ban on hunting dogs in Bavaria
fields.trailText: Alois Bäurle, a police dog-trainer, talks about the ban on hunting dogs in Bavaria
fields.body:
Die Unfälle, die in der vergangenen Zeit mit Kampfhunden passiert sind, zeigen in meinen Augen vor allem eines: Jeder Mensch, der einen Hund hat, sollte ihn auch entsprechend ausbilden lassen, um reagieren zu können, wenn sich das Tier falsch verhält. Klar: Wenn junge Hunde mal etwas anstellen, dann liegt das in der Natur der Sache. Die jungen Tiere haben ihren Spiel- und Jagdtrieb, doch Besitzer und Hund müssen dieses Verhalten als falsch erkennen und wissen, wie sie es korrigieren können. Dies trifft vor allem auf Halter von Kampfhunden zu. Sie sollten zumindest ein Seminar besuchen und lernen, wie man mit einem solchen Tier umgehen muß.

In unserem Gebiet wurde vor einigen Wochen ein kleines Kind von einem jungen Pitbull gebissen. Es hatte nur kleine Wunden, die auch gar nicht tief waren. Wahrscheinlich wollte der Hund nur mit dem Kind spielen und hat es dabei verletzt. Als wir zu der Familie kamen, haben wir gesehen, daß der Hund völlig falsch gehalten wurde; in einer Wohnung, ohne Gehege. Deshalb haben wir uns auch dafür eingesetzt, daß das Tier woanders hinkommt. Die Familie hat sich allerdings ganz verständig gezeigt und sofort zugestimmt. Das Problem für uns ist nur: Viele Tierheime hier nehmen gar keine Kampfhunde an. Und das macht es ziemlich schwierig, eine neue Unterbringung für diese Hunde zu finden. Vor kurzem hatten wir auch einen Obdachlosen in der Stadt, der mit einem Kampfhund unterwegs war, ihn aber leider nicht an der Leine hatte. Aber auch das haben wir in den Griff gekriegt.

Leider macht sich zur Zeit Hysterie unter den Leuten breit. Aber nicht jeder KampfHund ist gefährlich für seine Umwelt.

Glossar/ Glossary

etw. anstellen: to do sth. wrong
begutachten: to observe closely
Gassi gehen: to take a dog for a walk
das Gehege: a cage; area with a fence
scharf machen: to train (a dog) to attack people and other animals
der Unfall: accident
die Zucht, züchten: to breed

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the part-baked rumours cooked in an oven for seven minutes, removed when brown and served hot with butter
fields.trailText: Aston Villa will attempt to buy Tottenham's David Ginola, Leicester midfielder Neil Lennon and Liverpool left-back Steve Staunton before the start of the season, according to chairman Doug Ellis. But Villa face competition for the signature of Ginola from Marseille, who are willing to pay £2.5m for the winger's services.
fields.body:
Aston Villa will attempt to buy Tottenham's David Ginola, Leicester midfielder Neil Lennon and Liverpool left-back Steve Staunton before the start of the season, according to chairman Doug Ellis. But Villa face competition for the signature of Ginola from Marseille, who are willing to pay £2.5m for the winger's services.

Real Madrid will unveil Barcelona's Luis Figo either tomorrow or at the start of next week, according to varied reports from Spain. "I have always trusted the word of Florentino Perez [the new Real president who pledged to sign Figo if he was elected] and he has this assurance that the player will be in Madrid," confirmed new vice-president Fernando Fernandez Tapias. Barcelona cannot stop the move, as Real have met the conditions of the buy-out clause in Figo's contract.

Newcastle defender Steve Howey is a target for Liverpool, according to the Sun. The former England international nearly went to Anfield two years ago, and Phil Thompson is said to be a big admirer of the 28-year-old. But the Liverpool assistant manager faces competition from Arsenal and Aston Villa.

The Star suggests that West Ham, Everton and Leicester are interested in Temuri Ketsbaia, who has been left out of the squad for Newcastle's pre-season tour of the United States along with Marcelino, Silvio Maric and Laurent Charvet.

Sheffield Wednesday's Niclas Alexandersson has turned down Bradford and will join Everton in a £2.5m deal.

Leicester have pulled ahead of Birmingham in the race for Wolverhampton Wanderers striker Ade Akinbiyi with a club-record offer of £5m.

Charlton and Ipswich have both had £4m bids for Bolton's Claus Jensen accepted. The Danish midfielder will decide who to join after talks next week.

Belgium international Marc Wilmots is wanted by Celtic. The 31-year-old Schalke 04 midfielder has visited Glasgow to discuss terms with Martin O'Neill.

Southampton striker Luis Boa-Morte will play for Fulham in a friendly in France with a view to a permanent move to Craven Cottage.

Blackburn hope to re-sign Wales defender Chris Coleman from Fulham. The player, who cost £2.2m when he left Ewood Park for Craven Cottage, would return in a £3.5m deal.

Norwich are to give a trail to Carlos Hasselbaink, the 31-year-old brother of £15m Chelsea striker Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink. They are also interested in Arsenal's 18-year-old striker Graham Barrett.

Sheffield United are poised to sign Reading and ex-Tottenham midfielder Darren Caskey.

webTitle: Working Title tops Hollywood's most powerful Brit list

fields.headline: Working Title tops Hollywood's most powerful Brit list
fields.trailText: The names of Tim Bevan and Eric Fellner may be unfamiliar to the average film-goer, but according to the Sun, they are the most powerful Brits in Hollywood today
fields.body:
The names of Tim Bevan and Eric Fellner may be unfamiliar to the average film-goer, but according to the Sun, they are the most powerful Brits in Hollywood today.

Over a two-day feature, listing the top 100 powerful Brits, called the Brollywood 100, Working Title Film's co-chairmen were placed at number one, over perhaps the more familiar names of Hugh Grant (number 12), Jude Law (9) and Kate Winslet (7). Grant's former partner Liz Hurley only managed to make it to number 31.

Working Title were responsible for the hugely successful Four Weddings and A Funeral (pictured), Notting Hill and Bean, and are currently producing the film versions of Bridget Jones' Diary and Captain Corelli's Mandolin. They recently signed a $400m deal with Universal Studios to produce five films a year.

Tim Bevan founded the company in the 80s to make videos for pop groups such as Frankie Goes to Hollywood. Eric Fellner joined in 1992, and they haven't looked back since. Tim says the key to their success is simple. "Whether a film is British or American is not important, the aim is to make movies the world wants to see. But at the end of the day, it's luck."

The list was compiled after speaking to industry experts, and is based on power, connections, money and earning potential. At number two is Ridley Scott, the Durham-born director and producer who has already produced the biggest blockbuster of the summer, Gladiator, which has already earned £275m internationally. Catherine Zeta-Jones and Sam Mendes come in at number three and four respectively.

Despite a series of major flops, Euan McGregor is still considered highly influential, and comes in at number 8 - presumably due to his Stars Wars role. Emma Thompson at number 11 is way above her ex-husband Kenneth Branagh who only manages number 36.

Surprisingly it would seem that Rupert Everett (number 18) is deemed more influential than the double-Oscar winning Sir Michael Caine (number 22). Samantha Morton, who was Oscar-nominated for her role in Woody Allen's Sweet and Lowdown, only manages number 64, putting her below ex-Brookside star, Anna Friel (51) whose films Rogue Trader and Mad Cows both met with critical derision.

webTitle: Bid speculation bolsters shares in ITV firms

fields.headline: Bid speculation bolsters shares in ITV firms
fields.trailText: Shares in ITV companies Carlton Communications and United News & Media rebounded yesterday as investors bet on the merger breaking down and one or both becoming bid targets.
fields.body:
Shares in ITV companies Carlton Communications and United News & Media rebounded yesterday as investors bet on the merger breaking down and one or both becoming bid targets.

Speculation was growing that relations between the two sides could sour after demands made by Carlton that the deal be renegotiated to reflect the government's ruling on the merger.

Granada Media, which said at the start of the year that it hoped to bid for either, was last night still keeping its cards close to its chest.

Other potential bidders, however, have also emerged including RTL Group, the newly formed pan-European television business in which Pearson has a stake.

Carlton shares rose 3.7% to 798.5p, while United shares closed the day 3.6% higher at 917p. Granada Media was 0.5% up at 597p.

Carlton is calling for a renegotiation of the terms of its putative deal with United to reflect trade secretary Stephen Byers' insistence that the United-owned Meridian franchise be sold. United shares have also underperformed Carlton's since the deal was struck last November.

The boards of Carlton and United are expected to meet separately this week to discuss the implications of the ruling by Mr Byers. Takeover panel rules give the parties three weeks before they need to make their next moves public.

webTitle: Police hunt killer of mother and two children

fields.headline: Police hunt killer of mother and two children
fields.trailText: A murder hunt was under way today after a mother and her two young children were found dead at their home.
fields.body:
A murder hunt was under way today after a mother and her two young children were found dead at their home.

Police alerted by concerned relatives said the three had died "violent" deaths.

The woman, in her early 30s, and her eight-year-old son and seven-year-old daughter, were discovered at their terraced house in Northampton, yesterday afternoon.

A Northamptonshire Police spokeswoman said inquiries were under way to trace the woman's husband, who has not been named.

webTitle: Brown's spending review - a crucial moment for Britain

fields.headline: Brown's spending review - a crucial moment for Britain
fields.standfirst: The battle lines are drawn for the next election, says the Observer's chief political commentator, Andrew Rawnsley - it's Labour's investment in public services versus Tory tax cuts
fields.trailText: 18 July, 5.45pm:The battle lines are drawn for the next election, says the Observer's chief political commentator, Andrew Rawnsley - it's Labour's investment in public services versus Tory tax cuts.
fields.body:
This afternoon was a fulcrum moment for the government, for the Conservatives and for the future of Britain.

The battle lines of the next election are now clear. For all the talk of an end to isms, and predictions of the death of ideology, there is still a large and defining divide between right and left.

New Labour presents itself to the country as the party of public services. It has never before so boldly made the centre-left arguments for collective provision funded by taxation.

In their first two years in power, Tony Blair and Gordon Brown bound themselves into an eye-wateringly tight spending straitjacket for reasons which had as much to do with politics as they did with economics. Haunted by the fear that economic calamity would shipwreck them as it did every previous Labour government, desperate above all else to retain the confidence of the markets, the chancellor's favourite squeeze was prudence.

She was not entirely jilted this afternoon. Mr Brown told us that he would be repaying even more of the national debt than had been forecast.

But the chancellor spent most of his time at the despatch box dancing with Miss Bountiful. The stays on the spending corset burst off with an unprecedented cascade of money into those services which matter most to the public: education, transport, and law and order. Following the large sums already allocated to health, New Labour finally puts large money where the government's modernising mouth has been.

There are some risks here. Much of the additional investment will not arrive until after the general election; mid-way through the next parliament. Is it entirely coincidental that this is precisely the moment when Chancellor Brown might hope to become prime minister if Mr Blair decides to spend more time with his family?

The billions sound impressive, but both Mr Blair and Mr Brown are now aware that telephone number sums are meaningless to most people. New Labour's habit of over-boosting and regurgitating previous spending announcements has spread cynicism.

The voters will not be impressed until this money produces tangible improvements; better schools, hospitals, and railways that people can touch and taste.

That is why Mr Brown laid such heavy emphasis on rewards for results. "Money will be tied to performance," as he put it. If it does not bring about the decisive improvements to the NHS and education that the voters are now led to expect, then support for public provision is likely to be seriously weakened.

The left has to show that these large wedges of extra funding can make a real difference. If New Labour fails to deliver, then the case for active government will be badly undermined, which can only be of assistance to the arguments of the right.

"We will fight the next election as the low tax party," declared Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, advertising more clearly than ever the Conservative agenda. This is a gamble on the mendacity of the electorate.

When majorities tell the pollsters that they would rather have improved services to tax cuts, the Tories assume they are lying. The least convincing part of an underwhelming performance from Mr Portillo was when he was challenged to say which services the Tories will slash to fund tax cuts.

"Which schools? Which hospitals? How many teachers? How many nurses?" demanded Mr Brown. This is the challenge on which New Labour will seek to impale the Tories on every day until the next polling day.

Investment in public services versus tax cuts. That is now the essence of the struggle between New Labour and the Conservatives, a battle not just between politicians, but for the future of Britain.

fields.headline: Charles rules out marrying Camilla
fields.trailText: The Prince of Wales has issued his strongest rebuttal yet to rumours he is planning to marry Camilla Parker Bowles.
fields.body:
The Prince of Wales has issued his strongest rebuttal yet to rumours he is planning to marry Camilla Parker Bowles.

A strongly worded letter to the press complaints commission, written on behalf of the prince by his private secretary, Stephen Lamport, makes an official complaint about a newspaper report that alleged he was "exploring" the possibility of marrying Camilla in "secret discussions" with the Church of Scotland.

The unprecedented letter, which represents the first formal complaint Prince Charles has made to the press watchdog on his own behalf, insists that there was no truth in the article, published by the Sunday Times last month. He has previously only complained about potential invasion of privacy on behalf of his sons.

The PCC is asked by Mr Lamport to investigate the report, headlined "Charles explores Scottish wedding with Camilla".

The report followed Mrs Parker Bowles' surprise ap pearance at a dinner in Holyroodhouse attended by a number of senior clergy.

He wrote: "I should like to make clear that there is no truth whatsoever to the story and I should be very grateful if you would investigate this misleading report."

It is understood that Prince Charles and Mrs Parker Bowles gave their full support to the contents of the letter sent to the PCC.

The couple became the focus of intense speculation over plans for their future after they stepped into the public spotlight together at the Ritz last year.

Earlier this year, the Queen met Mrs Parker Bowles at a barbecue at Highgrove, the prince's country home.

A courtier quoted in the Times today says: "We have got to the end of our tether. There is no intention of remarrying. We keep saying it, but it is ignored or dismissed as dissembling. There is to be no wedding."

The Queen is also understood to have been informed of her son's complaint to the PCC before it was lodged.

webTitle: Policy and Politics : Sleaze allegations warning to MPs

fields.headline: Policy and Politics : Sleaze allegations warning to MPs
fields.trailText:
MPs were warned yesterday not to use the Commons standards watchdog to make "tit for tat" sleaze
           allegations against each other in the run-up to the general election.
fields.body:
MPs were warned yesterday not to use the Commons standards watchdog to make "tit for tat" sleaze allegations against each other in the run-up to the general election.

Robert Sheldon, chairman of the Commons standards and privileges committee, said that the committee would regard it as "a very serious matter" if MPs were to put in trivial allegations of rule-breaking in order to score party political points to further their party's election campaign.

He was giving evidence to Lord Neill's committee on standards in public life on the final day of its hearings into whether the House of Lords should have a compulsory register of interests and a code of conduct. Peers who oppose a register claim that it could lead to political point-scoring in the Lords.

Mr Sheldon said: "The tit for tat situation concerns me greatly, where people outside the Commons are willing to trip up others.

"This is getting quite serious because my task has been to improve the reputation of the house, and what we are seeing is that trivial matters are being put forward ... you get that particularly in the run-up to a general election."

Nobody in parliament "wants to be under suspicion when they have not done anything wrong," Mr Sheldon said.

The problem was the publicity that surrounded complaints made to the parliamentary commissioner: often complaints later proved groundless, yet this outcome was not reported subsequently in the newspapers.

Mr Sheldon said that he was concerned about a recent complaint about the former prime minister John Major having to disclose all the money he received from his lecture tours after signing an agency contract. Mr Major has still to agree the detail of the contract to be lodged with the register.

"John Major made a very sensible point that the agency didn't employ him, he employed the agency. I feel very strongly for him," Mr Sheldon said.

Mr Sheldon distinguished between trivial and serious complaints - an example of the latter leading to Teresa Gorman, Tory MP for Billericay, being suspended for a month, for covering up her investments and threatening those members of the public who provided the information. Two recent examples of trivial complaints - against Fabian Hamilton, Labour MP for Leeds north east, and Frank Cook, Labour MP for Stockton north - were thrown out by Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards, and by the committee.

Later, Baroness Jay, leader of the Lords, told Lord Neill that the government wanted a compulsory register of inter ests for all peers similar to the wide-ranging one in the Commons.

"It is anomalous that the House of Lords alone does not have a standards and ethics framework at a time when the House of Commons, local government and other public institutions are developing their own frameworks," she said.

"There is extensive anecdotal evidence that peers are, albeit inadvertently, failing to declare interests - either at the beginning of what they say in the chamber or, in some cases, at all.

"The relevance of peers' non-parliamentary activity to their parliamentary activity appears not to be in the forefront of their minds."
